QUESTIONS, AND CASES OF Conscience About ABSTINENCE in the Use of Lawful
things.
CHAP. I.
Quest. WHether may a man sin in the use of Lawful things?

Answ. Yea, abuse of lawful things is damnable, as well as the use of unlawful.
The abuse of lawful profits, pleasures, cares, and desires, choaks the seed of
the Word, Mat. 13.22. So Mat. 24.38. As in the days of Noah they did eat, they
drank, they married, and gave in marriage, until the day that Noah entered into
the Ark, etc. What? was it a sin to eat, to drink, to marry? No, but they
sinned in the abuse of these things, they were so intent upon these, that they
cast off all admonitions, and predictions of judgment. So Luke 14.18. What was
more lawful then to buy a Farm, a yoke of Oxen, or to mar^y a Wife? Yet these
shall never taste of the Supper: not because they did these things, but because
they were so inordinately intent upon them, that they refused the Call to the
Kings Supper. So 1 Cor. 10.7. The people sa^e down to eat, and drink, and rose
up to play.

Quest. Why is there so much danger in the use of lawful things?

Answ. 1. Because in using lawful things men are most secure, and think
themselves Liberties: As he laid his train against Christ himself, in the
matter of meat, and drink, when he was an hungry, Mat. 4.3. So also against us,
chiefly in things wherein God has given us allowance. Wherein was it that
Satan overcame Lot? Was it first in Incest with his daughters? No: but he first
foiled him in that which was lawful: He first abused himself with Wine, and
then in Incest.





Quest. What instances may be given to show how men abuse their lawful
Liberties with the hazard of their souls?

Answ. 1. In eating and drinking, which is not only lawful but necessary: yet
here Christians offend many ways.

1. When they eat not their own bread, earned by their lawful labor, 2 These.
3.12.

2. When they feed themselves without fear, Jude 12. not as before the Lord.

3. When they corrupt themselves in the creatures, losing sobriety, modesty,
chastity, health, and reason.

4. When they never taste the sweetness of God in the creature, more then
beasts do: nor sanctify themselves after feasting: as Job did his sons, Job
1.5.

5. When they waste the creatures, not remembering the afflictions of Jos^ph,
Amos 6.6.



First, for the matter, which is not skins as Adams, but stately and costly
beyond their rank.

2. For the manner, while they take liberty to disguise themselves in strange
attire, and monstrous fashions, showing no other hidden man of the heart but
lightness, vanity, wantonness, and thraldom, to every newfangled fashion,
for which the Lord threatened to visit the Kings children, Zeph. 1.8.

3. For the measure whilst they pass all bounds of sobriety, and prodigally
waste more on their backs, then would cloth a number of the poor servants of
Jesus Christ.

In recreation: which are both lawful and necessary: yet how do men sin

1. In respect of the matter, when with the fool, (Prove. 26.18) they make a
sport of sin: as of Dice, Cards, lascivious Dancing, Plays, Interludes, and
all other sports, wherein is neither praise, virtue, nor good report, Phil. 4.8.

2. In respect of the manner, when they turn their vocation into recreation,
pouring out their hearts unto pleasure, being lovers of pleasure more then of
God, 2 Timothy 3.4. when they waste their precious time in sports, hindering better
duties, both in their general and particular callings: dishonouring the sacred
Name of God by Oaths, blasphemous cursings, jesting upon the Holy Word of God,
jeering his Ministers, Servants, Religion, etc. or when others are hurt by
their sports, and gain by winning their money to their prejudice: or their own
estate, as Solomon says, He that loves pastime shall be a poor man, Prove.
21.17.

In Marriage: what is more necessary for man's comfort, and for the continuance
Only in the Lord, 1 Cor. 7.39. Joining themselves with Infidels, Heretics, and
enemies to the true Religion; as did Solomon to the turning away his heart from
the Lord. Others use it rather to the stirring up of natural corruptions then
to allay them: Some rather to further each other to hell then to heaven,
whilst the husband loses his authority by unthriftinesse, bitterness, or
lightness: and the wise shakes off her subjection by fullennesse, and contempt
both of his person, and commandments: Others sin more directly when the husband
leaves the wife of his youth, and embraces the bosom of a stranger: or the
wife forsakes the guide of her youth, and loves a stranger better.

In a man's calling, wherein its lawful and necessary for a man to busy
himself: Manna on the Sabbath-dayes, which shall rot between their teeth: or by
driving their Trades with as many glossings, lies and oaths, almost as words:
or by turning their Trades into Crafts, and Mysteries of Iniquity, getting as
much by Deceit and Injustice, as by fair dealing: or by choking their general
calling by their special, scarce allowing any time to Gods service, etc.

In providing for a man's family, which is lawful and necessary, and he that
does is worse then an Infidel, 1 Timothy 5.8. yet herein many sin by carking
cares: not seeking first the Kingdom of God for themselves and theirs, but
becoming drudges to the world, and to their children, neglecting to bring them
up in the nurture and instruction of the Lord, as they are commanded, Ephesians.
6.4.

In company and society with men, which is sweet and necessary, man being

Quest. What means may we use to prevent our abuse of these lawful things?

Answ. 1. Consider that lawful liberty used to the full extent of it, is
exceeding dangerous, and therefore some restraint is necessary. He that will
take all the liberty he may, will sometimes take that he ought not: and the more
the flesh is pampered, the more the spirit is weakened and foiled.

Romans 11.36. Of him, and through him, and to him are all things, to whom be
glory for ever, 1 Cor. 10.31. Whether ye eat, or drink or whatsoever you do, do
all to the glory of God.

Romans 13.14. In Marriage, meditate much on that sweet contract between Christ
and the soul: and so in the rest. This is an holy Alchimy, that draws Gold out
of Lead, Heaven out of Earth, and Grace out of Nature.

Acts 9.31. For where the Lord affords more outward blessings, and with them,
more time and means to serve him, he looks for the more service from them.

Job, when his sons feasted together, sanctified them, and sac^ificed according
to the number of them, saying, It may be my sons have sinned, etc. Job 1.5. Do
thou the like, mingle not thy joy with sin, lest it end in woe. Dr. Tailor on
the Parable of the Sower, p. 164.

CHAP. II. Questions, and Cases of Conscience about our Actions, Natural,
Civil, Recreative, Religious, etc.
Quest. WHat makes an Action good?

Answ. Every truly commendable and comfortable Action must consist of an
absolute integrity of all concurrents, and requisites. For though some mixture
of infirmities and imperfections will cleave to the face of the fairest action
(an absolute unstained purity being incompatible with mortality) yet every
several Ingredient must be attended, and temper^ with its own particular
goodness, and honesty, and seasonable conformity to the whole, or else the
whole action, though right in other respects, is utterly disrobed of all true
splendour, acceptance, and grace. Here a little leaven ^oures the whole lump:
and the iniquity, defect, and exorbitancy of any one ingredient, denominates
the whole action naught.

Quest. What are the Ingredients requisite to make an Action good?

Answ. 1. It must be good in its own nature, and warranted by Gods Word, by
which all things must be sanctified to us, 1 Timothy 4.5. Otherwise let the person

The Object about which the Action is exercised, must be qualified according to
the Rules of Religion. As works of charity are sweet sacrifices to God: but

We must look to the matter, else all may be marred. As for instance, the
matter of our beneficence must be our own goods got lawfully, else in respect
of

The person must be pleasing to God, else his best deeds are but beautiful
abominations. If the person be not justified by faith, and accepted through
Prove. 15.8, 9. So in the Pharisee, Luke 18.14.

Judas preached and wrought miracles, yet was a desperate hypocrite: See how
the Israelites sought God, and enqui^ed early after him, Psalm. 78.34 etc. yet
because their hearts were not upright God rejected them.

we must not do evil that good may come of it, Romans 3.8.

Mat. 6.5, 6. Meditation of divine things is an excellent duty: but not when
the Preacher is praying, etc.

Jehu did excellent service* by rooting out the idolatrous house of Ahab; and
destroying Baals Priests: yet it was but murder in Gods account, Hosea 1.4.
because he sought himself, and not Gods glory therein. See Boltons General
Directions for a comfortable walking with God, p. 149.

Quest. What things can make a good action to become evil?

Answ. 1. Impenitency in any sin will stain any action, be it in it self never
so good, Isa. 1.13, to 16.

Mat. 6.2, 6.

Heb. 11.6. when we either know not our warrant for it, or believe not Gods
acceptance of it.

Prove. 19.2. when we have not respect to the circum^ances of well-doing: when
good duties are done rudely, etc. whereas we should be wise to do good, Romans
16.19.

Josh. 24.14, 15. when our works are dead works, Hebr. 9.14. Deuteronomy 28.47.



Col. 3.17. Phil. 3.3.



Quest. Can any thing we do be good, when all our righteousnesses are as filthy
rags? Isa. 64.6.

Ans. Our works in themselves are not good, but by Gods indulgence assured unto
us in the New Covenant they are: where God

1. Accepts the will for the deed: we do well, when we desire and endeavor to
do as well as we can.

2. God beholds the work in Christ: and through his intercession passes by the
evil that cleaves to our best actions.

3. God regards it, as proceeding from his own spirit in us, who causes us to
do good, and works our works for us: as in Ptayer, Romans 8.26.

Mr. Byfield on Peter.

CHAP. III. Questions, and Cases of Conscience about Adoption.
Quest. HOw many sorts of sons are there?

Answ. Four; 1. There is a son by eternal generation:

2. By Creation; and so Adam, and the Angels are

3. By natural generation; and so Cain was the son of Adam.

4. By Adoption: and so Moses was the son of Pharaohs daughter. And

Quest. How manifold is Adoption?

Answ. Twofold: 1. External, whereby the Lord takes a people by outward
Covenant and Dispensation to be his sons: and thus the Jews were Gods first
Exodus 4.22. and unto them did belong the Adoption, Romans 9.4, 5. and hence their
children were accounted sons, as well as Saints, and holy, 1 Cor. 7.14. Ezekiel.
16.20, 21. but many fall from this Adoption, as the Jews did.

2. Internal, whereby the Lord out of everlasting love to particular persons in
Isaac by special Promise was accounted for the seed, Romans 9.8.

Quest. How manifold is this internal Adoption?

Answ. Twofold: 1. Adoption begun, 1 John 3.1, 2. Now are we the sons of God,
to whom yet the Lord behaves himself for some time, and for some special Gal.
4.1, 2. because some spirits will not be the better for the love of their
Father, but the worse, and therefore he is feign to keep an hard hand over
them. To others he behaves himself with more special respect, enabling them
with more boldness to cry Abba Father, Romans 8.15, 16. who are more easily bent
to his will by love.

Adoption perfected, when we shall receive all the privileges of sons, not one
excepted, Romans 8.23. where we are said to wait for the Adoption, the Redemption
By the first we are sons, but not seen and known to be such, 1 John 3.1, 2. By
the second, we shall be known before all the world to be so.

Quest. What is the manner of Adoption begun here in this world?

Answ. 1. God loves Jesus Christ with an unspeakable love as his only Son, and
our elder brother.



Ephesians. 1.5, 6. His love is not now toward us as to Adam, his Son by Creation:
but in loving his own Son immediately, hence he loves us, adopts us, and
accounts us his children.

Quest. What are the benefits and comforts that flow to us from hence?

Answ. If we are sons, then the Lord prizes and esteems us as sons: yea, the
poorest, weakest, feeblest believer, is more esteemed by God then all the
world, and the glory of it: yea, then all the Kings, and great men in the
world, Isa. 43.4, 5, 6. not because they can deserve it, but because he has
freely made them sons.

Mat. 6.31, 32. and if at any time we fall into want, and straits, the Lord
intends thereby our eternal good: Hence come all Gods corrections, Deuteronomy. 8.5.
Heb. 12.8.

Israel may say, My God has forsaken, and forgotten me, Isa. 49.14. and yet no
mother tenders her child, as the Lord does his children. Yea, he freely those
us to be his sons, and therefore loves us notwithstanding all our sins, Psalm.
89.32, 33. If he see Ephraim bemoaning his stubbornness, as well as his
sickness: as Jer. 31.20. God cries out, Is not he my Son?

heirs, and co-heires with Christ, Romans 8.17. sons by nature are all heirs,
but all sons by Adoption are: We are heirs, First, of the Kingdom of glory, 1
Pet. 1.4, 5. Secondly, of all this visible world, 1 Cor. 3.22. not that we have
it all in our own hand; it would be too cumbersome for us: but we have the use
and comfort of it. Thirdly, we are heirs of the Promise, Heb. 11.9. and 6.17.
whereby the Lord himself comes to be our inheritance and portion for ever.

Romans 8.15, 16. And hereby 1. We shall be enabled to pray to God, who before
could not do it, our mouths being stopped with guilt. 2. To cry Abba, Father,
and this spirit witnesses that we are sons of this Father. 3. Hereby we are
led and guided continually toward our last end: whence it is, that the same
sins which harden others, at last humble us: the same temptations by which
others fall, and perish, serve at last to purify us: Hence our decay in grace,
leads us to growth at last: Hence our fears and doubts serve to establish us
at last: Our wanderings from God for a time, make us esteem more of the Presence
and ways of God at the last. See Shepherds Sound Believer, p. 277.

Mal. 3.17.

Quest. How may we know our Adoption?

Answ. By our resemblance of God, as a natural child is like his natural
father.

Quest. But how may this be known?

Answ. 1. Examine the life of God in thee, who naturally art dead in sin. The
breath of this life is heavenly thoughts, meditations, affections: The Actions
of this life are spiritual growth, and increase in grace and virtue. The
maintenance of this life, is hungring and thirsting after heavenly Manna, and
Water of Life, the Word of God. The very being of it is our union and communion
with God by the Spirit, which is as the soul to the body.

and if thou be his child, thou art a child of light. As thou growest in
understanding thy Fathers Will, so thou growest in his Image, and art like
Christ thy elder brother, and have his Image renewed in knowledge, etc.

See whether thou growest up in holiness and righteousness? whether thy light
shine before men, Mat. 5.16. 2 Cor. 7.1. whether thou cleanse thy self from
all filthiness of flesh and spirit, etc. See Doctor Tailor on Tempt. p. 93.

Quest. What Duties are we taught from the consideration of our Adoption?

Answ. 1. To walk worthy of our Calling; Be not vassals of Sin and Satan:

To come often into our Fathers Presence, doing all as in his sight: seeking
Mal. 1.6.

Strive to resemble Christ, our elder brother, in all virtues, and holy
conversation: John 3.2, 3.

Love Gods Word, that we may grow by it in grace and knowledge: Its the Pet.
2.2.

Expect afflictions and chastisements from our Father, Heb. 12.7, etc.

Quest. What are the means of our Adoption?

Answ. 1. Internal. 2. External.

Quest. What is the internal means?

Answ. Faith in Christ, which has three acts or effects.

1. To believe Christ to be a Savior. 2. To believe him to be my Savior. 3.
To put confidence of heart in him, John 20.29.
Quest. What is the external means of our Adoption?

Answ. Baptism; yet not this alone, but when its joined with faith, Gal. 3.26,
27. and thus it comprehends both outward and inward Baptism, Mat. 3.11. 1 Pet.
3.21.

Quest. What are the marks of the inward Baptism?

Answ. The new birth, whereby a man is washed and cleansed by the Spirit of
God: which has three marks.

1. The Spirit of Grace and Supplication, Zach. 12.10. 2. To hear, and obey the
voice of God in all things, John 8.47. and 10.27. 3. Not to live in the
practice of any sin, 1 John 3.9.
Mr. Perkins on Gal.

Quest. How may the mystery of our Adoption be conceived of?

Answ. A Christian by the Gospel is made a believer. Now faith, after an
unspeakable manner engrafts us into the body of Christ; then being engrafted
into Christ, who is Gods Son, we thereby come to be the Sons of God, and heirs
with Christ. Christ is Gods heir, so are all that are grafted upon him, John.
1.12.

Quest. How may the glory of our Adoption appear to be so great?

Answ. 1. If we consider by whom we are adopted, viz. by God: If it be such an
honor to be heir to a great Prince in the world, what a surpassing glory Romans
8.17. the rather if we respect the excellency of God, who is King of Kings: or
his eternity; he lives for ever, Hos. 1.10. Isa. 9.6. Other fathers that adopt,
may die before they pass the estate.

If we consider the great price that was laid down to make us capable of this
honor to be heirs, viz. the blood of Christ, Gal. 4.4, 5. Heb. 9.14, 15.

If we consider the great things we are heirs to, we shall inherit the earth,
Mat. 5.5. be heirs of the world, Romans 4.13. yea, we shall inherit eternal
life: yea, we are co-heires with Christ, Romans 8.17.



1. They have Christ's spirit in their hearts, called therefore the spirit of
Adoption, Romans 8.15, 16. Gal. 4.6. this drives away all legal terrors, and
testifies to them that they are the adopted sons of God, enables them to pray
with boldness, and to call God Father: leads them into all truth, etc. John
16.13. Isa. 30.21.

2. By the right of their Adoption in Christ, both their persons and works are
accepted with God: so that they are Gods Favorites, what entertainment soever
they have in the world, Ephesians. 1.6.

3. They have an honorable and everlasting name: so that no preferment is like
theirs, Isa. 56.4, 5.

4. They have Gods Angels to attend them, Heb. 1. ult.

5. They may ask whatsoever they will of God, and are sure to have it: yea, he
complains that they will not ask enough, and often enough, John 16.23.

6. When they fall into distress, they have such interest in Gods special
Providence, that an hair of their heads shall not fall to the ground without
it. Besides, God will make himself mavelous in their deliverance, when all
worldly means fail, Isa. 43.18, 19, 20, 21.



1. Hereby we have communion of nature with him by his Incarnation, whereby he
became our brother: yea, we have communion with him in his divine nature, 2
Pet. 1.4.

2. We have communion of state with him, which the Scripture calls a great
mystery: for so we are said to live with him, to die with him, to suffer with
him, to be buried with him: yea, to rise and ascend with him, and to sit with
him, Ephesians. 2.6. only preserving the difference between the head and the members
in all this.

3. We have communion of offices with him: For he has made us Kings, and
Priests with him, Rev. 1.5, 6. 1 Pet. 2.9.

4. We have communion in benefits with him: For God our Father has blessed us
in him with all spiritual blessings in heavenly things, Ephesians. 1.3. Communion we
have with him in grace in this life, and in glory in the life to come.



1. We have an Act for it in Gods eternal counsel, Ephesians. 1.5. we are
predestined to Adoption.

2. Yea, we have Gods oath for it, that by these two immutable things the
heirs of Promise might have abundant consolation, Heb. 6.17, 18.

3. God has put his Spirit into us as the seal and earnest of our inheritance,
Ephesians. 1.13, 14.

Quest. What kind of persons must we be to attain to this Adoption?

Answ. 1. We must have a true justifying faith, John 1.12. as we said before.

Romans 8.13. For none can inherit, but such as overcome their corruptions, Rev.
21.7.

Cor. 6.17, 18.

We must make conscience of sanctifying the Sabbath, and choosing the Isa.
56.4, 5, 6.

Quest. What are the marks whereby we may know our selves to be the adopted
children of God?

Answ. Such are made like unto God their father in holiness, in some Pet.
1.15. and this they show two ways.

1. By purifying themselves, and sound humiliation for their sins that defaced
Gods Image in them, 1 John 3.2, 3. 2. By employing themselves constantly in
doing righteousness. Hereby they are known from the children of the devil, 1
John 3.10.
Such love the brethren as their fellow-heires, 1 John 3.14.

Such have the spirit of prayer, Romans 8.15, 16.

Such serve God, not out of a slavish fear, but with a filial affection, Isa.

Such will love them that hate them, and bless them that curse them, Luke 6.35.
Mat. 5.44.

Quest. How must the adopted sons of God carry themselves in this life?

Answ. They must be Peacemakers, Mat. 5.9. their Father is the God

They must not revile such as revile them, but rather bless them, seeing they
Pet. 3.9.

They must live without carfulness, knowing that they have a heavenly Father
Mat. 6.32. and being heirs of a better, they must not set their hearts upon
this world, 1 John 2.15.

They must willingly submit to their Fathers corrections, Heb. 12.9.

Mr. Byfield on Peter.

Quest. What may we do that we may attain the spirit of Adoption, and keep the
lively sense and feeling of it in our souls?

Answ. We must diligently attend upon the Ministry of the Word, 2 Cor. Ministry
of the Spirit, because by it God offers and communicates his Spirit, Gal. 3.2.

We must beg this spirit of Adoption of God, Luke 11.13.

We must open the doors of our hearts that the Spirit may enter, Psalm. 24.7.
Rev. 3, 20. that is, we must call off our minds from earthly things, and we
must raise them up to attend to the motions of the Spirit.

Quest. What are the Signs that we have the Spirit of Adoption?

Answ. If we have the Spirit of Prayer, whereby we can call God, Father, Zach.
12.10. Romans 8.15, 26. Gal. 4.6.

If we have an high esteem of that dignity which is in Adoption, John 1.12.
John 3.1.

If we reverence and honor God as our Father, Mal. 1.6. 1 Pet. 1.17.

If we yield child-like obedience to him, 1 Pet. 1.14. Romans 8.14.

If we are made conformable to the Image of God our Father, and Christ our Mat.
5.48. Romans 8.29 1 John 3.9.

If we have a lively hope of our future inheritance, Romans 8.17.

Quest. How may we preserve the witness of the Spirit of Adoption in us?

Answ. If we do not extinguish it by contempt of the means of grace, These.
5.19, 20.

If we do not grieve the Spirit by the filthiness of sin, Ephesians. 4.30.

If we stir it up by our honest endeavors.

Ames. Cas. Consc.

CHAP. IV. Questions, and Cases about Adoration or Worship.
Quest. WHat is Adoration?

Answ. Its the part of Gods Worship, whereby a man, upon a vile and base esteem
of himself, as being but dust and ashes, submits, and subjects his soul to the
Majesty and Glory of God.

Quest. What are the principal Grounds in the heart?

Answ. Two. 1. Abnegation, or denial of our selves, when we esteem our

Exaltation, or advancement of Gods Majesty, above all things in the world.
Genesis 18.27. Isa. 6.2. Dan. 9.7. Man. 15.27.

Quest. How manifold is Adoration?

Answ. Twofold, Religious, or Civil.

Quest. What is religious Adoration?

Answ. Its the Worship of God, in which Religion and Godliness is exercised,
expressed, and signified.

Quest. What is to be considered herein?

Answ. The inward intention of the mind, wherein God is conceived

The outward prostrating of the body, as bowing the knee, lifting up the hands,
etc. to testify our subjection unto God as our absolute Lord.

Quest. What is Civil Adoration?

Answ. It belongs to the Second Table, and is termed Sociall, because its the
Adoration, or Worship that fellow creatures give one to another.

Quest. What is to be considered herein?

Answ. The inward intention of the mind, which must be this: that the creature
worshipped is endued with excellent gifts by God, or that he has Power

The Action, or outward gesture of the body, in token that the creature
worshipped is endued with excellent gifts, and graced with authority over us.
So

Quest. To what things is Adoration due, and in what manner?

Answ. The things are of three sorts, 1. God the Creator. 2. The creatures. 3.
The works of the creatures.

Quest. What Adoration is due to God?

Answ. It must not be Sociall, (for we are not Gods companions,) but Religious,
which is due to him, and to him alone, Mat. 4.10.

Quest. What Caveats are to be remembered herein?

Answ. If Adoration be given to god with a false and erroneous intention, it
makes him an Idol. As if our bodies be bowed to worship God out of the Trinity,
as the Turks do: or if he be worshipped out of the Son, as the Jews do, we
worship not the true God, but an Idol. For God must be so conceived of us, as
he has manifested himself in his Word, and not otherwise.



Quest. Why so?

Answ. Because he that so worships him, binds his presence, operation and grace
to those places, to which God never bound himself, nor his Presence, etc.



God expressly forbids the Worship of his Majesty, in, at, or before any
creature Deuteronomy. 4.16, 17, 18, 19.

Obj^ct. But I intend not to worship the Image, but God in the Image?

Answ. It matters not what thy meaning is, seeing God detests that manner of
Worship; the Israelites worshipped not the Calfe, but God in the Calfe, Exodus
32.8. yet they are said to worship an Idol.

Obj. God was worshipped before the Ark, and there he promised to hear the
prayers of his people?

Answ. They had an express Command from God to worship before the Ark, and a
Promise that they should be accepted and heard, which the Idolater has not.

Obj. Subjects kneel before the Chair of State, though the King be absent, in
token of their subjection due to him, therefore much more may we to the Images
of God, and the Saints in Heaven?

Answ. Kneeling before the Chair of State is a mere Civil Worship, only to
show our subjection to our lawful Sovereign, and so is commanded by God: but we
have no such warrant to bow to Images: neither is it Gods Will, that they
should be Tokens of his Presence.

Quest. What Virtues are required in religious Adoration?

Answ. Fear, which is a great part of Gods Worship, Isa. 29.13. with Mat.
15.8, 9. where fear and worship a^e taken for one and the same.

Inward obedience of the hidden man of the heart: which is preferred before
sacrifice, 1 Samuel 15.22. and this stands in two things.

1. In yielding subjection of the Conscience to the Commands, Threats, and
Promises of God, so that we are willing to be bound by them. 2. When the rest
of the powers of the soul, in their place and time, perform obedience to God, 2
Cor. 10.5.
Psalm. 37.7. and 39.9. 2 Samuel 15.26.



1. In acknowledging that our selves and whatsoever we have is Gods, and
proceeds from his blessing alone. 2. In consecrating our bodies, souls,
callings, labors, and our lives to the honor and service of God*
Quest. What Adoration is due to the creatures?

Answ. The creatures are either, 1. Evil spirits. 2. Good Angels. 3. Living
men. 4. Saints departed.

Quest. Is any Adoration due to the evil spirits?

Answ. No: for they are Gods enemies, and accursed of him, therefore no honor
is due to them: neither are we to have any dealing with them at all, but
utterlie to renounce whatsoever comes from them, or their instruments, as
Spells Charms, Enchantments, etc. which serve to work wonders, but have no
such virtue from God, either by Creation, Nature, Word, or Institution.

Quest. What Adoration is due to the good Angels?

Answ. If they did appear to us, and we certainly knew them, we might adore
them, but only with a civil and sociall worship. So Genesis 19.1. they refuse
Religious worship, Rev. 19.10.

Quest. What Adoration is due to men?

Answ. That which is merely civil, and that in respect of the gifts of God that
we see in them, as also of the authority, and place they have amongst us.
Enjoined in the fifth Commandment. So we see in Abraham, G^n. 23.7. which
Adoration must be according to the laudable custom of the Country where we
live.

Quest. May not religious, or mixed Adoration be given to them?

Answ. By no means. Peter blamed Cornelius for it, Acts 10.25, 26. Mordecai
refused to give it to Haman, Esther 3.2. Kissing the Popes toe is therefore
unlawful, because its a Civil worship, mixed with Religious; tendered to him as
to Christ's Vicar, and is not done to any Potentate on the earth.

Quest. What Adoration is due to the Saints departed?

Answ. All the worship that we owe them, is no more but a reverend esteem of
their persons, and imitation of their virtues: No religious worship is due to
them, they having nothing to do with us, nor we with them.

Quest. Does any Adoration belong to the unreasonable creatures?

Answ. No, there belongs nothing to them, but a reverend and holy use of them.
For Adoration is a sign of subjection in the Inferior to the Superior: but
Man is their Superior, and therefore is not to worship them: therefore not the
relics of Saints, or the Bread and Wine in the Sacrament.

Quest. Is any Adoration due to the works of the Creatures, viz. Images?

Answ. None at all: For

1. Its expressly forbidden in the Second Commandment.

2. The Superior must perform no Adoration to the Inferior: Now man is a more
excellent Image of God then any other Image, and therefore better then it: yea,
the meanest worm which is Gods Workmanship, is better then any Image made by
man: therefore we may better worship a worm, then an Image.

Mr. Perkins, Vol. 2. p. 84, etc.

CHAP. V. Questions, and Cases of Conscience about Adultery.
Quest. WHat is Adultery?

Answ. It is uncleanness about the Act of generation between a man and a
woman, whereof one at the least is married, or betrothed to another.

Quest. Whether, when the husband or wife commits Adultery, the bond of
Marriage is thereby dissolved?

Answ. No: neither may the nocent, nor innocent party put the other away, but
still they remain man and wife, till the cause be fairly heard by a lawful
Magistrate, and by him judged and determined, which is proved.

1. Because the Scripture still calls them man and wife: Abraham was still
Sarahs husband after he had committed Adultery by lying with Hagar. So of
David, etc.

2. Though Christ has allowed it to the innocent party, that he or she may
commence that action, and being judged, put the other away: yet no where has
he commanded it, that before judgment, he should put her away, which, if she
had ceased to be his wife, he would have done, Matthew. 19.9.

3. Only he that joined them can separate them, and make them not man and wife,
which is God only. Indeed, Jerome reports of Fabiola, that without the judgment
of the Church, or Magistrate, she put away her husband, who was a very vicious,
and an adulterous man: But though he write not the rest, yet others say, that
she was made to do public penance: not that she made a divorce, but because
she did it of her self without the judgment of the Church.

4. As private and clandestine marriages are not allowed by reason of manifold
inconveniences; So privy and secret divorces are not allowable, because it
would prove prejudicial to the good of many.

5. They are man and wife, till a just cause be justly known to the contrary,
but that cannot be in private, but before a competent Judge: God allowing none
to be accounted Adulterers, but such as are lawfully convicted of it before a
lawful Magistrate; for by no right can a man be both Party and Judge.

6. If Adultery be not known to the innocent, then they are still man and wife,
though there be great presumption of it: why not then if known? Knowledge, or
not knowledge breaks the bond never the more, unless it be proved, judged and
determined.

7. Divorce is a punishment for a fault committed; now none may punish it but a
lawful Judge. See Stock on Mal. c. 2. p. 118.

Quest. How may married persons prevent, and withstand temptations to Adultery?

Answ. Consider that the Adulterer makes himself the member of an harlot, which
will lie heavy upon the conscience when time serves, that in sinning this sin,
the body is thus made the member of a Strumpet.

Solomon the wise to run into idolatry against common sense: and Sampson the
strong, though he knew the harlot would betray him, could not forbear.

It will damn men in hell except they repent, 1 Cor. 6.9, 10. No Adulterer
shall enter into the Kingdom of God. So 2 Pet. 2.9, 10.

Original lust unto it, and Satan is more eager to draw us to it.

Prove. 5.19, 20.

Prove. 22.14. Eccl. 7.26.

Cor. 7.5. There must be quenching, not provoking of lust: Raging lust is a
great enemy to love, and will not be content with one. Married persons must
avoid also,

1. Words, and talk full of obscenity* they must not by words corrupt one
another chastity, which is worse then corrupting the chastity of a stranger.

What if no body be by, yet God is by.

2. Their eyes must be pure and chaste, else it will follow, that their eyes
will be full of Adultery, 2 Pet. 2.14. Adam and Eve made coverings to hide
their nakedness each from other. Modesty is the best Preserver of Nuptial
chastity Love does no unsightly or unseemly thing.

3. The bed must be sanctified and kept undefiled by the Word and Prayer: The
Word is a mighty healer of corruptions, to which we must join Prayer, or else
we rely too much on the Physic. Prayer will keep us that we shall not surfeit,
and so come to a loathing: Nor fall into a defect: There must be a satisfying
and drinking away of our thirst at our own Cisterne, Prove. 5.19. least we
hanker after a strange fountain. Prayer will keep us from base and abusive
dalliances. It will keep the bed undefiled, and increase love, and mutual
affection. See Capell on Temptations p. 386.

These. 4.3. This is the Will of God, that ye should abstain from fornication,
and every one possess his vessel in holiness, etc.

Remember how the Lord interposeth, and challenges the Covenant between
forsakes the guide of her youth, forgets the Covenant of her God, Prove.
2.17. yea, he professes that he narrowly watches, and clearly sees when this
Covenant is broken. For Prove. 5.15, 17, 20, 21. this is made the reason of the
Precept: The ways of men are before the eyes of the Lord, though no other eye
sees it.

Remember, the Lord watches sinners of this kind to destroy both their souls
Pro. 5.22. He destroys his own soul: He shall be shut out of the heavenly
Jerusalem, Rev. 22.15. and by Gods Law the Adulterer and Adulteress should
die, because he would not have the land defiled: nor the guilty person live to
be an eyesore to the innocent. Its worse then theft, Prove. 6.30.31.

Consider further the odiousness of this sin.

1. It directly corrupts the fountain of honest, civil, and godly life, which
is the inviolable preservation of Gods Ordinance of Marriage.

2. Its infamous for the Church to be accounted an Assembly of harlots,

3. It brings confusion in the Commonwealth to have a bastardly brood
inheriting.

4. Its an injury to families to bring in unlawful and usurping heirs.

5. All other sins are without the body: this is against the body, 1 Corinthians.
6.18.

6. Whereas all other sins may be committed by one party, this winds in two
into the sin: So that if one party repent, the other may not, which will be a
great burden to the Penitent whilst he lives.

7. Its an high sin against the price of Christ's blood, wherewith their bodies
were bought to be members of Christ, that by this sin are made members of an
harlot.

8. The curse of God follows this sin: 1. In the soul of the sinner, Hebr.
13.4. Whoremongers and Adulterers God will judge. 2. In his body, Prove. 5.11.
He shall mourn, having consumed his flesh and his body. 3. In his Name Prove.
5.9. which precious thing is irrecoverably lost. 4. In his estate, It brings
him to a morsel of bread. Pro. 6.26. Its a fire that consumes all his
substance, Job 31.12. As we see in the Prodigal. 5. In his bastard-brood: we
never read of any that came to good besides Jephthah.

Quest. By what means may we preserve our chastity?

Answ. Get a pure heart, because out of it issue Adulteries, Mat. 15.19. Let
thy soul become a pure Spouse of Christ, love him, and cleave to him, this

Preserve in thy soul the fear of God, Eccl. 7.26. He that is good before God
shall be preserved, Prove. 2.10, 16. Consider Gods Presence, who sees thee.

Get an hearty love to thy wife, Prove. 5.19, 20.

Avoid occasions of wantonness; As 1. Idleness: one of Sodoms sins: standing
they are mockers. Avoid intemperance in sleep and apparel: Let thy diet be
sober, and sleep moderate. 3. Avoid the company and sight of persons, that may
become snares: as Joseph avoided his Mystresses presence: Death often enters by
the windows of the eyes: Beware of amarous books, pictures, speeches, etc. 5.
Use all good means appointed by God for this purpose; As first, resist lustful
thoughts at first, and exercise thy mind in holy thoughts. Secondly, consider
thy calling of a Christian, and remember that thereby thou art called to
holiness. 3. That the pleasure of sin is short, but the gnawing of a guilty
conscience durable. 4. Apply the sword of the Spirit, the Word of God against
it, which is a sharp two-edged sword, etc. 5. Fly to God by prayer; make thy
case known to him, and crave his assistance. See Dr. Tailor on Titus p. 386.

CHAP. VI. Questions, and Cases of Conscience about Affections, or Passions.
Quest. HOw many sorts or kinds of Affections be there?

Answ. Two. 1. Sensual. 2. Intellectual, or Rational.

Quest. What are sensual Affections?

Answ. They are such as belong to the sensual appetite: are sented in the body
for the instruments of them; and are suited to the body for the objects and
ends of them, and are guided by the phancie, and are common with us to beasts:
The objects of them are sensible things, as meats, drinks, marriage,
recreations, etc. A natural or bodily good to be obtained, or evil to be
avoided.

Quest. How may it appear that these sensitive Affections are not to be
abandoned, but only moderated according to the Rules of Reason and Faith?

Answ. 1. Because virtue never ruins that which is wholly conformable to
Reason: As its Reasonable to see a man moved with pity and compassion toward

To apprehend evil, to fear punishments, to attend recompenses with Joy, to
long after Promises, are they not encouragements to Piety, Temperance,

The Passions of our souls are the objects of many excellent virtues, which do
moderate them, and reduce them to Reason when they seek to fly out: As

4. The sensitive appetite is a gift freely bestowed upon us by God, but virtue
never destroys nature* but adds to it the perfections which it wants. It must



Quest. What are the Rational Affections?

Answ. They are such as appertain to the Will, of which they are immediate
acts, directed by the Understanding.

Quest. How may it be proved that there are Affections in the highest and
chiefest part of the soul?

Answ. 1. Because the Scriptures ascribe to God love, hatred, anger, zeal, etc.
who cannot be subject to any sensitive aberrations, and therefore as in him
they are perfections, we are commanded to imitate him in them: so there is no
reason why they should be denied to us in such sort as they be perfect, and
that is principally in the Intellectual power of the soul.





Quest. How may it be proved that these Rational Affections are motions of the
Will?

Answ. Because they are conversant about spiritual, celestial, yea, eternal
objects: as of God, Christ, Heaven, etc. Col. 3.2. of which the sensitive
appetite is incapable.

They remain in the soul when its separated from the body: the Saints carry

Luke 15.10. and desire to look into Gospel-mysteries, 1 Pet. 1.12. and the
devils fear and tremble, Jam. 2.19.

Paul makes the Will the seat of the Affections, and joins them together, 1
These. 2.8. being affectionately desirous of you, we were willing to have
imparted to you, not the Gospel only, but our own soul.

Quest. Are these rational Affections so elevated above the body, as that they
have nothing to do with it? no, not whilst the soul is in the body?

Answ. Yea, though they are originally and radically in the Will, yet the Will
stirs up the sensual Affections, and they stir the humors and patts of the
body, especially the spirits and the blood, and so make the whole man to
suffer, both body and soul. Hence they are called Passions: As Fear chills the
blood: Anger boiles it; Grief contracts and closes up the Heart: Joy dilates
it, etc.

Quest. Why must our Affections be carefully looked to, and ordered by Gods
Word?

Answ. The first sort of reasons may be taken from the effects of disordered
passions: As,

1. Because Passions when unruly, blind Judgment and Reason: Passions are

Passions seduce the Will: because the Understanding being the eye and director

Passions mightily change the quiet temper, and disposition of the mind:

1. Passions rebel against Reason, and undermine the Understandings of men to
their great molestation: For no sooner does the Mind ascend Heavenward by
Meditation, but inordinate Passions hale it back, and draw it down to the earth.

2. One passion fights with another, as fear opposes Anger, Covetousness,
Prodigality, and on a sudden men fall from one extreme to another, as from
great ^oy to great grief.

3. Passion is unsatiable, Covetousness increases as riches increase.

4. Inordinate Passions either prevent Reason, or are stirred up by a corrupt
judgment, and therefore neither observe time nor place; but upon every
occasion would be leaping into action, importuning execution: yea, sometimes
many greedy passions crowd in altogether, every one being more earnest then
other to be satisfied: so that to content them all, is impossible; to content
none is intolerable: to prosecute one, and abandon the rest, is to carry so
many hungry vipers continually gnawing upon our souls.

5. There are none that follow the streams of their Passions, but expect and
believe at last to get full rest and content to their appetites, which yet in
the event is altogether impossible: for they keep neither sense, order, nor
measure.

6. Inordinate passion it self is an extreme tortute and vexation; God having
so ordained that they which will give way to them, should feel the burden of
them: Thus anger, envy, pride, etc. more disquiet them that entertain them,
then they can hurt any other man.

Rashness, Inconstancy, Craftiness, are the companions of inordinate
Passions.

Inordinate passions are hurtful to the body, impair health, breed humors,

Secondly, the second sort of Reasons, to show that Affections should be
rightly ordered are taken from the consideration of the profit, and benefit of
well-guided affections. For, 1. They rather serve as instruments of virtue,
then foment vice: and as an occasion of victory, then a cause of foil. Christ,
in whom were no inordinate affections, had his soul heavy even unto death, Mat.
26.38.

2. The Scriptures exhort us to love, fear, joy, etc. therefore it were
blasphemous to say that these Passions are absolutely evil.

3. If the motions of our Wills be virtuous, being guided by Gods Word and
Prudence, if then the Passions concur with the Will, virtuous actions are
performed with much more ease and delight.

Quest. How may we know to what Passions our souls are most inclined?

Answ. By our company that we most delight in: Like affects like; meetings
and manners for the most part sympathize together.









Quest. By what degrees are the affections wrought on?

Answ. By nine degrees: In the five first, a carnal man may have his affections
wrought on, and in the last four of them he cannot. As,

Corinth wrought on the Affections of the Hearers that they flockt after them.
Paul durst not so preach, 1 Cor. 2.4.

When the Affections are so wrought on, that the heart is somewhat touched
Israelites to Saul, 1 Samuel 10.26. As a Needle touched with a Loadstone, turns
it self to the North: So a wicked man's Affections may be touched by the Word.

When Affections are so wrought on, that the heart is somewhat bowed thereby:
David bowed the hearts of the men of Judah, as of one man, 2 Samuel 19.14.

Absalom stole away the hearts of all Israel, 2 Samuel 15.6.

i. e. whilst he was in a Passion, Deuteronomy. 19.6. So Saul had a great zeal to
Gods Church, 2 Samuel 21.2. Jehu was zealous for God, 2 Kings 10.16.

Lam. 1.20. Behold, (Oh Lord) for I am in distress, my bowels are troubled, my
heart is turned within me, etc. viz. with grief for their sins.

Jer. 30.21. Who is he that engages his heart to approach unto me?

David's, Psalm 119.31. I have stuck unto thy Testimonies.

that it affects. Thus Solomon gave his heart to seek wisdom, Eccl. 1.13. No
wicked man can have his affections thus wrought on, yet his affections may be
raised a good way toward Christ. For,

1. By the sparks of right Reason, naturally implanted by God in the heart, he
may so regulate his affections that he may be chaste, sober, kind, liberal,
just, patient, etc. and to observe the things contained in the Law.

2. Their knowledge by the Word may raise up their affections exceedingly:
Knowledge may awe the heart with fear that it go not against its own
knowledge: Herod feared, Mark 6.20. and did many things.

3. God may quicken their knowledge and conscience, and tell them the horror
of their sins, which may raise up their affections many steps higher, to mourn
and be sorry for their sins: As in Ahab, 1 Kings 21.27. He rent his clothes,
fasted, and went softly.

4. They may have a deep sense and horror for their estate: they may be afraid
to be damned, and of Gods judgments, which may make them weep, and sigh, and
groan. So Mal. 2.13. They covered the Altar of God with tears, with weeping,
and crying out; and yet were hypocrites.

5. Self-love may wind up their affections yet higher: For when a man knows
that he cannot be saved unless he does thus and thus; Oh how affectionate may
he be to do it that he may be saved. For, 1. He may be loath to commit sin: He
may wish affectionately to leave it. He may use some means to leave it. As
Darius did to have deliveted Daniel from the Lions Den, Dan. 6.14. and Pilate
to deliver Christ. 2. He may vomit up his dear sins, and be sorry that other
men should commit them. So Micha confessed the silver that he had stolen, and
proffered to make restitution, and was troubled when he heard his Mother curse
and swear, Judge. 17.2. Joab was vexed when David would number the people, 1 Chronicles. 21.3. 3. He may be so set against sin, that money, favor, honors, etc.
may not prevail with him to commit it, as in Balaam, Numb. 24.13. 4. He may be
forward in Religion, and so strict in his ways, that he may be persecuted for
the truth-sake, and for Christ's sake, and may endure persecution a good while.
5. He may be ravished and enamoured with the joys of the Spirit. He may be in
some ecstasies of spiritual joy, Heb. 6.5. He may taste the good Word of God,
and Powers of the world to come.


Quest. Why may wicked men's Affections be so far wrought on, and yet come
short?

Answ. Because they are not kindly wrought on: the Galatians affections were
Paul, but they were not kindly wrought on. Its only the love of God shed abroad
in the heart that kindly affects us.

They are not judiciously wrought on: they are wrought on in a fit, but not

They are not wrought on regularly: He is affected with fear; but its with
Hos. 3.5. the true Israel of God are there said to fear the Lord and his
goodness.

They are not wrought on universally: Some affections are wrought on, but

Quest. How then shall we know whether we are rightly affected toward Chrict
or no?

Answ. He that is truly affected with Christ, grace, etc. affects nothing so

Psalm. 39.3.

Came. 5.8. Tell him I am sick of love.

Psalm. 33.1. as in the Fountain of all grace.

Quest. But why should we be so careful to have our Affections set right?

Answ. Hereby only we are in a capacity of being married to Christ, who will
have our Affections before he will marry us. When a man goes a wooing for a
wife, his care is to get her Affections. He will never marry her, if he be
wise, except he may have her affections. So if our affections be to the world,
or the Strumpet-like things of the world, Christ cannot abide us: Know ye not
that the love of the world is enmity with God, James 4.4. Therefore the Apostle
commands us to mortify inordinate Affections, Col. 3.5.

Hadad was in favor with Pharaoh, he married his wives Sister to him, 1 Kings
11.19. So if thou favourest the things of the world, thou weddest thy soul to
them; and what an infinite indignity is this to Christ, when such base and
sordid things should have those affections which belong to him?

without natural affections, implacable, Romans 1.31. what a care then should we
have of our affections, because thereby we are reconcilable to God?

Psalm. 24.4. He that has clean hands, and a pure heart: i. e. He whose
affections a^e clean, and heart pure: Psalm. 26.6. I will wash my hands in
innocence, etc. i. e. I will purge mine affections, and so pray, 1 Timothy 2.8.
Lifting up pure hands, i. e. holy affections without wrath, etc. Now what a sad
thing is it that these hands should be put out of joint? As long as our
affections are out of order, and set upon things below, we can never take hold
of grace, or Christ. When the devil takes a man Prisoner, he binds him hand
and foot: He binds up his heart and affections that he cannot weep, nor repent
of his sins: He cannot rejoice in grace nor goodness: He cannot delight in the
Word, etc. Above all things therefore be sure that thy hands be loose, and
thine affections at liberty to be set on heaven.

They are also the handles of the soul: As we can take hold of nothing that is

Affections are the souls stomach: that which the soul affects, it fills and
Pet. 2.2. Let us therefore ^et our affections upon the things which are above,
which is the wholesome food of the soul.

Affections are the materials of grace: the main work of grace is the ruling of
Gratia non tollit sed attollit naturam: It takes not away nature, but lifts it
up. Therefore Saint Paul calls our affections members, Romans 6.19. Because by
them grace works.

Affections are arguments what we are: As our affections are, so are our
souls. The goodness or vainness of our affections show that we are godly,
Affectus virum indicat. Our affections, show what we are.

Quest. How may it be proved that affections in themselves are not sinful?

Answ. Because Adam and Eve had affections in innocence, who were created
without sin.

Christ took our affections upon him, which if they were sinful he could not
have done. He rejoiced, Luke 10.21. He sorrowed, Mat. 26.38. He Mar. 3.5. He
desired, Luke 22.15.

God commands us to be angry, Ephesians. 4.26. and to mourn, Joel 2.12. to fear,
Luke 12.5. to be ashamed, Jer. 3.3. which if they were sinful in

1. Had we no affections, we should be like stocks and senseless stones; as is
implied, Lam. 1.12. q. d. Are you such blocks that ye are not at all affected
with my sorrows, therefore its reckoned as a symptom of a desperately
hardened heart, not to be affected with any thing.

2. Were it not for affections nature would be idle and lazy: For they are as
wind to the sails of a ship, as wheels to a Chariot: Hence Psalm. 119.32. I
will run the way of thy Commandments, when thou shall enlarge my heart, i. e.
my affections. Though a man's reason tells him, that he is bound to repent, to
be godly, to obey, etc. yet if he has no affections thereto, he cannot move
toward them. Hence Cant. 1.4. Draw me, viz. by the affections of love, and I
will run after thee. Affections are whetstones to good. Have thou love? Its a
whetstone to obedience. Have thou grief? Its a whetstone to repentance. Have
thou anger? Its a whetstone to zeal, etc.

3. Affections are good channels for grace to run in. Art thou covetous and
full of desires? Its easier for thee to covet the better things. Art thou
choleric? Its a fit channel for thy zeal for Gods glory to run in. Art thou
melancholy? Its a fit channel for repentance to run in. Art thou fearful? Its a
fit channel for the fear of God and his judgments to run in, etc. Jeremy was
of a sad constitution, and see what advantage he made of it. Jer. 9.1. Oh that
my head were waters, etc.

Quest. How are unmortified Passions to be subdued?

Answ. To bridle unlawful pleasures its good to accustom our selves to abstain
from lawful: He shall not fall in things unlawful, that warily restrains
himself sometimes in things lawful. As if a man be given to drunkenness, he
shall the easilier overcome it, if he abstain from strong drink when he might
use it. If a man be prone to pride, its best for him not to go so fine as he
might do. He that takes his liberty in all things that are lawful, will quickly
be a slave to his lusts. Hence 1 Cor. 6.12. All things are lawful, but all
things ^re not expedient, etc.

Nazarite: to prevent drunkenness must drink no Wine, nor eat Grapes or
Raisins, lest thereby they should be tempted to drink Wine, Numb. 6.1. etc.

Joseph's chastity: Jobs patience: Abraham's faith, etc.

Principiis obsta, etc. Cure the wound whilst its green: Take Physic before
the disease be rooted. As he that will be rid of an ill guest, the worser that
he entertaines him, the sooner he will be gone.

Cor. 9.27. I keep under my body, and bring it into subjection, etc. He that
would quell his passions whilst he pampers his body, is like him who would
quench a fire by adding more fuel to it.







Quest. How may affections be divided?

Answ. Into two kinds. First, some embrace their Object, as Love, Joy,

Secondly, others shun and decline them, as Hatred, Fear, etc.

Wherein consists the sanctified exercise of those affections that embrace, or
prosecute their Object.

Answ. In this, that they move to all good soundly, orderly, in fit season,

Quest. Is it not mercenary to yield obedience to God upon hope of reward?

Answ. No: for if the Lord use such means and motives to quicken us in Heavens
way, its not mercenary but lawful to make use of them for that end, So John
3.16, 18. Romans 2.7. Heb. 11.26.

Quest. Wherein stands the sanctified exercise of those affections that fly
from their object?

Answ. In that they shun all evil soundly, orderly, and constantly, according
to the direction of Gods Word.

Quest. What Reasons may induce us to shun that which is evil?

Answ. The remorse and pangs of conscience in the very act of sinning, may

The infamy and disgrace which attends wickedness: For no man can truly
