Quest. But is it not servile to foregoe sin for fear of punishment?

Answ. The Scripture commands the godly to fear him that is able to cast both
soul and body into hell, Mat. 10.^8. Heb. 4.1. and 2.3. and 10.26. Fear of
eternal wrath, as it makes men avoid sin, may well stand with confident
assurance of eternal happiness, and final perseverance.

Quest. May the state of our soul be discerned by our affections?

Answ. Yea: we may know our estate to be good, by our embracing of good things,
by our joy and delight in them, and by our wonderment at them: As, Oh, how I
love thy Law! Psalm. 119.97. One day in thy Courts, is better th^n a thousand
elsewher^, Psalm. 84.10. Oh the depth of his Mercy, Romans 11.33. One thing have I
desired of the Lord, and I will desire it, etc. Psalm. 27.4. when the soul
stands in admiration of God and good things; ready to welcome Christ and
heavenly things, and in comparison thereof to count all but dung, etc. A man is
then in a good estate, when hearing of the excellency of heavenly things, he is
exceedingly affected therewith, and gives them a room in his heart.



Quest* How happens it then, that Gods children sometimes, even when their
judgments are convinced, yet find their affections so flat, crying out: Alas!
that I should believe such happiness as heaven, such glory, and yet should
have my affections no more stirred in me? Can I be a child of God?

Answ. Sometimes the Judgment may be convinced, and yet the affections

1. Because there may be some division at the same time, as some present
cross, or some present thing lawfully loved that may take up our affections at
that time.

Gods children are sometimes deceived in judging of their affections, but when
opposition comes, then they are discovered: As for want of stirring up the
grace

This is a certain rule, that a man's affections are as his persuasion is, and
his perwasions as his ^ight is. As he has a heavenly light, discovering
heavenly things, so is his persuasion of a better state then the world can
yield: and answerable to his persuasion so is his soul raised up to delight in
the best things.

Quest. What rules are to be observed for the better government of our
affections.

Answ. They must be guided by the word of God: If they have not this rule to
guide them, they will wander out of the right way: These are good Servants but
bad Masters. They must not run till Reason bid them go. They are the feet of
the soul, now the eye must guide the foot or else it will go it knows not
whither. Hereby affections are directed to right Objects, to love what should
be loved, and to hate what should be hated: as Christ directs. Luke 12.3, 4, 5.
and so Col. 3.2. 1. Pet. 2.2. 1. John. 2.15. Affections misplaced are like
members out of joint which will one day cause pain.

Moderate affections, and keep them with in due bounds. Proportion them to
their objects in measure more or less according to the kind and degree of
good, or evil wherein they are to be ruled by judgment. Grieve for the
greatest evils most wherein God is dishonored, grieve for afflictions less
which are less-evills. So for joy; Luk 10.20. Psa. 41. and 16.3.

Quest. Why should the affections be thus kept within their bounds.

Answ. Because whilst affections are kept within bounds, they are kept in
order, every affection keeps his place, like soldiers in their ranks: but when
they break their bounds, they break their bancks like a swelling water.

Whilst they are kept within bounds they are kept in use, ate helpful one to
another, and obedient to reason, otherwise they hurt and devour one another;
as excessive grief devoures joy. etc when they exceed they make themselves
unuseful, and the man in whom they are, unfit either for the service of God, or
man. yea they captivate reason, and draw us to do things both contrary to
judgment and conscience.

Whilst they are kept within bounds they are kept in credit and esteem: but
Cant. 5.8.2. Cor. 5.13.14 Exodus, 32.19.

Quest. How may these immoderate affections be prevented? or cured?

Answ. Forsee by prudence such things before they come which may prove great
Provocations to our selves of joy, Grief, Anger, Fear, etc. and set bounds to
them in our resolutions before hand how much we will be affected with them when
they com to pass, and noe more.

Set up a Master affection in your hearts to rule all the rest, and keep them
in awe, in order, and in measure, and let that be the holy fear of God* that
your hearts may not dare to love any Creature overmuch, nor to grieve for any
worldly loss too much. etc. and that because you fear God, who will reward and
punish your affections as well as actions.

Phisicians open a vein to divert the course of blood! As when you are angry
overmuch at persons, or things, turn it against sin etc.



3. Rule.
Command affections so as to have them at your beck to make them come and go
when you bid them. For Prove 16.32. He is better than he that takes a City.
Contrarily Pro. 25.18. Hence 1 Cor* 7, 30.31. Psa. 131.2.

To this end pray to God for stren^th: For to command our affections requires
power as well as Skill. Ephesians. 3.10. Psa: 38.2. The weaker the person is in his
understanding and parts, the stronger are his passions: and as Persons grow
weak, their passions grow strong: the mind may out-reason affections, but
strength must over-master them.



1 From mixtures of the flesh: as of spiritual, and carnal together: Hence, 1
Pet. 1.22. see that ye love one another with a pure heart etc.

2 Purge them from mixtures of self, as the people followed Christ, not for
himself but for the loaves.

3 From mixtures of deceit: as of abundance of show of affections, when there
is little reality: as those hearers: Ezekiel. 33.31. Hence: Romans 12.9. Let love be
without ^ssimulation.

4 From all mixtures of corruption: As your zeal from passions, and
bitterness; your anger from revenge: your joys from levity etc.

4 Suit your affections to Gods Ordinances, and Providence: to Gods words, and
Luke 7.32. etc.

The administrations of Gods providence call for suitable affections: as Jsa.
22.12. In that day did the Lord God call to mourning: etc. yea we should suit
our affections to the conditions of others Romans 12.15. To weep with them that
weep etc. So Psa, 17.1.6. Neh. 1.4. Psa. 119* 136. we should mourn for the
sins of the times Ezekiel. 94. Jsa. 57.1.

Yea they should be suitable in degree: Great sins, or calamities call for
great sorrow: great salvations for great joy etc. For which end.

1 We must sanctify God in our hearts, and make him our fear, joy, hope etc.

2 To be affected contrary to our condition, or Gods dispensations makes a
discord in Gods ears, and pulls down judgment. Isa. 22.12.13.14. Amos 6.4.
etc.

3. To be affected with things as God would have us, is a means to make that
good use of them God intends us by them.

Mingle affections, not only to allay, and moderate them, but to corroborate

1 Because, this will keep the heart whole, and entire, and prevent heart
divisions, when the affections go hand in hand, and flow together in one
channel.

2. It will the better unite their forces, and make them more strong: what is
spoken of persons, is true of affections: Eccles. 4.9. etc. Two are better then
one, etc.

Seventhly, Spiritualize affections* as 1. Sorrow for affliction into sorrow
for sin; VII. Rule.
turn worldly sorrow into godly sorrow. So your delight in the creatures to
promote your joy in the Lord, and in communion with Christ, and in holy duties:
your hopes of favors from men to raise expectation of spiritual blessing from
God: your fear of man into an awful dread of God, Isa. 51.12.

Eighthly, Root and increase good affections in you, as Ephesians. 3.17. and that

1. Because, when they are rooted in the heart they will be durable, and mould
us into their likeness: else they will be but flashes, and bear no fruit, as
R^v. 2.4. Gal. 4.15. John 5.35.

2. Cherish holy affections, and blow them up from a smoke to a flame, by the
bellows of prayer, and fuel of the Word, 1 These. 4.9, 10.

Ninthly, Distinguish affections, and act them.

1. Distinguish them by the Objects about which they converse, and by the Roots
from whence they grow, and by the heads to which they rise.

1. The Objects about which affections are conversant, are either good or evil,
as apprehended so by the understanding: As when the understanding apprehends a
thing to be good, the affections embrace it with love, Cant. 5.2, 5, 6. and
this good is either present, and then we rejoice in it: or absent, and then we
desire it; If it be improbable to be attained, then we fear; If impossible,
then we despair: If obstructed, it stirs up anger.

If the evil be future, we fear it, etc.

2. The Roots from whence the affections grow, are love or hatred. All the
affections which arise from the apprehension of good grow from love: As desire
is love in motion: the continual sallies of love: Delight is love acquiescing
in the possession of it; Fear is love in awe of the beloved: Hope is love in
expectation: Zeal is love in a flame.

All the affections which arise from the apprehension of evil, grow from hatred.

3. The heads to which they arise, and are referred: Thus all the affections
which are conversant about good, have some delight in them, as Love, Desire,
Hope. All that are conversant about evil have some grief mingled with them: as
Hatred, Fear, Repentance, Anger.

2. Act them according to the nature of them. For,

Affections are the first principles, or movers of actions, and action is the
end or proper work of affections.

To act affections consider why God has placed them in the soul, and act them
accordingly: Concerning which see each particular affection under their proper
heads.

Tenthly, try affections whether they be true or false, real or counterfeit; X.
Rule.
and that

1. By their properties. 1. Are they set upon right objects? as to love,
desire, delight in, and hope for God and good only. To hate, fear, fly, and
mourn for, and be angry with that which is evil.

1. Are they sincere for their acts and ends? Are their acts real or feigned?
as Mar. 12.30. 1 John 3.18. Do you hate and mourn for sin really? Do ye prefer
God and his glory before self? Do ye prefer public good before private?

2. Are they sincere for their ends? Do we affect goodness for goodnesse-sake?
and God, his Word, Servants, etc. for the goodness that is in them? Do we hate
evil for evils sake? Do we affect spiritual things for spiritual ends? Do we
desire gifts and graces to glorify God, subdue corruptions, etc?

3. Are they moderate? Do you keep them within bounds? Are you fearful of
exceeding in them?

4. Are they seasonable for time and occasion? then they are good fruit, Psalm.
1.3. unseasonable affections are like Snow in Summer, or Rain in Harvest.

5. Are they constant in their course? not sudden flashes, or fleeting motions,
stirred up by fits, or upon extraordinary occasions, but the constant pulls of
our soul.

6. Are they unchangeable and invincible in their bent? Can nothing take of our
affections for God and goodness? our hatred and mourning for sin? our delight
in Gods Ordinances, and Duties? etc. Unchangeable love is true love: Such is
Gods to us: and invincible hatred against sin is right hatred, John 13.1. Jer.
31.3.

2. Try them by their effects?

First, do they draw us nearer to God, Christ, Heaven, to walk with him, and
wait on him for grace and strength? Do they further our Communion with God, and
conformity to him.

Secondly, do your affections prepare you to holy duties, put you forward to
them, in them, and further your obedience as the wheels and sails of your
soul?

Thirdly, do they help you in eschewing and overcoming evil, as well as in the
obtaining good? Do they turn you from, and set you against evil, so that you
dare not sin, because you hate it, and fear God?

But on the contrary, if your affections,

1. Disturb Reason and hinder it, or cause you to call good evil, or evil good,
or to stand in defense of evil, as Jonah did of his passion, Jonah 4.9. I do
well to be angry, etc.

2. Draw you away from God to go a whoring after vanity.

3. If they indispose you to duties, take off your edge to them, or put you out
of frame for them, as Exodus 6.9. 1 Pet. 3.7.

4. If they disquiet your souls, trouble and unsettle them, and cause a tempest
in them, as grief did in David, Psalm. 42.11. So Act. 16.27. Genesis 30.1.

5. If they put the body into a languishing condition, as Amons love, or lust
rather did him, 2 Samuel 13.4.

6. If your affections misguide tongue, or hand, as passion did Moses tongue,
Psalm. 106.33. Jeroboams hand, 1 Kings 13.4. they are not right.

Quest. Why should we try our affections?

Answ. First, Because they are the pulse of the soul, and by the temper of them

Secondly, Because there is much deceit in them: For a great part of the hearts

Quest. Why should we so diligently govern our affections?

Answ. First, Because such as the affections are, such is the man: Good
affections Job, chapter 1.1. And so Ps. 112.1. Deuteronomy. 5.29.

Secondly, God accepts our persons and services according to our affections: As
Abraham's willingness to sacrifice Isaac, Genesis 22.16, 17. and David's to build
him an house, 1 King. 8.18. 2 Samuel 7.11. For 2 Cor. 8.12. It is accepted if
there be a willing mind, etc. 2 Cor. 9.7. So Ephesians. 6.7, 8. Col. 3.2^, 24. Yea,
God is much taken with his peoples affections, 1 Cor. 8.3. Cant. 4.9.

Thirdly, Affections are the root of spiritual Worship in us, and of our
Communion Luke 8.15. Mal. 2.2. Deuteronomy. 6.6. Act. 2.41. Isa. 66.2. Jam. 5.16. Ephesians.
5.19. Mal. 3.16.

and solace of life lies in love, joy, desire, hope, etc. and how much
discomfort in fear, grief, anger, hatred, envy, etc? The greatest troubles
that ever befell many, were procured by their own disordered passions. So 1 Timothy
6.9, 10. 2 Timothy 3.1. to 5. John 12.43.

The best men are subject to discover humane infirmities in their affections,
as Moses, Psalm. 106.33. Job, chapter 40.5. David, 2 Samuel 1^.33. Abraham, Genesis
12.18, 19. Peter, Mat. 14.30, 31. Paul and Barnabas, Act. 14.15. Elias, 1 Kings
19.4.

Affections make us convertible to God, marriageable to Christ, pliable to

1. Convertible to God: for in the Conversion of sinners he works upon their
affections, to draw and gain them to himself, as Acts 2.27. and 16.29, 30.

2. Marriageable to Christ: for Christ wooes our affections, when he would
marry us to himself, by heart-charming compellations and arguments, Cant. 5.2.

3. Pliable to relations: for relations are founded in affections: as love is
the glue that makes man and wife cleave each to other, Ephesians. 5.31. so of Parents
and children, Masters and servants. So of friends, 1 Samuel 18.1.

4. Tractable, either to good or evil, to truth or error. Hence 1. Satan to
draw men from the Truth and Ordinances, labors to bring them into distaste of
their Ministers. 2. To draw them into error, he labors to bring the broachers
and teachers of errors into favor with their hearers, Ephesians. 4.14. 3. To draw
men to sin he bewitches their affections, and by them blindes and corrupts
their judgment, as he did Eves, Genesis 3.6, 12.


See Mr. Fenner. Ball. R^yner.
of the Government of Affections.

Quest. Whether may the strength of Grace consist with the want of those strong
affections, which Christians have found in their first Conversion?

Answ. For answer hereunto these three things are to be considered.

First, When a man may be said to lose his first affections?

Secondly, in what cases a strong Christian may be said to want strong
affections?

Thirdly, whence it is that they which have strong grace may yet want such

For the first, Affections are fitly compared to the pulses of the soul, by
which judgment may be given of the state and temper of the soul; and that we
may know when our affections beat low and are decayed, we may judge thereof by
these signs.

1. When we have not such quick desires after duties. Mostly a Christian at his
first Conversion, is so earnest and eager after holy duties, that he will
scarce allow himself time for the duties of his particular calling. Yea, many
times they tire themselves in hearing, reading, meditation, etc. But afterward
this heat abates, and they pray less, hear seldomer, etc. which usually
proceeds from their multitude of worldly occasions.

2. Affections may be judged to be decayed, when men want those soul-ravishing
joys which formerly they have had: which being abated, their affections also
are abated.

3. Affections are decayed, when sensible profiting by Ordinances is abated,
Indeed, a man may profit by Ordinances, and yet not be sensible of his
profiting. He may grow at the Root in solidity of Grace, though it may not
shoot up so much in blossom of affections.

Quest. For the second, In what cases may strong Christians want strong
affections?

Answ. First, If they have less sin in duties, though they have less
affections: Young Converts have oft-times much affections in holy duties, but
withal much corruption: they are subject to rashness, and precipitancie in
their prayers, to be proud of their graces, and to be too apt to have ca^nal
dependence upon their duties; but old experienced Christians, as they have often
less affection, so they have less sin in holy duties, and exercise more grace
in them. So after duties, a weak Christian is apt to indulge his corruptions,
thinking that he has made a compensation for his sins by his duties; but an
experienced grown Christian, though he be not so affectionate in duty, yet he
is careful afterward not to spoil all by sin.

Paul prays for the Philippians, not only that their love might abound, but
that their judgment might abound also, Phil. 1.9. Though old experienced
Christians have not so much affection; yet they have more solidity and
clearness of judgment, more experimental knowledge in the profound mysteries
of the Gospel, and more distinct apprehension of the deep things of Christ;
whereas affection without knowledge will be but rashness, yet such have a
Promise made unto them, Isa. 32.4. The heart of the rash shall understand
knowledge, etc.

Luke 23.27. Some men's temper is like ice that easily thawes; others are like
iron, and it must be a hot fire that will melt them down; But the less
affectionate, are the more judicious.



Quest. Whence is it that they that have strength of Grace, may yet want those
strong affections which they had at their first Conversion.

Answ. First, Because at first Conversion, grace was but particularly employed,
which afterward is more diffused, and generaly employed. When much water runs
in one channel, it makes the stream to run the stronger: but when there are
many rivulets cut out, though there be as much or more water, yet there is not
the same strength of the stream; So it is at our first Conversion, then all our
affections made up but one stream, and therefore seemed the stronger. A new
Convert has not so many duties to perform as a grown Christian, because he
does not know so many. It may be at first, all his affections run out to pray,
to hear, to read, and whilst all the affections run in this one channel,
they seem to be very strong: whereas a grown Christian has, besides these,
many particular duties of his calling, and relations to follow, and therefore
its no marvel though his affections seem weaker.

Secondly, This is from the newness of the condition. Naturally we are much
affected from darkness to light, and from the power of Satan unto God. 1 Pet.
2.9. By the Grace of Conversion, God brings us out of darkness into his
mavelous light: and because its so mavelous, therefore it does so much
affect. Our change at Conversion is very great: we become new men, and we are
so affected therewith, that we are (as it were) astonished therewith. Yet in
this case we must distinguish between solid affections, and transient passions,
which wear off presently, and vanish suddenly. The affections of some
Christians, especially of young ones, are like colors which are not in grain,
they will soon fade. It is with a new Convert, as with a man going to
execution; whilst he is upon the Ladder a Pardon is unexpectedly brought, how
will he be transported with joy? He will even leap for joy, yet afterward this
torrent of his joy may he abated, though his life be as dear to him as ever. So
when a soul has been brought by the Law to a sight of its lost condition, when
the Gospel proclaims a Pardon, and the Spirit of God has set on the comfort
of that Pardon upon the heart, Oh what ravishments has that soul fot the
present! which perhaps he shall not long retain: the violence of his joy is
abated, but the solidity of it remains.

A third Reason may be taken from Gods indulgence to young Converts, who
Shoes, but a Ring; not only clothes, but the best Robe: not only bread, but
the fatted Calfe, and Music at this Feast, and all this was for his newly
converted and repenting Son: he did not entertain him so every day after. At
our first Conversion God expresses much bounty and indulgence to us, and
afterward, though we have the same love from God, and the same love to God,
yet the expressions may not be the same now, as formerly they were.

Quest. What must we do when we find that we have lost our first affections?

Answ. First, Labor to be sensible of, and humbled for those decays. A decayed
condition is an uncomfortable condition: Though thy grace may carry thee to
Heaven; yet by thy decays, thou will live uncomfortably on earth.

Secondly, Labor to get those decays repaired. If thou have lost thy first
love, repent and do thy first works, Rev. 2.4, 5.

Thirdly, Make up the want of former affections in solidity of knowledge and
judgment: and if the candle give not so great a blaze, let it give a more clear
and

Fourthly, Labor to keep up the first vigor of your affections. For,

1. Remember that you may lose that in a short time, which you may be long

2. Labor to keep up your holy affections; For the truth of grace is more
discerned by our affections, then by our actions. Its easier to dissemble acts
of grace, then gracious affections. A Painter may paint the color, but not the
heat of the fire.

3. Its very hard to retain the first vigor of our affections, therefore we
should take the more pains about it. Flushing of spiritual joy is like the
sea, wherein the tide does not flow so high, but the ebb falls as low: Bernard
speaking of them, says, Rara bona, brevis mora, they come seldom, and stay but
a short time: As the Fall follows the Spring: and one day is clear, and another
cloudy; so it is with the best Christian, his affections are not always at the
same pitch: yet it should be our endeavor to maintain in our souls our first
vigorous affections in, and toward the ways of God.

Mr. Love of Grace.

CHAP. VII. Questions, and Cases of Conscience about Afflictions
Quest. WHat is Affliction?

Answ. Any trouble, grief, or evil whatsoever, that happens either to soul or
body, name, goods, or estate, for correction of sin, or for trial, as it does
to the godly: or for punishment and vengeance, as it does to the wicked, Romans
2.8.

Quest. Why does God suffer his children to be distressed and afflicted?

Answ. He respects himself therein: For

First, God gains glory many ways by it; As first his power is seen in their
Job, Mine eyes have seen thee, Job 42.5.

Secondly, not only present power and mercy is then seen, but former: we see
what power was used in preventing misery, what mercy in giving comfort.

Thirdly, Then God shall have their custom and company. Children that care not
for their Parents in prosperity, will fly to them in adversity.

He aims at his peoples good therein: For

1. Whilst they are Spectators, they lay about them in getting and exercising
of grace. Others deep sorrows make us see how needful it is to get much faith,
patience, Scriptures, etc. in readiness.

2. They stir up to prayers, mercies, etc. as when Peter was in prison, they
thought it high time to pray, Acts 12.5.

3. When themselves be afflicted, they help themselves by the afflictions of
others; Such suffered this affliction, and God loves them, why not me also?
Such cried, and sped well, why may not I? Psalm. 32.5, 6.

God aims at the Parties good in great distresses: Hereby they are tried,
humbled,

2. Hereby they are brought to receive often sentence of misery, Death, Hell in
themselves; and its good to taste these things before we feel any of them: It
will empty a man of himself, and make him trust in the living God. It will
learn him those three lessons of Christianity, mentioned by Paul, Phil. 3.3. To
worship God spiritually, to make Christ his joy, and to lay down all confidence
in the flesh.

3. Hereby they are made helpful to all, For 1. We cannot pity others till
experience has taught us. 2. We will not be serviceable till affliction has
humbled and broken us. 3. We know not how to comfort others till our selves
have been wounded and healed: But when we have learned by experience, we can
make our plaster serve another man, and comfort him in the same affliction
with the same consolation, 2 Cor. 1.4.

See Dr. Harris's David's comfort, p. 56.

Quest. Why does God suffer holy men to be afflicted?

Answ. Saint Chrysostom has set down eight Reasons, to which more may be
added.







Job.

Romans 8.17.

Sixthly, For the consolation of others, when they see that all things fall
alike





David.





Hosea 2.6.



See Stock on Mal. chapter 3. p. 236.

Quest. But what shall we say to extraordinary afflictions?

Answ. They are no good proofs of a bad person or condition, as in Job, etc.

Obj. But would God so afflict me if I were his child?

Answ. So? How so?

Obj. I am crossed in a child as never man was: so ungrateful: so unnatural?

Answ. Yea, except David: Eli* and yet they were beloved.

Obj. Oh, but I have such a beast to my husband as never woman had?

Answ. Yea, Abigail.

Obj. Oh, but my estate is so broken, that I am worth nothing?

Answ. So was David's at Ziklag: So Naomies, and yet beloved.

Obj. Oh, but I have sold all, and now want bread?

Answ. So did the widow of Sarepta, 2 Kings 4.1. So Neh. 5.2. etc. and Lam.
5.6, 10.

Obj. Oh, but my body is smitten too?

Answ. So was David's: Psalm. 32.3. and Jobs: and yet beloved.

Ob. But I am disabled from all service: I can neither pray, nor read, nor
hear, nor live, nor die.

Answ. So the Saints, Ps. 102.3. etc. the Church in Isay, and yet beloved.

Ob. Oh, but my spirit is wounded. I am scorched with hell-flames in my
conscience.

Answ. So Job, and David, and yet beloved.

Ob. Oh, but I am torn in pieces with hellish blasphemous tentations?

Answ. Christ had such offered from Satan, and yet beloved.

Ob. Oh, but I am haunted with lusts: now impure lusts: then covetous,
revengful lusts, etc.

Answ. So was Paul, Romans 7.14. etc. Gal: 5.17. yet beloved. Resolve therefore
that neither things present, nor things to come, shall be able to separate us
from the love of God, in Christ. For no affliction forfeits our title.

Ob. Oh, but mine be sins, passions, tentations?

Answ. Let them be what they will. If they be afflictions to us: If they tire,
wound; and make us cry to God, as Jehosaphat did, when they pursue us, they
weaken not our title.

Ob. Oh, but the smart of them may cause that without the hatred of sin! they
may make us weary because painful not sinful!

Answ. 1. They may: but these two are not well opposed: painfulness comes after

Secondly, If opposed; know the pains in hippocrites only follows sin
committed, Paul, Rom: 7:24. Who shall deliver me from this body of death.

Thirdly, Only great sins are painful, if nothing but pain be heeded, whereas

Fourthly, Sin is only painful to the unsanctified, whereas thou art as much

Fifthly, Pain makes an hyppocrite houle, but not to God, at least in the
First Davia, First to God, then to men: It ends in prayer, not in fretting,
despair etc. And is it thus with thee? Either thou must condemn David, or
confess that a man may be crossed in wife, child, house, goods, friends,
Kinsmen, all at once: Nay, hazarded in his life, tempted in his soul, troubled
in his conscience, yea plunged into a Sea of miseries, and yet be dear to, and
beloved of God. Dr. Harris.

Quest. What other reasons may be rendered why Gods Children are exercised with
grievous crosses?

Answ. Because they are so beset with corruption, and therefore must be purged.
For

First, Gods children will sometimes venture on noisome meats, and hurtful
David will lie, and commit adultery, and murder the innocent, what can God do
less (Unless he would have him spoiled) then scourge him thoroughly, when he
will be walking so near Hells-mouth, then take him by the heels, and make him
believe that he will throw him in. Its bettet he should lose his sin them God
his child.

Secondly, If they fall not to deadly poison, yet will they surfeit of lawful
meats; and pleasures unlawfully: So childish we are that we cannot be turned
lose to delights, and keep a mean: we cannot have prosperity but we abuse it,
swell, brag, snuff, look over our brethren, and forget our selves; It was so
with David, Psa. 30.6.7. Hezekiah, Jsa. 39.2.

Fifteenthly, by afflictions we are made conformable to our Head Christ.

Quest. What design has God in afflicting his children?

Answ. To teach them to know him and to trust in him, and to know themselves:
Luther, Schola crucis est Schola lucis, the House of Correction, is the School
of Instruction. (...) are (...). His rods when sanctified are powerful Sermons
to teach us.

1. To know God: and this is life eternal to know him, John 17.3. Its said of
Manasseh, 2 Chronicles. 33.13. Then he knew that the Lord was God: Affliction
teaches us not only to know God in his power, anger, hatred of sin, but also
in his goodness and mercy. For God does so sweeten the bitter Cup of
affliction, that a child of God does often taste more of Gods love in one
months affliction, then in many years of prosperity, 2 Cor. 1.4, 5. and 7.4.
Affliction also teaches us to know God experimentally, and affectionatively: so
to know him, as to love and fear him, and to fly to him as to our Rock and
hiding place in the day of distress, Cant. 3.1, 2, 3, 4. By night, i. e. in
the time of divine desertion, etc.

2. Not only to know God, but to trust in him also, 2 Cor. 1.9.

3. To know our selves also: when the Prodigal was in adversity he came to
himself, Luke 15.17. they teach us to know that we are but men, Psalm. 9.2. yea,
but frail men, Ezekiel. 21.17. and that God can crush us as easily as we do moths:
which will make us to stand in awe of God, and to study to serve and please him.

Secondly, Gods aim in affliction is to keep us from sin. So 2 Cor. 12.7. or

1. They open the eyes to see sin, as Genesis 42.21. Oculos quos culpa claudit,
poena aperit.

2. They open the ears to discipline, as Deuteronomy. 5.27. For Jer. 2.24.

3. They open the mouth to confess sin, Judge. 10.15.

4. They command us to depart from iniquity, Job 36.8, 9, 10. They are Gods
Furnaces to purge our dross: Gods Files to pare off our spiritual rust: Gods
Fanns to winnow out our chafe, Dan, 11.35. and 12.10.

Thirdly, Gods end is also to make us holy and righteous, Isa. 26.9. Hebr.

Fourthly, to make the world bitter to them, and Christ sweet. For Prove.

Fifthly, to prove their graces, Rev. 2.10. Deuteronomy. 8.2. 1. The truth and
sincerity Job with afflictions: and the strength of our graces; for it requires
a strong faith to endure great afflictions.

2. To improve our graces: For as the Palm Tree, the more its pressed, the hi^
her it grows, so do the graces of Gods people.

Sixthly, it is to put an edge upon their prayers, and all their other holy
services.

1. Upon Prayer: what a fervent prayer did Manasses make when he was in fetters
in the dungeon, 2 Chronicles. 33.13, 18, 19. When Saint Paul was struck off his
horse* and smitten with blindness, then he prayed to the purpose, Acts 9.11.
So Isa. 26.16.

2. Upon Preaching. Prosperity glutteth the spiritual appetite, Adversity whets
it.

3. Upon the Sacrament. How sweet is the Sacrament to a true Saint, after a
long and great sickness.

4. It makes God and his Word precious. If God set our corne-fields on fire, as
Absalom did Ioabs, then we come running to him: and how sweet is a
Scripture-Promise to a child of God in his distress, Hos. 5. ult.

Quest. What considerations may cheer up our hearts in the time of affliction?

Answ. First, that God never afflicts his people, but out of pure necessity, 1
Pet. Lam. 3.33. Isa. 27.9. Its sin that puts thunderbolts into Gods hand. God
never scourges us, but it is with a whip made of our own sins, Prove. 5.22.
Romans 2.5. Hence Isa. 28.21. Its his strange work.

Secondly, he does it out of his true and real love, Heb. 12.6, 7, 8.

Obj. Do not divine afflictions proceed from anger? was not God angry with
Moses for speaking unadvisedly, Psalm. 106.33. and with David for Adultery?

Answ. This anger was a fatherly anger rooted in love. It was not Ira quae
reprobat, but Ira quae purgat: It was not Ira hostilis, and exterminativa, but
Ira As its sometimes a great punishment for God not to punish, Isa. 1.5. Hosea
4.14. So its a great mercy sometimes for God to withdraw his mercy.

Thirdly, afflictions are a part of divine Predestination: that God that has
elected us to salvation, has also elected us to afflictions, 1 These. 1.3, 4,
6. Romans

Fourthly, they are part of that gracious Covenant which God has made with his
people, Psalm. 89.31. etc. In which Text three things are observable.

1. A supposition of sin? If his children forsake my Law, etc. For it is
always the cause sine qua non, the cause without which God would never
chastise us, and mostlie its the cause for which he chastises.

2. A gracious Promise, Then will I visit their transgressions with the Rod,
and their iniquiry with stripes.

3. A merciful qualification, Nevertheless, my loving kindness will I not take
from him, nor suffer my faithfulness to fail, etc. So Psalm. 119.75.

Fifthly, Consider that afflictions are part of the Saints blessedness, Job
5.17. Behold, happy is the man whom God corrects, etc. Afflictions when
sanctified are instructions, and so are evidences that we are in a blessed
condition, Psalm. 94.12. Job, when upon the dunghill, wonders why God should so
set his heart upon him, as to visit him every morning, and try him every
moment, Job 7.17, 18. Lazarus full of sores, and in his rags, was happier then
Dives in his robes: P^ilpot in his Colehouse, then Bonner in his Palace.





^i^^hly that all afflictions shall at last work for their good, Romans 8.28. God
D^u. ^.25. God will either deliver them out of afflictions, or send them to
heaven by them.

Quest. What must we do to prepare for ^fflictions?

Ans^. First, get a stock of graces: For sickness is a time of spending, not

Now the Graces to be stirred up beforehand are*

afflictions: when the win^e blew fiercely* Peter's little faith ^ailed, Mat.
14.30.

2. A great measure of patience to enable us to wait quietly and contentedly,
till God comes in with help, who many times deferres till the fourth watch of
the ni^ht, as Mat. 14.25.

3. A great stock of self-denial, humility, contempt of the world, heavenly
mindedness: Such will be as safe as No^^ in the A^k: and as those which had
