Fifthly, a stock of Scripture-Promises which will be as so many reviving
cordials, D^vid, Psalm. 119.92. I had perished in mine affliction, unless thy
Law had been my delight.

Quest. But what may we do to know the meaning and voice of Gods Ro^?

Answ. Gods Rod ordinarily speaks three Languages. 1. It corrects for sin. 2.
It tries and exercises grace. 3. It instructs in holiness: sometime its for
the two latter, and not for the former: as in Jobs, and the blind man's case.
But usually its for all three, Lam. 3.39. Isa. 42.24. Luke 1.20. 1 Cor. 11.30.

Quest. How shall we know whether our afflictions are only for trial and
instruction, and not for sin?

Answ. Its safest to believe that they are for sin also, when upon our selves,
though out of charity we judge them not so to others, Romans 5.12. For though all
afflictions are not sent directly and specially for sin, yet sin is the
original of all afflictions.

Quest. What course must we take to find out that particular sin for which God
corrects us?

Answ. First, Sometimes we may read our sin in our punishment. As in
Adonibezek, 1.7.

Secondly, consider, what that sin is, for which thy conscience most accuses

Thirdly, what is the sin of thy constitution: what is thy dilectum delictum,
thy peccatum in delitiis, thy beloved and bosome-sin, of which David speaks,
Psalm. 18.23. I have kept my self from mine iniquity.

Fourthly, when sick and near death, consider what sin does most trouble and

Fifthly, What those sins are, for which thy godly Minister, under whose charge

See Mr. Calamie's Godly man's Ark.

Quest. What means may we use to quiet our hearts in afflictions?

Answ. First, Remember that they are inflicted by the Decree of Heaven, and Job
5.6. So Jer. 51.53, 55. Psalm. 39.9. etc.

Secondly, that they are sent to try thy patience: to show how well thou

Thirdly, its the common state of all mankind: we are all borne to sorrow, Job
5.7. As a man we must bear what is common to man, and as a sinful man we bring
troubles on our selves, and therefore should say with the Church, Mich. 7.9. I
will bear the indignation of the Lord, because I have sinned against him.

Fourthly, that God takes care for his children, and then especially when they
Psalm. 40.17. I am poor and needy, yet the Lord thinks of me. So Jer. 29.11.
Isa. 49.13.14, 15.

Fifthly, that God intends us no evil but good thereby, Jer. 24.5. For Romans

Sixthly, when in affliction, be assured that it shall be better with thee then
now, James 5.6. the darkest night shall have a fair morning; The Rod of the
wicked shall not always rest, etc. So Isa. 54.11. and 62.3.

Seventhly, what we lose by afflictions are such things as may be spared, and
Zach. 10.8. 2 Cor. 4.8, 9. Zeph. 3.19.

Eighthly, no affliction shall be too much, or too long, for that only is too

1. That exceeds our desert. Whereas Ezra 9.13. Thou have punished us less
then our iniquities deserve.

2. Nor too much in regard of our strength, for God proportions his burdens to
our backs, and his strokes to our strength, Isa. 27.7.

Obj. But Paul says, 2 Cor. 1.8. that he was pressed out of measure?

Answ. First, Indeed he met with unreasonable men who knew no measure, and his
afflictions were above his strength as a man; but he was able to do, and to
suffer all things, through Christ strengthening him, Phil. 4.13. At such times
God increases their power, Isa. 40.29, etc.

How long? and a little time seems long; But God who intends our good, must
take a time answerable to his own intentions; when the sore is cured, the
plaster will fall off; If we be not in the fault, usually thy time is short: A
day: the evil day, Ephesians. 6.13. A night, Psalm. 30.5. A piece of a night, Isa,
17.14. A moment, Isa. 54.8. A small moment, ver. 7.

Quest. How can this be when afflictions are often much longer?

Answ. First, in the times of affliction there are many lucida intervalla,
intermissions,





See Mr. Valentines Parl. Sermon.

Quest. What are the benefits of receiving our afflictions as from God?

Answ. First, it will put us upon serious humiliation for our sins, whereby we
have provoked him against us, the rather because no hand can heal us, but the
same that has wounded us, Hosea 6.1. 2 Chro. 7.14.

Psalm. 76.10.



Quest. What is especially to be feared when afflictions are heavy, and long
upon us.

Answ. First, then especially fear, and look to the seeds of rage and madness
which are in thy heart. Never more need to look to the banks, then when a
tempest is upon the sea. Have you seen a beast break his teeth upon the chain
that ties him? or a dog pour forth his revenge upon the stone that hurt him,
then have you seen some dark shadows of that fierceness and fury that is apt
to rise out of our hearts, when Gods hand lies close upon us. When thou hear
of the strange impatience of Jonah, at the beating of the Sun upon his head,
unto whom yet it was a wonder that he did now see the Sun: when thou hear of
those deep expostulations of David with God, Psalm. 77.9, 10. Has he forgotten
to be gracious? forgotten his Promises? forgorten his Truth? forgotten his
Power and Mercy? and shut up all his kindness in displeasure? when thou
hear the impatiencies of Job, yet a man renowned for his patience, Jam.
5.11. expostulating and charging God, Is it good for (...) that thou should
oppress? Job 10.3. when thou hear of those deep curses of Jeremy against
the day of his birth, Ier. 20.14, 18. of those froward expostulations and
debates of the people of Israel with Moses, and of Moses with God, Why have
thou evil entreated this people? why have thou sent me? Exodus 5.28.22. Oh then
reflect upon thy self, and be afraid of thine own evil heart, which is far
more likely to break out against God, then any of those were; and for
prevention hereof keep in thy sight the history of thy sins, make them as
heinous to thy own view as they are in their own nature. The way not to rage
against afflictions is to know our selves aright; that will make us to confess
as Ezra, That the Lord has punished us less then our iniquities have deserved.
Ezr. 9.13. The way to bear the hand of God with patience is to confess our
sins, and to be humbled for them. Levit. 26.40, 41. Wherein is showed that the
sight of our sin and humiliation for it, is the way to make us accept of the
chastisements of God: so Lament. 3.39. Wherefore does the living man complain?
a man for the punishment (...) his sins. Where are three strong reasons why we
should not murmr in our affliction. First, We are men, and what an impudency
is it for the clay to swell against the Potter that formed it, and complain
why have thou made me thus? Secondly, We are sinners all the punishments we
suffer are the wages of our own iniquities, an^ what a madness is it to
complain against the justice of our Judge? Thirdly, We are living men, and
therefore God has punished us less then our sins deserve: for the wages of sin
is death: Romans 6.23. and what ingratitude is it to repine against merciful,
and moderate punishments? and yet we are prone hereunto; But it is the cure;
See v. 40. Let us search, and try our ways, and turn again unto the Lord our
God, the more that we grow acquainted with our sinful estates, and mavelous
provocations, with the patience, and promises of God, the more we shall
justify God, and wait upon him; the more we shall judge our selves less then
the least of Gods mercies, forbearances; as Mich. 7.9. q. d. I have pressed,
and vexed, and wearied him with my sins without any care of his glory, but he
has visited me in jugdment not in fury: In wrath he has remember mercy, and
not consumed me as he might have done, he has not rewarded me according to my
sins, etc. but has spared me as a son, when I dealt with him as a Traitor. See
Dr. Raynolds sinfulness of sin, p. 175.

Quest. How shall we bear afflictions rightly?

Asw. First, If we count it no strange thing to lie under it, 1 Pet. 4.12. but
rather that it is that whereunto we are ordained of old, to be conformed to
Christ in Romans 8.29. Yea, if we esteem them as the beaten path, by which God
will have all his Children to enter into heaven. Acts 14.22. 2 Timothy 3.12.

2ly, If we observe the example of all, or the most excellent of Gods servants,
and especially of his only Son, from the beginning of the world to this day,
Heb. 12.1.2

Thirdly, If we inure and accustom ourselves: to bear the yoke from our
youth, it will tame our proud and rebellious hearts, and frame us to bear
afflictions Lam. 3.27.

Fourthly, If we consider that Satan every day invents new mischief against us,
Job. 1.6. etc.

Fifthly, if we remember that it is a sign of Gods love, Heb. 12.7. Rev. 3.19.
and Psalm. 37.5. Esth. 4.16.

Sixthly, If we remember the many good uses of afflictions. For hereby Gods
power appears in our weakness: and we have the better proof of his grace
dwelling Cor. 12.9. as Faith, Hope, Love, humbleness of mind, patience, etc.
that these light, and momentany afflictions work an exceeding, and eternal
weight of glory. 2 Cor. 4.17.

Quest. How shall we be sure to profit by afflictions?

Answ. First by the confessions of the Saints, who have experimented it: as
David, Psalm. 119.67, 71. Manasseh. 2 Chronicles. 33.13.

Qu. How come we by wisdom not only patiently to bear, but to profit by
afflictions?

Answ. First, it is obtained of God by prayer, Jam. 1.5, 6, 17.

Secondly, by a due consideration of the end, fruit, and uses of afflictions.

Quest. What are the ends of afflictions?

Ans. First, To keep us from wandering, or to bring us back when we have erred,
and to make us tractable scholars in the school of Christ. Ps. 119.67.71. 2
Cor. 1.10.

Manasseh: 2 Chronicles. 3 and 13.

Psa. 34.17, 19.

Romans 5.4.5. Jam. 1.3.

Cor. 11.31, 32.

Dan. 12.10. and as mustard laid upon the breast, to weane us from the world.
Psalm. 131.2.

Heb. 12.6, 8.

Heb. 12.8, 9. See practice of Christianity.

Quest. Are not all afflictions evil in their own nature?

Answ. Yes, and so the Lord stills them, Isa. 45.7. Amos. 3.9.

Henc^, Prove. 15.15. All the days of the afflicted are evil* and Genesis 47.9.
Few and evil are the days of my Pilgrimage, etc.



Lam. 3.19.



Quest. Are afflictions then simply, and absolutely evil?

Answ. No, for thus sin is only evil, but they are of an indifferent nature.

Quest. How then come they to be good.

Answ. First, In respect of the chief efficient, or author whence they come,
they are good, either as they are punishments inflicted by a righteous Judge,
or chastisements coming from the hand of a merciful Father.



Thirdly, As they help us to come to the chief goodness: For God has ordained
Romans 8.29. 1 These. 3.3.

Fourthly, As they are means to draw us nearer to God by true repentance, and
Mat. 7.14. Act. 14.22.

Quest. What rules are we to observe in preparing our selves unto the conflict
with afflictions

Answ. First, We must hear, read, and study the word of God: For

Ps. 119.92.

Psalm. 119.25, 50. Its our joy in all our sorrows, v. 143. and its our chief
comforter in all our miseries.

2. We must be frequent, and fervent in Prayer, acknowledging our sins, that
all Prove. 28.13. 1 John 1.9.

Thirdly, In our prosperity we must labor diligently in the moderating, and

Fourthly, we must not fain unto our selves afflictions in our conceit, and
imagination,

Fifthly, We must not by fear anticipate afflictions, making our selves
miserable

Sixthly, With wise, and Christian providence we must forsee crosses, and in
Luke. 14.28.31. Mat. 16.14.

Seventhly, We must not fix our hearts upon any thing in the world, but use
these outward blessings as though we used them not, and enjoy them as those
lose with immoderate grief: and if we look upon these things as perpetuities,
we shall be subject to much sorrow and find small patience when they prove
movables. So we should look upon Honor, riches, relations, health, etc.



Heb. 12:6: Psla. 119.120. and indeed we have small cause to contemn
afflictions if we consider our own weakness and want of patience etc. The
latter of these evils is to be avoided; because we should be courageous in the
power of Gods might, and not faint. Heb. 12.6. we should resolve with Job:
Though thou kill me, yet will I trust in thee, Job. 13.15. such resolution was
in the three Children, Dan. 3.18. In Peter, and John, Act. 5.29, and In Paul,
Act. 21.13. Hence Romans 8.35.38. Remember his promise. 1 Cor. 10.13.

John 18.11.

Mat. 4.7. Jacob used all good means to escape his brothers fury, Genesis 32.11,
13. Moses fled from Pharaoh, Exodus 2.15. David from Saul and Absalom, 1 Samuel
19.12. 2 Samuel 15.16. -- Joseph and Mary from Herod, Mat. 2.14. Paul from the
Jews, Acts 9.25. and 22.21. and 23.

Quest. What considerations may move us, patiently and quietly to bear those
afflictions which God lays upon us?

Answ. First, that afflictions are not laid upon us by God as punishments to
satisfy his justice: For,

1. Christ bore all our sins in his body upon the Cross, 1 Pet. 2.24. Isa.
53.5, 6, and had not Christ done this, he had not been a perfect Savior, nor
had offered to his Father a full and all-sufficient price for our Redemption.
But he was a perfect Savior, Luke 1.74. Heb. 7.25. and 9.12, 26. Mat. 20.28.
John 1.29. 1 John 1.7.

2. Christ taking upon him our debt, by being our Surety, he has discharged it
to the uttermost farthing. Yea, he has also cancelled the handwriting of
Ordinances, and the obligation of the Law by nailing them to his Cross, Col.
2.14. Gal. 3.13. and therefore God cannot require a new satisfaction by our
sufferings, etc. Yea, God is so far off from punishing, where his Justice being
satisfied, wills him to spare, that when he corrects his people, its called
his strange work, Isa. 28.21. and he is grieved for it, Judge. 10.16.

3. Where there is no sin, there is no place for punishment: but in the
faithful there is no sin, because it is not imputed to them: their sins are
washed away by the blood of Christ, and being justified for his righteousness
and obedience, they are accepted as righteous in Gods sight, Col. 1.14. and
2.13. Rev. 1.5. 1 John 1.7. John 3.29. Jer. 31.34. Isa. 1.18. Jer. 50.18. Mich.
7.19. Psalm. 31.1, 2.

4. Afflictions tend to our good, to the mortifying of our sins, and to the
multiplying and increasing Gods graces in us, and furthering our everlasting
happiness, Romans 8.18, 28. 1 Cor. 11.32. Heb. 12.10, 11. 2 Cor. 4.17. Lam.
3.27. therefore they are not punishments for sin, not being inflicted for our
hurt, but for our good.

5. That which is either a cause, or means of eternal blessedness, cannot be
a punishment for sin: but so are afflictions to the godly, Psalm. 94.12, 13. and
23.4. and 16.11. and 119.67.

Secondly, that afflictions are to the godly the chastisements of a gracious
Father,

Because we have testimonies and examples in Scripture to make this out, Ier.
25.29. 1 Pet. 4.17. Amos 3.2. Prove. 3.11, 12. Heb. 12.5, 6. Rev. 3.19. 1 Cor.
11.32. So we see in the examples of Job, David, 2 Samuel 12.25. 2 Samuel 7.14. of
the Church, Psalm. 89.31, 32, 33. Ps. 99.8. Romans 8.35, 38.

Quest. How is this love of God manifested unto them in their afflictions?

Answ. First, by the measure of afflictions, and that

1. In general, in that he corrects us in measure, when our sins have been out
Isa. 64.9, 12. Jer. 30.11. and 46.28. Mat. 10.30 So we see in Job 1.12. and
2.6. and Isreal's bondage, Exodus 12.40, 41. Jer. 25.11. and 29.10. Rev. 2.10.
and 12.6.

2. In that all our afflictions are small and light, far inferior to the
desert of our sins, Lam. 3.22. 2 Cor. 4.17. 1 Cor. 11.32. 2 Cor. 6.9.

3. In that they are momentany, and of short continuance, 1 King. 11.39. 2 Samuel
7.14. Isa. 57.16. Lam. 3.31, 32. Mich. 7.18. Psalm. 103.8, etc. Mal. 3.17. Ps.
30.5. Hos. 6.1, 2. Isa. 54.8. Ps. 71.20.

Secondly, In that our afflictions exceed not our strength: In anger he
remembers Hab. 3.2. He corrects in judgment, Jer. 10.24. and 30.11. 1 Cor.
10.13. yea, he proportioneth them according to the scantest measure of
necessity, laying no more upon us then he is necessarily enforced to do, having
therein respect to his own glory, and our benefit.

Thirdly, in that God the Father has committed the tempering of our Cup Psalm.
103.14. Yea, he himself began to us of this Cup, and drank it all off, and has
left us only some few drops. His was given him in anger for the purging away of
punishment in respect of sin: but ours in love, either to purge out sin, or to
prevent sin, Isa. 53.4, 5. Heb. 4.15, 16. and 2.17, 18. and 5.2. Job 5.18, 19.
Mat. 12.20.

Mat. 8.24. Exodus 2.23. and 14.10. Psalm. 118.18. 2 Cor. 4.8, 9. Romans 8.35. 2
Cor. 1.5, 7. Psalm. 94.19. and 46.4. and that he gives strength also, See Isa.
40.29, 30, 31. Psalm. 41.1, 3. 2 These, 3.3. Isa. 41.10, 13, 14. Psalm. 46.1, 2,
3. God uses to moderate our grief for worldly crosses, by giving us spiritual
comforts, Romans 5.3. Act. 7.76.

1. He takes no delight in our sufferings, but uses all means to prevent our
punishment, Lam. 3.33. Isa. 28.21. Mich. 7.18. 2. The measure of our
afflictions exceeds not necessity, and therefore first he corrects us gently,
and if that prevail, he proceeds no further. 3. By Gods corrections and
medicines we may guess at the greatness of our faults and grievous diseases,
4. Our great afflictions argue that our sins are great, either in their own
nature, or as they are aggravated by circumstances.


1. As a Soldier, behaving himself valiantly in fight, the honor returns
also to his Captain: so when we fight manfully against temptations and
afflictions, God our General is glorified thereby: and that in the
manifestation of his power and goodness, assisting us in our afflictions, 2
Cor. 12.9. and 4.7. Ps. 44.3, 5, 6, 7, 8. 2 Cor. 10.17. Isa. 25.3, 4. 1 Samuel
2.6. Psalm. 50.15. 2. God is glorified in our afflictions, as they are trials of
our spiritual graces, John 21.19. Psalm. 44.22.




1. As they learn by them to fear God in his judgments, 1 Pet. 4.17.

2. As they serve to restrain them from committing the like sin, which they see
punished in us: Thus God severely chastened Moses and Aaron for their distrust,
that others might be aware of the like: so David for his adultery: Lots wife
for looking back, Luke 17.32. So 1 Cor. 10.6, 11.

3. As they serve to manifest Gods graces in us, and so make us examples of
piety unto them, and Presidents for their imitation. So Abraham's trial in
offering Isaac, Genesis 22.2. Moses was tried both with prosperity and adversity,
Heb. 11.25. So Jam. 5.11. Acts 5.41. Jam. 5.8, 10. Mat. 5.12. Phil. 1.13, 14.

4. As they are Partners of humane frailty, whilst in our afflictions we
bewray impatience: For this will comfort a man when he bears his Cross with
much weakness and imperfection, in that he observes that Gods dear children,
yea, and great Worthies have showed the like frailty, as Job 3. Jer. 20.18.

5. As they are occasioned hereby to acknowledge and magnify Gods power,
appearing in our weakness, his wisdom in our foolishness, and his goodness,
and the virtue of his graces in our frailty, and natural corruption, 2 Cor.
1.11.

6. As our hearts are made tender by afflictions, so that we are apt to pity
others in the like miseries: as also because after we are delivered, we are the
better able from our own experience, to comfort others with those consolations,
wherewith ourselves have been comforted. So Psalm. 34.4, 5. 2 Cor. 1.4. So it
was in Christ, Heb. 2.18.

Quest. How will it appear that afflictions cannot hurt the children of God?

Answ. First, because the afflictions of this life do neither deprive us of any
of Romans 8.38, 39. Heb. 12.6. they do not extinguish no^ diminish in us Gods
sanctifying Graces, but rather they are increased by them; they do not make us
more slack in the service of God, but rather kindle our affections in them. Nor
do they hinder our heavenly happiness, but rather further it. Again, they
bring not upon us the chiefest evils that are to be avoided: For they do not
empair our spiritual estate: for though the outward man decay, the inward man
is renewed daily: they defile us not with sin, but rather (like files) scour
off our rust; they do not subject us to the Curse of the Law, or to the wrath
of God, or to the torments of Hell: but rather by bringing us to a fight of our
sin, and sense of our misery, drive us to Christ the great Physician of our
souls, they hurt us not in the day of death, but by our being inured to suffer
them, death becomes much more tolerable, etc. Psalm. 34.19, 22. and 129. 2, 3. 2
Cor. 4.8, 9. Exodus 3.1, 2, 3.

Secondly, because God not only aims at, but powerfully effects our good Romans
8.28. Deuteronomy. 8.16. Lam. 3.27. Ps. 119.71. So Genesis 50.20.

Quest. How does God intend, and work our good by afflictions?

Answ. First, in this life, whether we consider them as trials, or as fatherly

1. As trials, for they are not always chastisements for sin, but sometimes
gracious trials, whereby God tries us for his glory, and our own good. So
Deuteronomy. 8.2. Zach. 13.9. 1 Pet. 4.12, 13. Job 1.9, 10, 12. and 23.10. Psalm.
139.1, 5. and this God does, not to better his own knowledge: for, Psalm. 139.1,
2. Jer. 17.10. Heb. 4.13. but to make us known better, both to our selves and
others. Again, God tries us by afflictions, whether we are true Christians or
no, lest we declare ourselves to others as the stony ground did, Mat. 13.5, 6.
So Mar. 10.22. Christ tried the young man. Yea, God by afflictions tries what
measure of grace we have attained unto, as what measure of faith and affiance
we have in God. So Acts 21.13. Romans 8.35, 38. Job 13.15. So also of our love,
patience, humility and obedience, Acts 20.19. 2 Cor. 6.4, 5. 2 Samuel 15.26. Mar.
14.36.

2. He tries us for the advancing of our credit, and esteem also, through the
manifestation of his graces in us, Prove. 17.3. Ars tua Typhe jacet si non sit
in aequore fluctus, etc.

3. He tries us likewise for the discovery of our infirmities, and corruptions
for our further humiliation, Psalm. 81.7. Mat. 26.70, 71.

Quest. What comfort may the consideration hereof afford us in our afflictions?

Answ. First, this consideration may justly move us to bear all our
afflictions, not only with patience and humility, but also with thanksgiving,
and spiritual

1. Because nothing should seem too difficult to be attempted, nothing too
grievous to be borne, if it tend to the advancement of Gods glory, which should
be the supreme end we should aim at in all we do, and suffer.

2. Because hereby we may get assurance that we are Gods children; for God
tries, and in trying purifieth us, that we may be vessels of glory for his own
use, Isa. 48.10. Psalm. 11.5. Iam. 1.2, 3.

Quest. How may we know that our afflictions are trials, and not punishments
for sin?

Answ. First, when by them we are purified, and made to shine more gloriously
in the eyes of God and men, through the brightness of those saving graces
which are manifested by them.

Secondly, when we a^e not overcome in the conflict, so as to murmr against
the dispensations of God, but show Christian fortitude notwithstanding, and
overcoming all these assaults.

Thirdly, When they prove profitable to us in humbling us for sin, and
quickening us in prayer for pardon and reconciliation through the blood of
Christ.

Secondly, we may be comforted in our afflictions, because they have always
Jam. 1.13. but he tries us to do us good, Deuteronomy. 8.16. 1 Pet. 1.6, 7. and that
after victory we may receive the Crown of eternal life, Rev. 2.10. Job 23.10.

Obj. But my afflictions are great, and my strength small, so that I fear I
shall be overcome?

Answ. God knows how to fit his trials to thy strength, and he has bound
himself by Promise to do it, 1 Cor. 10.13.

Obj. Yea, but in the mean time I am so pressed, that I discover many
corruptions?

Answ. Happily this is necessary and profitable for thee, that thou may be
humbled by the sight and sense of thy corruptions, brought to unfeigned
repentance for them, and an hearty endeavor in the use of all good means, to
be freed from them.

Abraham, Job, David, Paul, etc.



1. By enriching us first with his graces, and then trying them, whereby their
excellency is manifested to all that behold them.

2. By crowning his graces in us, when as by trial they are approved: as the
Armorer first graces his armor by good Workmanship, and then brings it to the
proof, and lastly employes it in his Princes service.

Fifthly, we may be comforted, because God uses afflictions as an effectual
Hosea 5.15. and 6.1, 2. Isa. 17.7. Ps. 83.16. and 78.34, 35. Isa. 26.16. 2 Chronicles. 33.12. Act. 9.5.

1. For by afflictions he fits, and prepares us to hear the Word, Hos. 2 6, 7.
Job 33.16, 17. and 36.15.

2. By afflictions he works in us contrition and humiliation, 2 Samuel 15.26. 1 Chronicles. 21.17. Lam. 3.22.

3. Afflictions are usually the last means that God uses to convert obstinate
sinners, Jer. 8.5, 6. Amos 4.6, 12. If they profit not by these, their case is
desperate as in those foregoing texts. So Isa. 1.5. and 9.13.

Heb. 12.10. Job 33.16, 17. Isa. 4.4. Ezekiel 24.11.



1. First, those which are seated in the understanding; as saving knowledge,
and spiritual wisdom, Prove. 19.15. Isa. 28.19. Hos. 6.1, 3. Job 33.16, 17. and
33.15. Psalm. 119.71. and the benefit of this spiritual wisdom, does much
exceed our hurt by afflictions, Prove. 3.11, 19. and 3.15. John 17.3. Psalm.
94.12.

2. They much confirm, strengthen and increase our faith. So in Abraham, Heb.
11.9. and this they do through the experience which we then have of the truth
both of Gods threatenings and gracious Promises. So 1 Samuel 17.36, 37. 2 Cor.
1.9, 10. As also by causing us to renew our repentance, and assuring us that
our sins, for which we are thus corrected, shall not rise up to our
condemnation, 1 Cor. 11.32. They also strengthen our faith as they are signs
of our Election, Romans 8.29. Luke 24.16. 2 Timothy 2.12. Acts 9.15, 16. Amos 3.20.
and as they are signs of our effectual calling, 2 Timothy 3.12. Luke 9.23. 1 Pet.
4.17. ^er. 25.29. John 15.19. and as they are signs of our Adoption, Gal. 4.1.
Heb. 12.6, 8. 2 Samuel 7.15, 16. Gal. 4.29.

3. They confirm and increase in us affiance, love, hope, fear, and humility.
Our affiance, Jer. 10.6. Psalm. 23.4. and 46.1, 2. 2 Cor. 1.9, 10. Job 13.15. So
for our hope, Romans 5.4. and 4.18, 21. and our love, Cant. 8.6, 7. and our
fear, Psalm. 119.120. Heb. 12.31. Isa. 57.11. Psalm. 111.10. and our humility,
Psalm. 115.1. Dan. 9.7. Deuteronomy. 8.2. 2 Cor. 12.7. 2 Samuel 15.26. 2 Chronicles. 12.6. and
33.12. Lam. 3.28, 29, 30.

4. They increase in us repentance and new obedience, as they put us upon
self-examination to see our sins, and to bewail them with greater grief, Genesis
42.21. Psalm. 32.4, 5. 1 Kings 8.35, 36. God by them increases in us obedience
to his Will, Heb. 12.11. 1 Pet. 4.1, 2. John 15.1, 2. 2 Chronicles. 12.8.

5. They make us more devout and zealous in his service: as in prayer, Isa.
37.1, 2, 3. Psalm. 18.1, 2. 2 Chronicles. 33.12. Isa. 26.16. Psalm. 78.34. and 81.7.
and 107.6, etc. and 108.12. In thanksgiving, Psalm. 103.8. Lam. 3.22. Exodus
15.1. Jude 5.1. Psalm. 30.11, 12. and 59.16, 17. and 9.13, 14. They increase our
patience, Romans 5.3. Jam. 1.3. 2 Samuel 15.26. Heb. 5.8.

2. Secondly, God by afflictions works and increases in us all those
virtues,

1. Hereby we are moved to do justice unto all men.

2. We are made more merciful, and compassionate toward others in misery, Heb.
5.2. and 2.18. and 4.15, 16.

3. We are by them made more humble and courteous toward our neighbors, Prove.
18.23. 1 Kings 20.10, 18, 30, 31.

4. Afflictions bring us to a knowledge of our selves, Psa. 30.6. and 104.29.
Hag. 1.9.

5. By the exercise of afflictions our strength is increased to bear them,
Prove. 24.10.

6. By afflictions God works and increases in us temperance, sobriety,
modesty, and chastity.

Thirdly, God uses afflictions as means to convey to us diverse worldly
benefits

1. By afflictions we profit much in civil wisdom and policy.

2. By them we are enabled to discern our friends from our foes; He who is a
friend in need, is a friend indeed.

3. By them we come the better to relish Gods blessings and benefits, Prove.
27.7.

Quest. What further helps are there to comfort us in, and under afflictions?

Answ. First, if we compare our lesser and lighter afflictions with those
Abraham, Genesis 12.1, 2, 10. and 13.7, 8. and 14.12, 14. and 16.2. and 20.2. and
21. Of Isaac, Gal. 4.29. Genesis 25.35. Of Jacob, Genesis 27. and 34. and 35.22. and
37.35. Of Moses, Heb. 11.25. Of Job, David, Jam. 5.11. 1 Samuel 30* 2 Samuel 18.33.
Of Paul, Act. 9.15, 16. 1 Cor. 4.10. etc. and 2 Cor. 4.9, 10. and 6.4, 5, 6.
and 11.23, etc. And its the lot of the whole Church militant to suffer
afflictions, Isa. 41.14. and 54.11. 1 These. 2.14. The Scripture often foretells
the manifold afflictions of the faithful, Luke 9.23. John 16.20. Revel. 3.19. 2 Timothy 3.12. Heb. 12.6, 8. Acts 14.22. 1 Pet. 5.9. Heb. 10.33, 34.

Isa. 53.2, 3. Heb. 2.10. and 5.8. Luke 24.16. and 8.3. and 9.58. Mat. 27.38,
etc. 46. and consider further.

1. That Christ suffered all those miseries being innocent, Isa. 53.9. 1 Pet.
2.22. 1 John 3.5.

2. Yea, he suffered them for us who are sinners, dead in our sins, children of
wrath, and enemies to God, Isa. 53.4* 5. 1 Pet. 2.24.

3. That we shall be adjudged unworthy to reign with Christ, if we be not
content to suffer with him, Matthew. 10.38, 39. and 16.24, 25. Luke 14.13.

4. That God has pre-ordained those to be like Christ in sufferings, who shall
reign with him in glory, Romans 8.29. 1 Pet. 2.21. 2 Cor. 8.9. Mat. 20.22, 23.

Eighthly, we may be comforted* by comparing our afflictions with the
punishments

1. The wicked endure many and great miseries in this life, for the attaining
of earthly vanities, J^r. 5.9. Hab. 2.13.

2. But especially their intolerable torments in hell, do infinitely exceed all
the miseries of Gods people in this world.

Luke 6.21. John 16.20. Romans 8.18. 2 Cor. 4.17. 1 Pet. 1.4, 6, 7. 1 Cor. 2.9.

Psalm. 118.18. Psalm. 34.17, 19. and 147.3. Heb. 12.10. Psalm. 125.3. Isa. 57.16.
For,

1. God takes notice of all our afflictions to deliver us out of them, Psalm.
34.15. and 94.7, 9. and 33.18, 19. 2 P^t. 1.9. Psalm. 40.17.

2. God is present with us in all our afflictions to help and relieve us, Job
5.15, 16. and 36.15. Psalm. 34.18. and 121.5. and 145.18, 19. and 91.14, 15.
John 14.18. Isa. 43.1, 2. and 41.10, 13, 14. and 46.1, 2, 3. 2 Chronicles. 32.7, 8.
and our God is Omnipotent, and therefore able to help us, Psalm. 18.31. Isa.
63.1. Nahum 1.6, 7. Isa. 26.4. Yea, he loves us, and therefore will deliver us,
Deuteronomy. 7.6. and 32.9. Tit. 2.14. 1 Pet. 2.9. Jer. 31.3. Psalm. 103.13. Isa.
49.15. and he never shows his love more then in the time of affliction, Isa.
63.9. Judge. 10.16. Jer. 31.20. Lam. 3.31, 32, 33.

Mr. Downhams Christian Warfare.

CHAP. VIII. Questions, and Cases of Conscience about the Angels.
Quest. WHat are Angels?

Answ. Created good spirits sent forth by God to minister for the good of the
Elect, and for the punishment of the wicked, Heb. 1.17, 14. 2 Kings 19.15.

Quest. What titles does the Scripture give to them?

Answ. First, they are called spirits, to show their nature, which is
spiritual.

Secondly, Ministers, to show their Office, which is to

Thirdly, Men of God: So Judge. 13.6, 9. The Angel is called a man, because he
appeared in the shape of a man: and a man of God, because he came from, and was
sent by God.

Fourthly, Sons of God: So Job 1.6. Because they received their being, and are
sustained by God, as also for that being made after his Image, they still
retain the same.

Fifthly, Gods. So Psalm. 8.5. to set out their excellency, Psalm. 82.1, 6. For
so in Scripture^language excellent things are styled Gods, Psalm. 97.7.

Sixthly, Cherubims, Genesis 3.24. Ezekiel. 10.1. which signifies a Figure or Image:
most usually a resemblance of a young man: for so they appeared as a man, to
show that they had knowledge and understanding, (as men have reasonable souls)
and as a young man, to set out their beauty, vigor, strength, etc.

Seventhly, Seraphims, Isa. 6.2, 6. which comes from an Heb. word that
signifies to burn: and they were so called, either from this particular act in
touching the Prophets lips with a burning cole: or from their fervent zeal in
executing the Will of God.

Eighthly, Watchers: So Dan. 4.13, 17. and its attributed to Angels.

1. Because of their nature, being spirits they are not subject to drowsinesse
and sleepiness: but wake and watch day and night.

2. Because of their office, which is always to behold the face of God, Mat.
18.10. and to be ever ready to do his Will, Psalm. 103.20. which requires
watching.

3. Because of the constant and continual care that they have over the Saints
to keep them from the manifold dangers, whereunto they are subject. Hence they
are said to be full of eyes round about, Ezekiel. 1.18.

Holy ones; So Dan. 4.13, 17. because of that holiness wherein they were at
first created, and in which they still abide: Hence called holy Angels, Mar.
8.38. Mat. 25.31.

Gods Host. So Genesis 32.2. Psalm. 103.21. Luke 2.13. because God uses them as an
Host to protect his Saints, 2 Kings 6.17. and to destroy his enemies, 2 Chronicles.
32.21. Rev. 12.7.

Thrones. So Col. 1.16. because of their dignity and excellency, being fit to
sit on thrones, at least in comparison of other creatures.

Dominions: So Col. 1.16. because God has given them dominion and rule,
whereby as Lords under God they order and govern matters and persons in the
world.

Principalities; as Dominions note indefinitely and generally, such as have
authority without respect to any peculiar jurisdiction; So Principalities are
such as have a special and peculiar jurisdiction: So Tit. 3.1. Its attributed
to Angels, Ephesians. 3.10. Col 1.16. because God sets them over particular Policies,
Kingdoms and Persons.

Powers: the word properly signifies that right which Governors have to
exercise their authority. So John 10.18. Acts 5.4. It shows therefore that
Angels have a good right to that Government which they take upon them.

Mights: this title imports strength and ability to accomplish what they
undertake. Hence they are said to be mighty in strength, Psalm. 103.20. So they
are called, Romans 8.38.

Quest. What are the principal properties of the Angels?

Answ. First, they have great knowledge: for they are understanding creatures
Mat. 18.10. In Heaven they always behold the face of God, implying, that they
are privy to the whole Counsel of God revealed in Heaven. On earth also they
frequent the Assemblies of Saints, whereby they know the whole counsel of God
made known to the Church, Ephesians. 3.10. 1 Pet. 1.12. And this gift is necessary,
because their maine function, is to be Gods messengers to declare and execute
his Will, which they could not do without knowledge thereof.

Jam. 3.13. they are coupled together. And this is necessary, because the evil
Angels, against whom the good Angels defend the Saints, are exceeding crafty
and subtle.

Thirdly, Purity: which is perfect without the mixture of any impurity and Rev.
15.6. Hence they are styled holy Angels, Mar. 8.38. under which is comprised
their sincerity, Rev. 14.5. and their integrity in execuring Gods Will, Psalm.
103.20. and these are necessary to make them fit to appear in the Presence of
the pure and holy God; For Rev. 21.27. Hab. 1.13. Psalm. 5.4.

Fourthly, Glory: such is the brightness of their glory, that its resembled to
Mat. 28.3. so that men on earth cannot endure the brightness of Angels, Numb.
22.31, 33. Mat. 28.4. Yea, good men cannot endure it, Luke 1.12. and 2.9. Rev.
19.10. and 22.8. Dan. 8.17. and this is necessary for the glory of the Lord
whom they serve, as Courtiers attending upon Kings are gorgeously attired, Mat.
11.8.

Fifthly, Power: Hence they are called mighty, 2 These. 1.7. Strong, Rev. Psalm.
103.20. Resembled to horses and charets of fire, 2 Kings 6.17. See what one
Angel did, 1 Kings 17.35. and this is necessary, because the Church and
children of God whom they defend, have here against them, not only many,
mighty, cruel, malicious men, but Principalities, Powers, etc. Ephesians. 6.12.

Sixthly, Speed: Hence they are said to have wings, Isa. 6.2. Dan. 9.21, 23.

1. They cannot be hindered by any bodily impediments, no corporal substance
can stay their course; they can pass through, and pass over Castles, Cities,
Stone-walls, Iron-gates, Woods, Rivers, Seas, etc.

2. They have no corporal gravity to slaken their motion.

3. They need not such space of time to pass from place to place, as bodies
need. They can suddenly move from heaven to earth, or into any place of the
world.

4. They have great forwardness to do any task enjoined by their Lord, more
then any other creatures. Its necessary for them.

1. Because heaven and earth are so far asunder, and they have often occasions to
pass from one to the other.

2. Many Saints in the world, (whose distress requires present succors) are
far distant one from another.

3. Devils are very swift to mischief: and its meet that good Angels be as
swift to protect, as evil ones to annoy.

Seventhly, Zeal, which is most fervent; Hence Seraphim; such as burn flame of
fire, Heb. 1.7. Its necessary because of the fiery fury of the devil and his
instruments in plotting against Gods glory, and his Saints good, therefore the
good Angels must be as zealous in maintaining the cause of God and his Saints,
as the other are furious against them.

Eighthly, Constancy in good: and this with respect both to their condition

In respect of their condition they are immortal, and without decay; Hence
after the Resurrection we are said to be equal to the Angels, Luke 20.36.

In respect of their disposition: It always temains good, and ever will do:
they never yielded to any evil, nor were weary of good, nor never repented of
doing good. Hence Rev. 7.15. they serve God day and night: And Mat. 18.10. Its
necessary, because the Lord whom they serve is Jehovah that changes not, Mal.
3.6. Jam. 1.17. God established the good Angels that stand, and this is the
true cause of their unalterable constancy.

Quest. What are the Offices of the Angels?

Answ. They may be ranked under three Heads.

First, such as they perform to God, which are these.

1. They attend in his Presence for the honor of his Majesty, and to set out
his magnificence. So 1 Kings 22.19.

2. They follow the Lord whithersoever he goes. Hence styled Charets of God,
Psalm. 68.17.

3. They are his Messengers to be sent on his Errands, Psalm. 104.4. Dan. 7.10.

4. They are often employed in declaring his Will, as in delivering the Law, Acts
7.53. Gal. 3.19. Heb. 2.2. So in diverse other particulars: As Genesis 16.7, 9. and
19.1. 2 Kings 1.3. Dan. 7.16. Luke 1.13, 26* and 2.10. Acts 1.11. and 5.19, 20.
and 8.26. and 10.3. Revelat. 1.1.

5. They are his Ministers, to do what God appoints them, Psalm. 103.20. Genesis
19.1. Numb. 20.16. Numb. 22.22. Dan. 6.22.

6. They are Executioners of Gods judgments, as 2 Samuel 24.15, 16. 2 King.
19.35. Rev. 15.7.

7. They are special instruments of praising God, Rev. 7.11, 12. and 4.8. Hence
they are called on to do it, Psalm. 103.20. and 142.2.

John 1.51. G^n. 28.12. Heb. 1.6. Psalm. 91.11. More particularly, 1. They
foretold his conception, Luke 1.30, 31. 2. Declared his birth, Luke 2.9. etc.
3. Prevented his danger, Mat. 2.13, 14. 4. Ministered to him in his need, Mar.
1.13. 5. Protected him from enemies, Mat. 26.53. 6. Comforted him in his Agony,
Luke 22.43. 7. Opened his Grave at his Resurrection, Mat. 28.2. 8. Witnessed
his Resurrection, Luke 24.5, 6, 23. 9. Confirmed his Ascension, Acts 1.10, 11.
10. Accompanied him to Heaven, Ps. 68.17, 18. Ephesians. 4.8. 11. Reveal what he will
have done, Rev. 1.1. and 22.16. 12. Fight with him against his enemies, Rev.
12* 7. 13. Gather out of his Kingdom all things that offend, Matthew. 13.49, 50.
14. Accompany him at his last coming, Mar. 8.38. Mat. 25.31. 15. Execute his
last judgment, Mat. 13.49, 50.


Heb. 1.14. Hence, Mat. 18.10. In particular, 1. They are Stewards to provide
for them in their need, 1 Kings 19.5, etc. 2. As Physicians to cure their
maladies, John 5.4. 3. As Nurses to bear up and keep them from hurt, Ps. 91.11,
12. 4. As Guides to direct and keep them from wanderings, Genesis 24.7. and 32.1.
5. As soldiers to guard them, Psalm. 34.7. 2 Kings 6.17. and to destroy their
enemies, 2 Kings 19.35. 6. Rescuers and deliverers to pull them out of dangers,
Acts 5.19. and 12.7, etc. Dan. 6, 22. In reference to our souls in this life:
1. They are as Prophets or Teachets to instruct them, Dan. 8.16, 17. and 9.22.
Luke 1.15, 34, 35. Act. 1.11. 2. They are Comforters to them in their fears
and perplexities, Genesis 21.17. Isa. 6.6, 7. 3. Coadjutors to stand with them
against Satan, Zach. 3.1, 2. Judge. 9. 4. Fellow Members to rejoice with them at
the Conversion of sinners, Luke 15.10 5. Tutors to punish them for their
offenses, that they may be brought to repentance, 2 Samuel 24.16. In the life to
come they are, 1. Watchers, to carry their souls at the separation of them
from their bodies into Heaven, Luke 16.22. 2. As Keepers at the last day to
gather all the Elect together, Matthew. 24.31. 3. Fanners or Fishers to separate
the evil from the good, Matthew. 13.49. 4. Companions in Heaven to join with
them in praising God, Rev. 7.9, 10, 11.




Dr. Gouge on Heb.

Quest. Why does God use the Ministry of the Angels about us?

Answ. Not for any necessity, for he can do it of himself without them; but to
declare his abundant love to, and care of us in providing for our comfort, and
making far more excellent creatures then our selves our Keepers.

Quest. Why are the Angels such tender Keepers of Gods children?

Answ. First, because Christ our Head (who is their Lord and Head also) has
Col. 1.20. viz. Angels and men* so that whereas they hate us for our sins,
now they tender us as hi^ members.

2. They love us as Nurses their children, now that they see that God loves us

Thirdly, because he has given them charge and commandment so to do, Ps.

Quest. What comfort does the consideration hereof bring to Gods children?

Answ. First, When we see our own weakness and impotency on the one hand, and
the multitude, power and policy of the enemies on the other. When

Secondly, when we neglect the Watch over our selves, through sleep of Mat.
2.13. when Joseph slept, dreaming of no danger from Herod, the Angel
admonishes him in a dream, and tells him how to escape.

Thirdly, when we see great difficulties between us and our desires, what
comfort is it that we have Gods Angels ready to do it to our hands? as Mar

Fourthly, when Satan begins to insult, and makes as if he would t^ample upon
Daniel. Dr. ^ailor.

Fifthly, that their care and attendance on us will be perpetual, because their
love to us is founded on their love to Christ our Head, whose Members and

Ob. But Gods children often fall into inconveniences, how then are they
attended by the Angels?

Answ. First, they are preserved by the Angels from many inconveniences

Secondly, if at any time we fall into inconveniences, its because we are out
Ps. 91.11.

Thirdly, if we suffer in the custody of Angels any inconvenience, it is that
we Romans 8.28.

Quest. What may this Guardianship of the Angels teach us?

Answ. First, Not to grieve these good spirits: Its wondrous humility in them
that they will stoop to be our servants that are weaker, and baser then they:
and its wonderful patience that they will continue to guard us, though we
grieve them by our sins: this consideration would keep us from secret sins
where no eye of man sees us, but God and our consciences, and the blessed
Angels see us, and grieve when we fall into sin.

Tim. 5.21. but they are not the Spouse of Christ as we are; he has honored
our nature more then the Angelical.

Quest. But what need we the guard of Angels, since God can guard us without
them?

Answ. It is not by reason of any defect in God to supply his want of power,
but further to enlarge and demonstrate his goodness: God could do it of
himself, but having ordained such ranks of creatures, he makes all to serve for
his own ends.

Quest. What may we learn further from hence?

Answ. First, to take an holy State upon us, and to think our selves too good
to abase our selves to sin, to be slaves to men, seeing we have Angels to
attend upon us; we are Kings, and have a mighty guard, therefore we should
carry our selves answerable.



Quest, What excellencies are attributed to the Angels in Scripture?

Answ. They are said to be excellent for holiness, Mar. 8.38. excellent for
beauty, Acts 6.15. excellent for strength, Psalm. 103.20. excellent for wisdom,
2 Samuel 14.17. excellent for swiftness. Hence Isaiah 6.2.

Quest. Wherein should we imitate the Angels?

Answ. First, rejoice at the Conversion of sinners as they do, Luke 15.

Isa. 6.2, 25.

Psalm. 103.20, 21.

viz. with cheerfulness, sincerity, and without wearisomness.

Quest. What further comfort may the Nature and Offices of the Angels afford us?

Ans. First, In regard of their readiness they stand before the face of God,
ready

Jacob was alone, the blessed Angels were with him.







Quest. How are the Angels employed?

Answ. First, in respect of God they stand before him to execute his Will,
Psalm. 103.20, 21: and to praise him, Isa. 6.3.

Secondly, In respect of man they are employed.

1. By way of punishment, and that 1. To blind them that they cannot see, Genesis
19.11. 2. To stop them that they cannot go, Number. 22.26. 3. To slay them that
they cannot live, 2 King. 19.15. Acts 12.23.


2. In mercy to the godly, and that 1. To defend them from dangers, Ps. 34.8.
2. To comfort them in troubles, Luke 22.23. 3. To encourage them in duties, 2
King. 1.15. 4. To reveal to them hidden mysteries, Dan. 9.22, 23, 24. 5. To
carry their souls to heaven, Luke 16.22.


Quest. How else does God use the Ministry of Angels?

Answ. First, in the swaying of the Kingdoms of the world, and wherein we Ephesians.
3.10. they are called Principalities and Powers, because God gives them a
pre-eminence under him, and a power of ordering th^se inferior things; As the
devils are called, Powers of darkness, Ephesians. 6.12. because the wickedness of
the world does set them up as Kings and Princes: So Dan. 10.13. the Angels are
called Great Princes. They are made to he above Kings and earthly Powers, as
God is above them, Eccl. 5.8. Marvel not at the oppression in a Province; for
there is an high one above the High on earth: and there is the Father, Son, and
Spirit, higher then both. A created Angel led the Israelites into Canaan, as
may be gathered by comparing the 20. and 31. Chapters of Exodus together.

Secondly, they are Gods Warriors and Ministers of his manifold decrees. Kings
2.11. and 6.17. Hab. 3.8. Ps. 68.17.

Thirdly, they are Spirits of Heaven, Mat. 24.36. Gal. 1.8. resembling Sons of
God, Job 1.6. and 38.7. both in regard of their substance, which is
incorporeal: and in regard of their excellent properties, life, and
immottality, blessedness and glory, a part whereof is their just Lordship, and
Command over the inferior Creatures. For as they stand before the Lord, who
sends them out at his pleasure to serve his Providence, so they have no small
stroke in ordering and managing natural and civil affairs. Hence Ezekiel. 1.6, 7.
they have faces to look every way, when as Gods Watchmen, they stand Sentinel
in Heavens Turret: their feet are like Calves feet, round, and ready to go
either forward or backward with greatest facility. For as they see every way,
so they are ready to go every way, for dispensing Gods benefits, or executing
his chastisements on the Elect, and his vengeance on reprobates. Let us labor
to obey God as the Angels do; else we may be Angels for gifts, and yet go to
Hell.

Angels wait for Gods commands, and are ready to run on his errand, Mat. 18.10.
Dan. 7.10. Jacob saw them at Bethel, ascending to contemplate and praise God,
and to minister to him; and descending to execute Gods Will upon men for mercy
or judgment?

Quest. What other employment have they?

Answ. They are eyewitnesses of what is done in the Church of God, 1 Cor.
11.10. The woman ought to have power on her head, because of the Angels. This
was shadowed out in the old Church? Exodus 36.8. the Curtains were wrought with
Cherubims, to signify that about us, who are the true Tabernacle, and Church
of God, there are troops of Angels. Hence 1 Timothy 5.21.

Quest. How manifold is the knowledge of the Angels?

Answ. Its fourfold.





Dan. 7.16, etc.



Now the knowledge which the Apostle speaks of, that they have acquired, Ephesians.
3.10. is this knowledge of experience, beholding that which the Gospel wrought
in the Church, they did more fully see the work of Redemption. For, 1. They did
see accomplished before their eyes things which they had known in some sort; as
we know things absent unaccomplished. 2. They did thus grow to a more full and
confirmed enlightening, in the wise work of our Redemption. 3. And, which is
the principal, they did thus come to a more full knowledge, and acknowledgment
of the deep riches of the wisdom of God, the fountain of the former. For
though the Angels had always a blessed knowledge of God; yet not a perfect,
either in regard of themselves seeing, or of God seen: they did not see him
totaliter, so as there was no further thing in him to be seen; nor yet with
such a sight in regard of themselves; so perfect, that no further light could
be lent to it then it had.


Baines on the Ephesians.

CHAP. IX. Questions, and Cases of Conscience about Anger, Wrath, Passion,
Malice, Hatred, and Revenge.
Quest. HOw many sorts of Anger be there?

Answ. Two. 1. Good. 2. Bad.

Quest. What is good Anger?

Answ. Its a displeasure not against the person, but against the sin of our
neighbor, or of our selves: this anger being moderate, and joined with
compassion is an holy anger: Commanded, Ephesians. 4.21. Commended, 2 Cor. 7.11. Or,

Its a displeasure at that which stands in our way, and hinders good. Thus
Moses was angry, Exodus 11.8. Lev. 10.16. etc.

Quest. What is bad Anger?

Answ. Its a desire to be revenged upon the person of our neighbor, either by
words or deeds, threatened, Mat. 5.22.

Quest. Why is Anger placed in the heart?

Answ. First, to be an Harbinger, or Usher to prepare the way, for obtaining
some good desired, and to remove the obstacles that lie in the way.

Secondly, to be as it were the hearts dagger for the defense of love, desire,
delight,

Quest. How must we act Anger?

Answ. First, against sin as the open enemy, and grand Obstructer of Gods
glory, Isa. 59.2. especially against sin in our selves: and in those that are
near and dear to us. So Moses, Exodus 32.19. Nehemiah, chapter 13.17, 21.

Secondly, For the removal of the impediments of Gods glory, and our

Thirdly, for the Reformation of the person, and the abuse.

Quest. How may it be proved that there is a good and lawful Anger?

Answ. First, because its attributed to God himself, Romans 1.18. John

Secondly, it was made by God, and was in man before the fall.

Thirdly, yea, it was in Christ himself as man, Mar. 3.5. Mat. 10.14. Joh.

Fourthly, many holy men in Scripture are commended for it, Exodus 16.20. Act.
8.20. Act. 7.24. and 13.11, 12. Neh. 5.6.

Fifthly, in true repentance there must be anger and revenge, 2 Cor. 7.11.

Eccles. 7.3. and commands it, Ephesians. 4.26. Mat. 5.22.



Quest. When is anger rightly ordered?

Answ. When it is moved, quickened and guided by faith, stirring up godly sorrow
for sin in our selves or others, joined with an holy and just desire of
revenge, to the saving of the person, appeasing of Gods anger, and promoting
the Kingdom of Christ.

Holy anger must have a just and weighty occasion: so we read of Moses, he was
angry, when contrary to the command of God Mann^h was reserved till the next
morning, Exodus 16.20. when they tempted God in worshipping the golden calf,
Exodus 23.19. When Corah etc. rebelled, Numb. 16.15. The causes of just anger
are,

Phineas, Numb. 25.7, 8. and Elias, 1 King. 19.14.

Paul, Acts 23.2. and in Christ, John 18.23. But this gives no place to private
revenge, when out of bitterness of spirit we seek the hurt of them that wrong
us. Forbidden, Matthew. 5.39. Romans 12.17. yet when wronged we may implore the aid
of the Magistrate, yet without a desire to hurt him that wrongs us, as Luke
18.3.

Thirdly, when injury is offered to our brethren; for by the law of charity we
Moses, Acts 7.24. in David, 2 Samuel 13.21. in Nehemiah, chapter 5.6. hence, James
1.9. we are commanded to be slow to anger: For the object of holy anger is sin,
not the person: so in David, Ps. 119.139. in Jeremy, chapter 6.10, 11.

Quest. What are the properties of holy anger?

Answ. First, It must begin at home: we must be most angry with our own sins.

Hab. 3.1, 2. So in Moses, he prays for those with whom he was angry, Exodus
32.31, etc.

Thirdly, anger for an offense must be mixed with sorrow for the offense. So in
Mark 3.5. Hence Gal. 61.

Fourthly, we must show Christian modesty in our anger, by abstaining Michael,
Jude 9.

decorum, and fit respect in it, and that,

1. In regard of our selves, we must have respect to our place and calling: A
Magistrate must show his anger, not only in countenance and words, but in his
actions also: and so must a father, the contrary was Eli's sin; but a private
person must only show it in countenance and words.

2. The offenders are not to be used all alike: A mean man must not show his
anger to a noble man, or Magistrate as he may to his equal; the son must not
show his anger to his father as the father may to the son. Moses, a Magistrate
uses the sword, Exodus 32.27. John Baptist, a Minister, uses only the sword
of the Spirit, Matthew. 3.7. Jacob a private man toward Laban, uses only mild
and gentle admonitions, Genesis 31.36. Jonathan by rising from the Table, and
going out, 1 Samuel 20.34. The three children in humble and respective words to
the King, Dan. 3.16. Paul the like to Festus, and Agrippa, Acts 25.10, 11. and
26.25, 29.

so as that it make us not to neglect our duty either to God or man.

Seventhly it must be moderate, rising and falling according to the nature of

Eighthly, it must be seasonable for time and continuance: It must not continue

Ninthly, the ends of holy anger must be just and holy: which are,

1. The glory of God which is set forth by our anger, when being private
persons we manifest our detestation of sin in word and countenance: Being
Magistrates we punish sin, and execute justice.

2. The good of Church and Commonwealth, which most properly belongs to
Magistrates who are to punish sin, not only that civil justice may be
maintained, but that Gods anger which hangs over whole countries where sin is
countenanced, or not justly punished, may be averted.

3. The good of the party: For hereby the offender is restrained from the like
future miscarriages.

Quest. How are we to stir up just and holy anger in our selves?

Answ. We are to stir it up by the exaggeration of the injury done, or
received, and that by the consideration of these four circumstances.

First, from the person that does the wrong: his baseness, wisdom, gravity,

Secondly, the second circumstance is the injury it self, as if we be injured
in

Thirdly, the person injured; as if he be a person of great authority, esteem,
and virtue: If one that was then endeavoring the offenders good, etc. In

Fourthly, the mannner of injuring: as if we be esteemed as friends, and yet
For in words we profess our selves Christ's servants, but in deeds we deny him:
We lightly regard his presence: sin against knowledge, and conscience, etc. If
ever we had just cause of indignation, it is against our selves for sinning
against God.

Quest. Why is anger rightly to be ordered?

Answ. First, because of all passion: it is deepliest rooted, and extends its
branches farthest; For no age, condition, or nation are free from it: other
passions only trouble some particular persons. Lust enflames one, ambition
another, covetousness another, etc. But whole states are enflamed by anger,
and fury.







Fifthly, it is the character of a fool, Prove. 12.16. and 14.17, 29. Eccles.

Sixthly, it makes a man unmindful of his own condition: If poor, yet he will

Seventhly, an angry person can neither please God nor man: He regards

Quest. What are the several kinds of disordered anger that must be shunned?

Answ. It Is disordered when it is not moved by faith, arises not from love,
keeps not within its bounds, and is not directed to a right end. The kinds of
it are many.

Caine, Genes. 4.5. In Saul, 2 Samuel 20.30. In Asa, 2 Chronicles. 16.10. In the Jews,
Luke 4.28. In Nebuchadnezzar, Dan. 3.13.



1. Unjust anger that proceeds from our own suspicion and imagination only, as
in Eliab, 1 Samuel 17.28.

2. When we are provoked without cause, or upon every small occasion contrary to
the law of love, 1 Corinthians. 13.7. Prove. 10.12. and it is a man's glory to pass
by a Transgression, Proverbs 19.11. And so sudden anger which is admitted
without deliberation; condemned, Eccles. 7.9. Its a foolish thing, Prove.
14.17.29. such abound with transgressions, Proverbs 29.22.

Thirdly, immoderate, and immodest anger: which may be discerned by

1. When men utter words dishonorable to God by blaspheming, swearing,
cursing, etc. or opprobrious to their neighbors, as when their anger breaks
out into bitter and reviling speeches, as Shemei did against David, 2 Samuel
16.5. the Jews against Steven, Acts 7.54. Forbidden, Ephesians. 4.32.

3. When we have no regard of order, and comeliness, either in respect of our
selves, or those with whom we are angry: In respect of our selves, when (though
private men) we take revenge, which belongs to God, Romans 12.19. In respect of
the party with whom we are angry; as when a son being angry with his father
(though upon just cause) uses him unreverently: and so of servants toward
their Masters, etc. and all inferiors toward their superiors.

4. When it makes us forget any duty of love which we owe to them, as to pray
for them, and endeavor their reformation: So in the Disciples, Luke 9.54.

5. When it stirs us up to violent and unseasonable reproofs, Psalm 106.32, 33.

6. When its not mixed with sorrow proportionable to the displeasure that we
conceived: He that is rightly angry, though he be displeased with the offense,
yet he pities the offender.

Fourthly, when anger is partial its disordered: and that is,

1. When its hot against some sins* and can brook others as bad, either because
they suite with our disposition, or that we have little wrong by them.

2. when we are zealous against sin in our enemies, but ^avourable to it in our
selves or friends.

3. When we are as angry for small as for great offenses: whereas our anger
should be proportioned to the offense.

Fifthly, when it is directed against the person of the offender, not against
Cains toward Abel: Saul's toward David, Nebuchadnezzars toward the three
children, but Christ's rule is otherwise, Mat. 5.44.

Sixthly, when being long retained it turns to hatred.

Quest. What Motives may dissuade us from sinful anger?

Answ. First, consider the sinful causes of it, which are

1. Unbelief in Gods Word; David tells us that he was so patient toward his
adversaries because he waited upon God, Psalm. 38.13, etc.

2. Folly, for Eccles. 7.9. it rests in the bosom of fools.

3. Self-love which makes us so to prize our selves as never to think on the
injuries and indignities we do to others; and hainously to aggravate every
small wrong done to our selves.

4. Pride, which makes us more sharp-^ighted in apprehending a wrong, and more
furiously insolent in taking revenge, Prove. 13.10. so in the Ephramites, Judge.
8.1. and 12.1, etc. so Psalm. 10.2. This set Haman against Mordecai, and the
Jews, Esth. 3.5, 6.

5. Covetousness: For if the hope of a covetous man fail his expectation,
their unquiet thoughts prepare a lodging in their hearts for anger; they
trouble their own house, Prove. 15.27.

6. Impotency, and effeminatenesse of mind which makes men unable to bear
injuries: Hence women, children, sick, and aged persons are so waiward.

7. Luxurious niceness; If the houses of such are not kept neat; their diet
cooked to their minds: if a spot be on their clothes, they are so enraged that
the house will not hold them.

8. Curiosity: For when men have an itching desire to see and hear all things:
How friends, and foes speak of them: what servants do, and say, etc. they come
to hear, and know many things which provoke them to anger. Hence Prove. 20.3.
Eccles. 7.21, 22.

9. Lightness in believing reports, and listening to tale-bearers: Hence,
Prove. 26.20. and 16.28. so in Saul, 1 Samuel 22.19. yea, in David, in hearkening
to Ziba, 2 Samuel 19.29. Hence Jam. 3.6.

10. Inordinate love, or excessive sorrow: For the powers of the soul, being
weakened by these passions, are made unable to bear any burden.

11. Want of meditating on the common imperfections whereunto we are all by
nature subject: For if we consider that our selves have as great, or greater
faults as those we are angry for in others, we would not be so easily provoked
for every trifling occasion, Eccles. 7.21, 22. Titus. 2.3. If we would look
more at home, and less abroad, it would prevent much anger.

12. Tenderness of education, and foolish cockering of mothers, begets anger,
making their children more teasty then wasps, more proud then peacocks, more
wanton then the Asse-colt, etc. whereas severer education would pull down their
stomachs, and make them more patient.

13. Idleness, unthriftinesse, and voluptuousness nourish anger. Hence,
Proverbs 26.17. 1 These. 4.11. 1 Timothy 5.13. Proverbs 16.12, etc. and 20.1.





1. It blindes reason, and makes men for the present as though they were
distract of their wits. It Is a short madness, and in this respect worse; for
that madness is involuntary* but this passion is entered into willingly and
wittingly. Madness is an evil of punishment, but this is an evil of sin: So in
Simeon, and Levi, Genesis 34.25. In David, 1 Samuel 25.13, 22. in Saul, 1 Samuel
22.18, 19. in Theodosius.

2. As it springs from, so it causes infidelity, and fretting against God, as
in Moses, Numb. 20.10, etc. Prove. 19.3. 2 Samuel 6.8.

3. It extinguisheth the love of God, which cannot kindle in such an unquiet
breast. How should we love God whom we have not seen, if we love not our
neighbor whom we have seen, 1 John 4.20.

4. It Is an hindrance of holy prayer. An angry man cannot call upon God, or if
he should, God would not hear. Hence, Psalm. 26.6. 1 Timothy 2.8. Mat. 5.23. and
6.12, 14, 15. 1 Pet. 3.7.

5. It makes the Word of God unprofitable: Hence, Jam. 1.19. Be swift to hear,
slow to wrath. It hardens the heart that the Word cannot take root.

6. It so fills, and swells the mind that there is no room for good thoughts,
and meditations, it is so full of thoughts of revenge, etc. so that it stops
communion with God, and disturbs the peace of conscience.

7. It makes men impatient of admonition, which is ordained by God as one means
to recover us from sin: so in Abner when justly reproved, 2 Samuel 3.8.

8. It grieves the Spirit of God, and lets the Devil into men's hearts, to whose
image they are conformed by unjust anger, Ephesians. 4.27.30, 31.

9. It disfits a man for society. Hence, Prove. 22.24, 25. make no friendship
with an angry man, etc.

10. It macerates, and vexes the soul with fury, so that they become
self-tormentors; Rage, and fury, tortures more then wrong, and injury.

11. It exposes to infinite dangers, by provoking men to enter into private
quarrels so as wholly to neglect themselves, that they may hurt their enemies:
Like the Be that loses her life to sting others. It often ruins the body;
some being extraordinarily moved have broken their veins, and vomited out their
souls with their blood. Others have fallen into mortal diseases, as Apoplexies,
frenzies, madness, palsies, falling sickness, etc. These are its effects in
regard of our selves; now in regard of our neighbors.

1. It overthrows all friendship: for there was never friendship so inviolable,
but anger has dissolved it. Hence, Prove. 27.4. Anger is cruel, and wrath
raging: they will fall from words to blows, then to wounds, then to death.

2. Yea, it makes men hurt whom they should most love, as wife, children,
servants, who being necessarily conversant with them, are most exposed to their
fury.

3. It Is the gate of vice whereby it enters. Hence, Psalm. 37.8. Cease from
anger, leave off wrath, fret not thy self to do evil; so Prove. 29.22. A furious
man abounds in transgressions: so Jam. 1.20.

The effects of anger which are caused by others as a deserved punishment of
it, are,

1, It subjects a man to the wrath of God, and brings his curse upon him, Mat.
6.14, 15. Hence Job 5.2. Prove. 19.19. Mat. 5.22.

2. Such are a prey to Satan, whilst they plot, and devise that mischief which
pleases him; and when once by passion he has blinded the eye of reason, he
can easily lead us into all wickedness. As Crows first pick out the sheeps
eyes, and then prey upon them.

3. It brings contempt from men, whence by it they blaze abroad their folly,
whereas wisdom procures honor and respect.

4.. An angry man lies open to the malice, fraud and violence of his adversary:
For having no power over his passion when provoked, he rusheth himself
headlong into danger, not caring what he says, or what he does, though
tending to his own prejudice, and to his adversaries advantage.

Prove. 23.26. God calls for the heart, i. e. a heart well drained from sinful
affections; and a Christian may fetch a surer evidence of his spiritual estate
from his reformation herein, then from any particular duty to the affirmative
Commandments of the moral Law.

Object. But I am chollerick by nature and cannot expel it?

Answ. This excuse is no better then Adams fig-leafe to hide the nakedness of
thy sin. It will not excuse us before a temporal Judge to say, we are prone by
nature to such a sin: much less before God, God gave us not such a nature, but
it comes from original sin, therefore we must not excuse one sin with another;
and what serves grace for but to reform nature. If thou be regenerate by
the Holy Ghost, he makes of a Leopard a Lamb, etc. Esaias 11.6, 7.

Object. Though I be somewhat hot for the time, yet it is quickly gone?

Answ. Eccles. 7.9. Be not of an hasty spirit, for anger rests in the bosom of
fools: Many are the mischiefs of sudden anger: as it begins without son, so it
ends without shame, and repentance: Gods children should resemble their
heavenly father, who is slow to anger, Exodus 34.6, 7.

Object. I say nothing in my passion, what would you have me do?

Answ. Concealed anger, (if nourished in the heart, and hidden to have a better
opportunity for revenge, or being dissembled for credits sake) is worse then
professed anger. First, in respect of the party that is angry, because
turbulent affections kept in, torment the more, like a raging fire that has no
vent, or a violent stream that is stopped. Secondly, in respect of the person
with whom we are angry; because it makes him less wary, and more secure. Hence
a secret enemy is more dangerous then a professed enemy: Prove. 12.20. and
14.17. as we see in. Caine, Genesis 4.8. In Absolon, 2 Samuel 13.22, 23. in Joab, 2 Samuel 20.9. in Judas, Luke 22.47.

Object. But he has often offended me; I can bear no longer.

Answ. Love covers a multitude of sins, Prove. 11.12. we must forgive to seventy
times seven times, Mat. 18.22. as David did to Saul; Joseph to his brethren.

Object. But except God give us the gift of patience we can never put up
injuries contentedly?

Answ. Such would have God do all, and will do nothing themselves: For if they
sincerely desired the grace of patience, they would use Gods means to get it.

Quest. But by what means is corrupt anger to be subdued, and mortified?

Answ. First, faith, as it moderates all passions, so this of sinful anger:

1. By stamping Gods image of goodness, patience, and long-suffering upon the
soul: A man cannot have fellowship with God by faith, but he shall be like him:
Faith teaches us to imitate our heavenly father, as Exodus 34.6. Psalm. 103.8, 9.
see his long-suffering, 1 Pet. 3.19* 20. Ezekiel. 4.5. therefore Col. 3.12. Look
upon Christ's example, and imitate him.

2. By acknowledging the providence of God, without which the least injury
could not befall us: the least being a portion of that cup which Gods hand
reaches out to us: So in Job, chap. 1.21. in Joseph, Genesis 50.20. in David, 2 Samuel 16.10, 11. This persuasion that all our sufferings come from God, is a
forcible motive to patience. For 1. It constraines us to confess that all our
chastisements are just, yea, less then our sins deserved, being but light and
momentany: we have cause therefore to admire Gods goodness in such gentle
rods, rather then to be angry at them. 2. It teaches that the manner of Gods
dealing is exceeding tender, and compassionate, Psalm. 25.10. when we deserve to
be cast into hell fire, he does only lop and prune to make us more fruitful,
therefore we have more cause to be thankful then to be offended. 3. It shows
that God in his infinite wisdom will dispose of every thing for our good, as
he has promised, Romans 8.28. why then should we be angry, seeing God will turn
the injuries of men into blessings? say therefore with Christ, John 18.11.
shall I not drink of the cup, etc. 4. It acknowledges the present course that
God takes to be best, and most behooful for us: For God is wisest, and his
prescriptions most safe and healthful: we have therefore no reason to be angry
unless we will fight against God.


3. It looks up to Christ, and imprints the virtues of his death upon the soul:
He that believes in Christ crucified, is made like unto Christ in love,
meekness, and all other graces that he manifested in his death. For it thus
pleads; Christ endured scoffs, reproaches, railings, revilings, buffetings,
scourgings, yea, and death it self: not for any demerit of his but for our
sakes; and shall we grudge to suffer small injuries from men at our Savior
Christ's request, seeing we have deserved far greater?

4. It submits to the absolute sovereignty of the Lord, and will not encroach
upon his Prerogative Royal: Now all revenge is Gods right, and he has not
given it to man, Romans 12.19. A private man in the Commonwealth may not usurp
the place of a Judge, nor a servant of a Master: much less may a Christian, by
revenging his own quarrel in word or deed, intrude himself into Gods office.

5. Faith works humility, and lowliness, and banisheth self-love, and pride:
For it minds a man of his sin, and the desert thereof: and that whatsoever good
he enjoys, he holds as an alms of grace; whatsoever he suffers, he
acknowledges less then his desert, and a just chastisement of love, and
therefore is patient.

6. It raises the heart to an earnest desire of spiritual things, and treads
under feet all vain and transitory things, and therefore a believer is not
much disquieted when he is crossed in them. As the upper region of the air is
not molested with wind, rain, hail, etc. so a heavenly minded Christian is
lifted up far above these sublunary things, and cannot be afflicted with them.

7. Faith begets soundness of spirit, and Christian hardiness: But a sound
mind is not easily disturbed with wrongs that are offered, no more then sound
flesh is when handled.

8. It seeks the approbation of God, but is not vainly inquisitive what others
think, or speak, or do; whereas he that basely enquireth what is said against
him in every company, disquiets himself with anger, and makes his faults more
public.

9. It acquaints us with the common frailties of all mankind; discovers the
filthiness of original sin which has infected all the sons of Adam: It puts
us in mind how often we have provoked God, and offended our brethren, the
remembrance whereof is a great curb to carnal anger, seeing we do many things
that need pardon both from God and man.

10. It kindles in us just indignation against our own sins, which restraines
carnal anger from breaking out against others: For he that is zealous against
his own sins, has no leisure to quarrel with others for petty wrongs and
injuries.

11. Faith proceeds with counsel and deliberation: It considers before it
judge, and judges before it proceed to execution: It defers to censure till
time has revealed the truth.

12. Faith works by love, which is of more force to restrain us from revenge,
then injury to provoke unto ange^: For love suffers long, yea, suffers all
things, 1 Corinthians. 13.4, 7. It makes us look upon him with whom we are angry as
a brother: To remember that we would have other men to forgive us when we wrong
them, and therefore we must do the like.

13. It Is the property of faith to receive the whole Word, and to diffuse the
saving virtue thereof into every power of the soul, which changes us in to the
nature of it self: But the Word requires meekness, long-suffering, and
patience: the Word is compared to leaven that leaveneth the whole lump.

14. Faith obtains of God by prayer the spirit of meekness whereby our
nature is renewed after the image of God; and our affections sanctified that
they may further Gods glory, the good of our brethren, and our own salvation.

15. It shows the danger of retaining anger which is a high degree of murder.
It shows that the promise of forgiveness is made only to them that forgive,
Matthew. 6. that judgment merciless belongs to them that show no mercy, James
2.13. that with what measure we mete it shall be measured to us, Mat. 18.23.

Quest. What further means may a Christian use to subdue anger?

Answ. First, shun all businesses above thy reach, least being oppressed with
an unsupportable burden, it makes thee froward and teasty.



Prove. 22.24, 25. As one stick kindles many.



Fifthly, take heed of meddling with the strife that belongs not to thee,
Proverbs 26.17. and 29.9.

Sixthly, look often upon the admirable examples of the patience of Gods
Abraham, Genesis 13.8. of Moses, Exodus 17.4, 11. of David, 2 Samuel 16.10. of
Stephen, Act. 7.60. especially of Christ himself, 1 Pet. 2.22.

Seventhly, look also upon the examples of such as have given themselves

Eighthly: fly jealousies and surmisings which fill us with choler as much as
just grounds: causing us to make a bad construction of a look, a smile, etc.
and so to

Ninthly, be not light in giving credit to reports, seeing the many practices

Tenthly, make the best construction of every thing: If the party that has

11. Remove the ocasions of anger: As Cotys King of Thrace, when one brought
him curious vessels, but brittle, he commended their rare workmanship,

Answ. First, yield not obedience to it: believe it not when it would provoke

Secondly, remember that it is a dishonest thing to revenge an injury, Prove.

Thirdly, do not multiply words which are the fuel of anger: we may as well

Fourthly, when angry, make some delay before thou speak, or do any

Sixthly, Remember that daily thou sinnest often against God; and therefore

Seventhly, consider whether thou purposest ever, or never to lay aside thy

Eighthly, Consider how much precious time thou spendest about a

Quest. How may we cure anger in others?

Answ. First, if thou live with those that be furious, the best way to win
them to kindness, is for thy self truly to repent of thy sins. For Prove. 16.7.
If a man's ways please the Lord, he will make his enemies to be at peace with
him, Isa. 11.6. etc. He makes the Wolf to feed with the Lamb, etc. the hearts
of men are in his hands, and he turns them as he pleases: as he did Esaus to
Jacob, Genesis 32.9. etc. and 33.4, 5. Remember his Promise, that if we humble our
selves, he will grant us compassion in the sight of them that hated us, 2 Chronicles. 30.9. 1 Kings 8.47, etc. 2 Chronicles. 7.11. etc. Solomon prays for it.

Prove. 26.21. and 30.33. Jam. 3.5, 6. As Cannon-shot loses its force if it
light on earth, or soft wool, but dasheth the stone-wall in pieces: so the
violence of anger is abated, when not resisted: but furiously rages when it
meets with opposition.

Prove. 15.1. and 25.15. Genesis 50.17. Jude 8.1. etc. as milk quenches wild
fire, and oil lime, so does a mild answer anger.

Abigail to David, 1 Samuel 25.24. But this must be done when the heat of anger
is somewhat assuaged, and with mildness and moderation, else it may provoke
more.

Jacobs case with Esau, Genesis 33.3, 4.

Saul's anger against David, 1 Samuel 24.17. and 26.21. Hence Prove. 25.21. If
thine enemy hunger, give him bread, etc. A great fire melts the hardest iron:
so said Jacob, Genesis 32.20. So Prove. 21.14.

Eccl. 1.3. and 10.4.

See Mr. Balls Power of Godliness; Dr. Tailor on Tit. Mr. Bolton, Mr. Rein^r,
and Dr. Harris.

Quest. How are vicious and virtuous anger differenced?

Answ. Chiefly in the object: the virtuous regards the interest of God, the
vicious the interest of a man's self; but both proceed from glory, and have
their motions for the vindication of glory: For a religious anger has for its
motive the glory of God: but the motive of vicious anger is a man's particular
glory, and the resenting of private contempt either true, or imagined. Hence
the proudest men are most choleric, for being great lovers of themselves, and
valuing themselves at a very high rate, they deem the smallest offenses against
them to be unpardonable crimes. But he that knows himself, and apprehends how
small a thing he is, will not think the offenses against him to be very great,
and therefore will not be much moved at them.

Quest. What other causes be there of sinful Anger?

Answ. First, weakness contributes much to it: For though a fit of anger look
like a sally of vigor and courage, yet its the effect of a soft spirit. Great
and strong spirits are patient, but a weak nature can suffer nothing. The wind
stirs leaves and small twigges, seldom the bodies of great trees.

Secondly, all things that make a man tender and wanton, make him also

Thirdly, anger is produced by giving way to the wandering of thoughts,
curiosity,

Fourthly, its sometimes stirred up by contrary causes, as by prosperity and
adversity,

Quest. What are the evil effects of it, the more to make us shun and hate it?

Answ. First, its dreadful, when assisted by power, like an impetuous storm,
that overthrows all that lies in its way: How often has it razed Cities,
ruined Theodosius, (the best of Emperors) slew many thousands of innocents
amongst the nocents in Thessalonica. How many have been massacred by wicked
Princes? and what slaughters would there be in the world, if mean fellows had
as much power as wrath?

Secondly, its dangerous to the angry man himself; for by the overflowing of
the gall, wrath overflows all the faculties of the mind, which discovers it
self

Thirdly, there is no cause so good, but its marred by impetuous anger: The

Fourthly, the wrong done to Piety or Justice, is no just reason for our
immoderate

To which end we must remember, that in the violation of Justice, God is more
interessed then we are, and knows how to punish it when he sees it expedient:
and if God will not punish as yet, our wills must not be more hasty then his,
and it becomes not us to be impatient for our own interest^, when himself is
patient in the wrong done to his own: Let the cause of our anger be never so
holy and just; yet that of James is a perpetual truth, chap. 1.20. The wrath of
man works not the righteousness of God. If it be the cause of God that we
