Answ. By the woeful experience of such as have either used unlawful callings,
as Thieves, Cheaters, Gamesters, Parasites, Stage Players, etc. Or else that
have lived without a calling, who besides that they are commonly unprofitable
Caterpillars, yea burthensom, and chargeable to others, they either grow
profane in their lives, or fall away from the truth of religion into damnable
sects, and erroneous doctrines.

Quest. How may we prove that diligent walking in our callings is so acceptable
to God?

Answ. Because as he that has no lawful calling, or that walks negligently
in one that is lawful, transgresses all the Commandments of the second Table,
thereby highly displeasing God, and pulling a curse upon himself: So he that
walks diligently in a lawful calling, keeps Gods Commandments, and so has a
promise of a blessing annexed to it, Lev. 20.26. Deuteronomy. 28.8. Prove. 10.4, 22.

Quest. Do all that walk painfully in a lawful calling please God?

Answ. No, except withal they observe these rules.

1. That such be true believers, without which its impossible to please God,
Heb. 11.6. and such as are careful daily to amend their lives.

2. They must follow their earthly businesses with heavenly minds: and see
that their worldly affairs do not justle out the seasonable performance of
holy duties: that so they may also thrive in grace, and be good husbands for
their souls.

3. That they so shun unnecessary meddling with other men's matters, that
withal they be not so shut up in their bowels, as to neglect their brethrens
causes, when duty and conscience calls for their asistance.

Quest. How is conscionable walking in our callings a furtherance to a godly
life.

Answ. Because therein we follow God in doing that which he requires at our
hands, and imitate the example of the godly that went before us, who have found
the benefit and comfort of it.

Practice of Christianity.

Quest. Why else must we have, and attend upon our particular callings?

Answ. First, God has commanded us to labor the six days, and to do all our
work, Exodus 20.9, 10.

Bezaleel, Exodus 31.2. etc. So Isa. 28.24. etc. and 54.16.

Genesis 3.19. 1 These. 4.11. and such as will not work, must not eat, 2 These.
3.10. etc. Its a character of a good woman, Prove. 31.27. Idelness is disorder,
2 These. 3.8.

Fourthly, The promise of plenty, comfort, and blessing is made to the
diligent, Prove. 10.4. and 13.4. and 12.27. Hence Psalm. 128.1, 2. Isa. 3.10. Mr.
Reyners Precepts.

Fifthly, Man is born to travel, and labor, Job. 5.7.

Quest. What else may move us to diligence in our particular callings?

Answ. Remember that God who has set us in our callings, has promised Prove.
28.19. and 10.4. See also, Jos. 1.8.

Secondly, whereas all other creatures live to themselves, man was appointed to
live to others as well as to himself; the Church, his Country, family, the

Thirdly, an honest calling is a School of Christianity. For,

1. As we send little children to School to keep them out of harms way, and
unhappy turns: so diligence in our callings fenceth us against Satan's
tentations: and it is a bridle to restrain our own lewd desires, abating wicked
lusts, abandoning loose commpany, and fitting us for the Lords coming, when we
are in his service.

2. Whilst in this School we perform duties for the Lords sake, we have daily
practice and increase of graces, such, as faith, obedience, patience,
meekness, constancy, truth, invocation, thanksgiving, and by experience of
Gods goodness for the time pas^, we are the better enabled to depend upon him
for the time to come.

3. In this School also we learn to be teachers of others, and to be patterns
to others of the right use of the world, whilst our selves use it daily, as
not using it: whilst we so play the good husbands, as that we keep our selves
from being worldlings: not laying aside our heavenly minds, whilst we are
about our worldly businesses.

Fourthly, consider the danger of those that stand idle all the day long,
passing Paul says, that such as live in pleasure are dead while they live:
They are out of Gods protection, never out of Satan's snares: their heart, like
the field of the sluggard, its overgrown with the nettles of lusts, etc. As
rust frets iron unused, and moths garments unworne, so good things are shaken
out of the hearts of idle persons; their souls are but as salt to keep their
bodies from stinking: It shall one day be said to them, Take that unprofitable
servant, etc. Mat. 25.30. Tailor on Titus.

Quest. May not a man change his particular calling if he dislike it, and like
another better?

Answ. Every one ought to continue constantly, and conscionably in his
particular calling; wherein their calling to grace did find them if it be
warrantable, and lawful, as we see, 1 Cor. 7.10. No comfortable change of a
calling can be made but in these cases.

1. Of private necessity, when a man is disenabled to follow it, or cannot get
a subsistence by it.

2. Or for the common good, and that truly so, not hypocritically pretended,
and for by-respects. If any man then upon the giving of his name to religion,
shall grow into neglect, distaste, or dereliction of his honest particular
calling, we may ever strongly suspect him of hollownesse, and hypocrisy: Hence
Mr. Perkins says, Though a man be endued with excellent gifts, and be able to
speak well, to conceive prayer, and with some reverence hear the Word, and
receive the Sacraments, yet if he practice not the duties of Godliness within
his own calling, all is but hypocrisy. See Boltons first Vol.

Quest. How may we live by faith in the exercise of our particular callings?

Answ. When considering that its Gods Ordinance that men should labor in some
honest vocation for their private maintenance, and the common good, we believe
the promises that he has made of protection, and blessing us therein. The
Texts of Scripture are plain for both, Genesis 2.15. and 3.19. Ephesians. 4.28. 1 Corinthians. 7.10. 1 These. 4.11, 12. 2 These. 3.10, 11, 12. Prove. 10.4. and 12.17.
and 13.11. and 12.24. and 22.29. Psalm 91.11.

Quest. Why is it necessary that we should live by faith in them?

Answ. To prevent the evils which beset us in our ordinary callings, as
covetousness, injustice, impatience and distracting care. Naturally men are
apt to incumber themselves with superfluous businesses, and trouble themselves
about the event and success: they content not themselves with their lot and
condition, but desire to heap up riches above measure: they forecast many
things in their heads long before, and know no end of their cares. The trouble
which we meet with in the world, begets love of the world, and whether it be
crossed or prosper, the more they be exercised about the things of this life,
the more they follow after them with greediness, vexation, discontent,
plotting how to compass their designs, whether by right or wrong, by fraud or
oppression. Now the Sovereigne remedy against these, and such other mischiefs
is a lively faith, which lifts up the heart to better things, quietly
submitting to the good pleasure of God, commending the success of all their
honest employments to his Highness, and resting upon his grace for present
help and future supply in the use of such means as he has ordained, Heb. 11.6.

Quest. What are the acts of faith in this particular?

Answ. First, it informs us to make choice of an honest calling for which we
are fitted, and into which we may enter by direct, good, and lawful means,
Prove. 16.20.

Prove. 3.5, 6. For if we do, either it shall not effect what we do intend, or
if we bring it to pass, yet it shall not succeed, or avail to those honest
uses which we intended, Psalm 127.1, 2. Hag. 1.6, 9. Eccl. 9.11.



Psalm. 128.2. Ephesians. 6.5, 6. Faith awakens the sluggard, rowseth the lazy, makes
the idle lay his bones to work, Prove. 31.13, 15. and him that was a purloiner
to deal truly, justly, and honestly.

Isa. 7.4. Jos. 7.5. Prove. 31.17. 2 Timothy 1.7, 8, 9. Heb. 11.7. Mark 6.18. Heb.
11.9, 10.

ill report, and good report, honor and disgrace, Heb. 11.35, 36, 37. 1 Cor.
4.3. 1 These. 2.6, 9. Phil. 3.7, 8. It directs us to order the affairs of our
callings wisely, and to go about them in a good manner, i. e. in obedience to
God, to right ends, and with an heavenly mind, exercising the graces that God
has bestowed on us, Eccl. 2.26. 1 Samuel 18.14.

Eighthly, it teaches to moderate our cares, confine desires of earthly things,
Psalm. 55.22. Mat. 6.32. 1 Pet. 5.7. Psalm. 127.^. Prove. 16.3.

Ninthly, it supporteth with strength patiently to bear the miseries, and Adam
we are subject unto, and works the soul to contentation in every estate,
Phil. 4.11, 12.

Tenthly, it restrains distrustful cares about the success of our labors,
but Phil. 4.6.

Eleventhly, if we find wished success, it makes us vigilant, frugal, humble,
Cor. 7.31. Prove. 21.25, 26. Psalm. 112.9.

Twelfthly, Faith coupleth the labors of our callings with the practice of
Christianity.

Quest. But how may we live by faith touching the success of our labors,
which we find too much above our strength or means?

Answ. First, faith in such cases causes self-denial in respect of our
judgment, Prove. 3.5. and 16.2. and 21.2. Jer. 10.23. Lam. 3.37.

Secondly, it teaches submission to Gods direction, and depends upon his Jude
1.1. and 20.18, 23, 28. Isa. 8.20. It chooses what God approves, though to
humane wisdom it seems bootlesse, and improbable. It trusts God for ability
to the work, provision of the means, the disposition of them, and the good
success to come by them, Mat. 6.25. and 10.19. Psalm. 32.8. Ezra. 5.5.

Thirdly, it brings forth industry and endeavor to serve Gods providence: He

Fourthly, it cannot be silent in such a case, but sends us to God by prayer,
Chron. 20.12. Psalm. 5.2, 3.

Fifthly, it puts life and hardiness in us to play the men, Judge. 5.8.

Sixthly, it waits upon God for good success, and triumphs before the
victory, Prove. 16.3.

Seventhly, its ready and forward to praise God for good success, Psa. 103.1,
2. Judge. 5.9, 10, 11. See Ball on Faith.

Quest. How many sorts of men transgress about their callings?

Answ. First, such as run into callings before God sends them. Many such
intruders

Secondly, such as live by such ways as God calls them from: as by usury,

Thirdly, such as do the work of their calling at an unlawful time: as on the

Fourthly, such as abide not in their Callings.

Fifthly, such as meddle with many callings: being called but to one.



Byfield on Peter.

Quest. What must we propose to our selves in following the duties of our
particular callings?

Answ. We must not make gain our end therein, as Heathens and Turks do, and all
that do so are servants and drudges to Mammon, but Christians ought to follow
their work, because God has so appointed, aiming also at the good of the
Church and Commonwealth, and our own gain must come in on the by, as it shall
please God to send it. We must follow our callings as a means God has
appointed to keep us from idleness, and to humble us thereby, and that we may
be instruments of the common good. Rogers on Pet.

Quest. What other Rules are to be observed in our particular callings?

Answ. First, that our calling be lawful and agreeable to Gods Will, and Word:
such an one as our labor in it may tend to Gods glory, and to the good of the
Church and Commonwealth, and the furthering, not only of our temporal, but our
spiritual good, and the eternal salvation of our souls.



Cor. 7.20, 24.



1. For our persons we must be regenerate, and sanctified: for our persons must
be accepted, before our works can please God, Tit. 1.15. To the pure all things
are pure, etc. All that a wicked man does is abominable, Prove. 21.27.4. neither
can such expect a blessing upon their labors, Ps. 1.3. and 112.1, 2, etc. and
128.1. Gods promise belongs only to the righteous as appears in those Texts. 2.
The duties of our callings must be performed in faith: as was showed before,
Heb. 11.6. Joh. 15.5. Romans 14.23.

2. They must proceed out of unfeigned love to God and our neighbors, which is
the fountain of all true obedience, and not principally from self-love, and
love of the world: the love of God will move us to consecrate our lives, and
labors wholly unto him, and love unto our neighbors will make us to seek
their good as well as our own, 1 Cor. 13.5. Gal. 5.13.

3. They must be directed to right ends: As 1. Principally to Gods glory, which
we should advance in every thing, 1 Cor. 10.31. 2. The good of the Church and
Commonwealth, which we should prefer before our private good. 3. So to aim at
our own profit, as that we join there with the welfare, and benefit of our
neighbors, and not raise our gain out of their losses.


4. Our care must be to perform the duties of our callings after a right
manner: For which end we must, first follow our earthly businesses with
heavenly minds, and affections; as Citizens of Heaven, and pilgrims on earth,
longing after the joys of our own country, Phil. 3.20. Coll. 3.1, 2.
especially in the midst of our ordinary businesses, we should often lift up our
hearts to God, craving his blessing in, and giving him praise at the end of our
work, not forgetting Christ's Counsel, Mat. 6.33. Secondly, we must sanctify
them by the Word and prayer: The first is done when we labor to see our
warrant out of Scripture for all we do: doing all things both for substance and
manner as Gods Word requires and directs: The second is done when by prayer
we desire Gods blessing upon all our labors, and return him thanks when we
have obtained it, Col. 3.17. For its Gods blessing only that makes rich, Prove.
10.22. Deuteronomy. 8.13.18. He gives, and he takes away, Job 1.21. 1 Samuel 2.8. Psalm.
113.7. Abraham and Lot by Gods blessing waxed rich, Genesis 13.5, 6. and Isaac,
Genesis 26.3.12. and Jacob, Genesis 32.10. without which all our labor is in vain,
Psalm. 127.1, 2. God will blow upon it, Hag. 1.6, 9.

5. There are sundry virtues to be exercised in the right and religious
performance of the duties of our callings: As,

(1) Knowledge, and judgment, whereby we are enabled to discern between good,
and evil, right, and wrong, without which we walk in darkness, and shall be
apt to commit many errors.

(2) Affiance in God, whereby we cast our selves upon his promise, and
providence in the use of lawful means: as Psalm. 37.5. Commit thy way to the
Lord, trust in him, and he shall bring it to pass. For which end remember
that* God takes care of the fowls, clothes the lilies, Mat. 6.25, 28.

(3) Get and use a good conscience both toward God and man, as Paul, Act.
24.16. Heb. 13.18. this willl keep us from all secret sins, and crafty
conveyances, whereby we are naturally apt to wrong our neighbors for our
private advantage.

(4) We must get contentation, being in all things contented with Gods good
pleasure, judging that condition best wherein he has placed us, indifferently
welcoming poverty, or riches, prosperity or adversity, gain or loss, because
they are sent of God, Phil. 4.12. If we get this, we shall not be discontented
with the baseness of our callings, nor envy others their great preferments,
their less labor, and more gains, etc. It will also keep us from base
covetousness, knowing that godliness is the greatest gain, 1 Timothy 6.6. Hence,
Heb. 13.5.

(5) We must possess our souls with patience, which we have need to do,
considering that we are daily subject to many crosses, and miscarriages which
would otherwise discourage us from going on.

(6) We must have our hearts replenished with thankfulness to God being always
ready, when we observe his love in blessing our labors, to render him the
praise of all, Gen, 32.10. Not sacrificing to our own nets, as Hab. 1.16. But
seeing all comes from God, to return all praise to God, 1 Cor. 4.7.

(7) We must perform the duties of our calling with alacrity, and
cheerfulness, doing it heartily as to the Lord, Col. 3.23, 24. who will reward
our labors with an heavenly inheritance: and this will make all our labors
more easy, and to be more acceptable to God.

(8) We must observe justice in all the duties of our callings, doing nothing
in them but what may advance our neighbors good as well as our own, 1 These.
4.6. dealing with others as we would that they should deal with us.

Mr. Downams Guide to Godliness.

CHAP. XXIV. Questions, and Cases of Conscience about our holy Calling, or
Vocation.
Quest. OF how many sorts is the Calling of God?

Answ. First, the particular calling, which is to serve Heb. 5.4. Romans 1.11.

Secondly, the general calling which is to serve God

Quest. Of how many sorts is this general Calling?

A^sw. 1. External. 2. Internal. 3. Both external and internal.

Quest. What is the external Calling?

Answ. Its the work of Gods grace in his Word offering Christ, and calling upon
all sorts of men to reform their ways, and to receive Christ, and to yield
obedience to the Will of God, with promise of salvation if they obey.

Quest. What is the inward calling?

Answ. Its the action of God both by his Word and Spirit, calling out his Elect
by name particularly, and persuading them to separate from the world, and
receive the Covenant of Gods grace in Christ, and to devote themselves to
holiness of life.

Quest. Why is our conversion termed our calling?

Answ. First, because the means whereby God works upon us, ordinarily

Secondly, because through the mighty working of the Spirit of Christ, the

Thirdly, because God would hereby note unto us the easiness of the work, he

Quest. But how may our effectual calling be discerned, seeing wicked men may
be affected with the Word?

Answ. It may be discerned by the effects of it, whereof some appear
immediately, other some a longer time after.

Quest. What are those effects?

Answ. First, a true sight of, and willing confession of our sinne-guiltinesse,
joined with a detestation of all sin, and dislike of our ways which are not
good.





Romans 8.28.

Joel 2.32.



Quest. Wherein does Gods wonderful mercy appear in our calling?

Answ. By the consideration of the things whereunto we are called, which are,
1. To his mavelous light, 1 Pet. 2.9. 2. To the fellowship of his Son Jesus
Christ, 1 Cor. 1.9. 3. To a wonderful liberty from the servitude of sin, Satan,
the world, and the ceremonial Law, Gal. 5.13. 4. To the grace of Christ, Gal.
1.6. 5. To an estate of immunity, and free pardon, Romans 5.31. 6. To all safety,
Isa. 41.1, 2, 3. Romans 8.28. 7. To Christ's glorious Kingdom, 2 These. 2.14. 1
These. 2.12. 2 Pet. 1.3. 1 Pet. 5.10.


Quest. How may we walk worthy of our calling?

Answ. First, if we be humble, and not wise in our own conceits, Romans 11.25,
30, 31.



1. Because its no common favor, but a special grace bestowed upon us: For no
man comes to Christ, but whom the Father draws, Joh. 6.44.

2. God has done it without respect to our works, or desert on our part, 2 Timothy 1.9.

3. Because of the means, and manner of our calling: all the three persons of
the Trinity concur in it, and its an holy calling, 2 Timothy 1.9.

4. Because of the privileges to which we are called: as to be sons, and
heirs with Christ, 1 Cor. 1.7. to a Kingdom and glory, 1 These. 2.12. 2 These.
2.14.

5. Because Gods gifts and calling are without repentance, Romans 11.29. Isa. ^4.
7, etc. Jam. 1.17.

Tit. 3.8. Its the end of our calling, Luke 1.74, 75.

Isa. 29.23, 24.

Ephesians. 4.11, etc.

Quest. Why should we be so solicitous to know our calling?

Answ. First, because it instates us into all the promises of God.

Acts 15.9.

Ephesians. 6.16. Heb. 10.19, 20, 22. 1 John 5.4, 5.

Fourthly, it puts life into all our duties, both of Religion and
Righteousness, Gal. 5.6.

Fifthly, it opens a spring of grace in our hearts, John 7.38.

Mr. Byfield on Peter.

Quest. Does a Christian always know that he is called?

Answ. Sometimes a Christian staggers a little, either not being an experienced
Christian, or through sight of corruptions and tentations: but setting these
aside, a Christian knows his calling, and will live by his Rules: for its not
only a calling, but it works a disposition: and therefore if we find it not,
we must attend upon the means of the Gospel, which is called the Kingdom of
Heav^n, and it will bring us into a good estate, and show us our estate also,
which being once made known to us, we may assure our selves it will remain with
us for ever; which also may be gathered from this, in that its an high calling,
and nothing can break any one link of that chain made by God, Romans 8. 29,
30.

Dr. Sibbs on Phil.

Quest. How may it be proved that a Christian may certainly know his vocation
or calling?

Answ. First, because its the Office of the Spirit of God, which the faithful
have received to certify them of those things, which God has freely bestowed
Cor. 2.12 Romans 8.15.

Secondly, Gods children are commanded to make their calling and election sure,
2 Pet. 1.10. neither is this a legal, but an Evangelical Precept.

Thirdly, the grace which they have received of God, has the nature and force
of an earnest, in respect of the inheritance that is promised them, Ephesians.

Fourthly, the certain knowledge of the grace of God bestowed upon us, is Pet.
1.6, 8.

Fifthly, a conscience purified from dead works, does necessarily infer a
certain Heb. 10.20. Romans 8.26. and 9.2.

Sixthly, this is expressly affirmed of the faithful, and that from such reasons
Cor. 13.5. 1 John 3.14. and 4* 16. and 5.20.

Quest. By what signs may this certainty of our vocation be confirmed to us?

Answ. First, By the constant inclination of our wills to God as to our
chiefest Psalm 119.57. For no man can place his chiefest happiness in the
fruition of God, except he be called out of the world, and converted from the
Idols which he had formerly set up in his heart.

Secondly, by a purpose and readiness of mind to hearken to God in all things,
Sam. 3.10. Act. 9.6. Psa. 40.8, 9. For hereby we answer to the Call of God.
Psa. 26.7, 8.

Thirdly, By an earnest longing after the Word of God, 1 Pet. 2.2. for by this
Word Pet. 1.23.

Fourthly, By our sincere love to them who are begotten to God by the same Joh.
3.41.

Quest What means are we to use that we way be made partakers of this holy
calling?

Ans. Though God is many times found of those that sought him not, yet there
are several duties to be performed by us ordinarily, if we will be made
partakers of this heavenly calling: as.

1. We must prize Gods word above all earthly treasures, Psa. 119.14. For none
will seek the Kingdom of God till he under-valew all things in comparison of
it Mat. 10.37. Luke 14.26.

2. We must bestow our principal care, and labor in the attaining of it, Joh.
6.27. Pro. 2.4. and 8.17. the reason is because that esteem can never be solid,
and serious, which has not endeavors added to it.

3. We must with all diligence, and care apply our selves to the use of those
means which God has sanctified to communicate his grace to us by, Pro. 1.34.
we must wait, as the impotent did at the pool of Bethesda, Joh. 5.3, 4, 7. and
the reason is, because God who is the author of grace, has appointed, and
makes effectual those means, whereby he will convey his grace to us.

4. Yea, we must set such a rate upon them that we must be content to sell all
to purchase this pearl, Pro. 23.23. Mat. 13.43, 45. For though God requires
nothing of us, but freely bestows life upon us, Isa. 45.1.2. yet we ought to
forsake all unlawful things in act, and all natural good things in affection,
and disposition, that we may get the grace of God.

Quest. What Motives may stir us up to embrace the calling of God?

Answ. First, If we seriously consider who it is that calls us, Its the
omnipotent God, to whom we are bound to hearken in all things, though we Know
not what will follow Heb. 11.8.

Pet. 5.10. Ephesians. 1.13.

Act. 26.18. Luke 3.7.

Romans 8.10. 2. Cor. 5.20. and truly we are desperately hardened if such
goodness will not work upon us, as, 1 Samuel 24.17, 18, 19.

Cor. 1.26.

Mat. 22.7, 8. Luke 4.24.

Pro. 1.24. etc.

Ames. Cas. Consc.

Quest, How else may our vocation, or calling be described?

Answ. Its an effect of Gods election, whereby Christ, God and man, does by his
Kingly authority call, and invite us whilst we live here unto the participation
of the inestimable benefit of our Redemption, that thereby we may attain unto
life everlasting.

Quest. How manifold is this calling?

Answ. 1. Its twofold. 1. Common and general, whereby all indifferently, good
and bad, elect and reprobate, are outwardly invited by the Ministry of the Word
to embrace the benefit of Redemption wrought by Christ: This is ineffectual to
reprobates, because they refuse to come, when invited to the Kings Supper, Luke
14.24.

follows that near union whereby we being ingrafted into his body, mystically
do become his members, and he our head, Mat. 22.3, 8. Romans 8.30. Act. 13.48.
Joh. 6.45. Act. 16.14.

Quest. What are the parts of our effectual calling?

Answ. First. Our separation from the world, of which formerly we were true
Joh. 15.19. Ephesians. 2.19. and this he does, not for any merit of ours, but of his
free grace, Jsa. 65.1. Ephe. 2.1.3.12. 1 Cor. 6.11. 1 Pet. 4.3. Isa. 53.6. 2 Timothy 1.9.

Secondly, that reciprocal donation, whereby God the Father gives Christ, Isa.
9.6. John 3.16. Romans 8.32. John 17.6. and 10.29.

Thirdly, the union and communion which is betwixt Christ and Gods Elect, Ephesians.
4.15, 16. and 5.30. John 15.1. Ephesians. 2.20, 21, 22. 1 John 4.13. John 6.54.

Quest. What is the means of our effectual calling?

Answ. First, on Gods part, the preaching of the Word, which is made effectual

Secondly, the means on our part, is the saving hearing of the Word,

Quest. What necessity is there of our effectual calling?

Answ. First, before our effectual calling, we are no true members of the Ephesians.
5.23, 25. Acts 2.47.

Secondly, if we be not truly called, we are not truly justified, nor
sanctified, Romans 8.30.

Thirdly, if we be not thus called, we cannot come to Christ, nor communicate

Quest. But why should we be so careful in attending upon the Word.

Answ. First, because the Ministry of the Word is Gods Ordinance, instituted
Ephesians. 4.11, 12. neither does he ordinarily use any other means for our Calling
and Conversion. Hence Philip was sent to the Eunuch, Acts 8. Ananias to Paul,
Acts 9. Peter to Cornelius, Acts 10.5, 6.

Secondly, its God himself, who speaks by the mouths of his Ambassadors, Cor.
5.20. and 4.7. Jerem. 1.9. Luke 10.16.

Thirdly, the titles which are given to the Word, may strongly move us to
attend upon the same. Its called the Ministry of reconciliation, 2 Cor. 5.18.
the Gospel of Peace, Ephesians. 6.15. the Word of grace, Acts 14.3.18.32. the Word of
Life, Phil. 2.16. Acts 13.26. the Word of salvation: the Kingdom of God, Mat.
13.44. by which we are brought into the Kingdom of grace and glory. Heavenly
seed, 1 Cor. 4.15. whence Ministers are called spiritual Fathers, 1 Cor. 3.2.
Its milk for Babes, and strong meat for men, Heb. 5.12. Its a rule for our
lives, Deuteronomy. 5.32. Jos. 1.8. A Lamp to our feet, etc. Psalm. 119.105. the Sword
of the Spirit, Ephesians. 6.17.

Luke 1.79. Mat. 5.14. Acts 13.47.

Ephesians. 2.8. Heb. 11.6. John 1.12. and 3.16, 18. Romans 10.17. 1 Timothy 4.16.

Quest. But if once we be converted, what need we hear so often?

Ans. First, neglect of Gods Word is a manifest sign that we are not truly
converted, John 8.47. and 10.3, 4, 27. they which have grace cannot but be
ravished with the excellency of the Word.

Amos 8.11, 12.

to teach, to reprove, etc. that the man of God may be perfect, etc. 2 Timothy
3.16. 2 Cor. 14.3. therefore with David, we should desire to dwell in the house
of God, Psalm. 27.4.

Mr. Downhams Christian Warfare.

Quest. Whether is not our Vocation or Calling all one with our Sanctification?

Answ. No: For 1. Our Vocation is before Justification, Romans 8.30. but
Sanctification is not before Justification: therefore they are not the same.

These. 4.7. therefore its not all one with it.

Jer. 3.22. Now faith is no part of Sanctification strictly taken, because its
the means and instrument of our Justification and Sanctification, Acts 26.18.
Hence our hearts are said to be purified by faith, Acts 15.9. Gal. 2.20. John
5.24. we pass from death to life by faith, therefore its no part of our
spiritual life, as faith comes by hearing, and therefore hearing is no part of
Faith: so Justification comes by Faith, and therefore its no part of
Sanctification.

Quest. What is the nature of the Call of God?

Answ. Concerning this Call, I shall lay down these Propositions.



John 20.31. 1 Cor. 1.21. with 26. The Spirit indeed inwardly accompanies the
voice of the Gospel, but now none are called by the immediate voice of the
Spirit without the Gospel, or by the immediate testimony of the Spirit,
breathed out of free grace without the Word, Ephesians. 1.12, 13.

Thirdly, this voice of the Gospel, is the voice of God in Christ, or the Romans
1.6. John 5.29. 2 These. 2.12, 13. Its called Christ's Call, Heb. 3.1. because
Christ takes (as it were) the written Word in his own lips, and thereby pierces
through the ears to the heart, through all the noise of fears, sorrows,
objections against believing, and makes it to be heard as his voice.

Fourthly, the thing that Christ calls us unto, is, to come to him: Christ will
Mat. 11.27. Jer. 3.7, 22. and 4.1. He calls for us to come and possess his
fullness, Luke 14.17. 1 Cor. 1.9.

Fifthly, this Call to Come, is all one for substance with the offer of Christ,

1. A Command to receive Christ, as present and ready to be given, 1 John
4.23. 2. Persuasion and entreaty, to come and accept of this offer, 2 Corinthians.
5.19, 20. 3. A Promise of the thing offered if we will receive it.
Sixthly, this Call or Offer has three special qualifications.

1. Its inward as well as outward: For thousands are outwardly called, which
yet never come, because they want the inward Call, John 6.45. He that has
heard and learned of the Father comes to me, Hos. 2.14.

2. Its a particular Call, Mar. 16.15. there is a general Call, and offer of
grace to every one: but when the Spirit applies generals to particulars
particularly, this makes the Call particular, Isa. 43.1. John 12.5.

3. Its effectual as well as inward and particular, Luke 24.23. Compel them to
come in, John 10.16. Its a calling out of purpose, Romans 8.28. Mat. 9.12, 13. 2 Chronicles. 30.10, 11.

Quest. Wherein does the necessity of this Call appear?

Answ. First, no man should come unless first called. For what has any

Secondly, no man would come without the Lords Call, Mat. 20.6, 7. No man has
hired, or called us. There must be an effectual Call to bring men home, Isa.
55.5.

3. No man could come unless called, John 6.44. unless the Father draw by
this Call. For Romans 11.32. we are shut up under belief.

Quest. How is this Call a ground of faith?

Answ. First, its the ground by which, or wherefore it rests upon the Promise:

Secondly, the fullness and plenteous riches of mercy, and this gives great
encouragement Psalm. 130.7, 8.

Thirdly, the preciousnesse and sweetness of mercy, makes the soul exceedingly
Psalm. 36.6, 7. and to disesteem all things to enjoy it: But when to all this,
God sends a special command to come in, and to take mercy, and that for no
other reason, but because its commanded, this puts an end to all fears and
discouragements, and the soul answers, as Jer. 3.22. Behold, we come, etc.

Mr. Shepherds Sound Believer.

Quest. What are the parts of inward Calling?

Answ. First, the enlightening the mind to understand the principles of
Reprobate, yet its the foundation of the rest, without which there is no
effectual Calling.

Lydia's was,) when we believe every thing particularly to belong to us, and so
the Promise of salvation amongst the rest.



Quest. What are the fruits of this effectual Calling?

Answ. First, when a man goes about the works of the same, and labors to walk
worthy of it in an holy life.

Paul accounted all but dung in comparison of the knowledge of Christ
crucified: and the things which he highly esteemed before his Calling,
afterward he made no reckoning of them.



Quest. What are the marks of effectual Calling?

Answ. They are either Negative, or Affirmative. First, Negative. As 1. Not to
hear the Word, and that diligently. 2. Nor to hear joyfully. 3. Nor to reform
many things, as Herod. 4. Nor to do some choice duties: as Ananias and Saphira.
Secondly, Affirmative.


1. To seek above all to be at peace with God, and to have his Spirit to assure
us of everlasting salvation: not to serve the times, but above all to be
assured of Gods favor.

2. That we hate unfeignedly all evil: but especially the evils of the times,
and of our natures.

3. To affect heartily all good: but especially those good things which the
world and times disregard, and that our selves are most untoward unto.

Mr. Rogers on Pet.

Quest. What other signs are there of our effectual Calling?

Answ. First, if we be effectually called, it supposes that we are chosen, and
singled out from others in the world: and whom God calls he qualifies: when he
called Saul to be King, he gave him a Kingly heart: so if God call us to his
heavenly Kingdom, he will give us holy, Kingly, and heavenly hearts and minds.

Nehemiah, Shall such a man as I do thus? speak thus? think thus?

David, What is man that thou should be mindful of him?

Thou art my son, the heart answers, Thou art my God. Behold I come quickly,
(says Christ,) Even so come Lord Jesus, says thy heart.



Dr. Sibbs on Phil.

CHAP. XXV. Questions, and Cases of Conscience about Cares of the World,
Quest. HOw many-fold are the Cares of the World?

Answ. Twofold. 1. Regular. 2. Irregular.

First, Care is then regular. 1. When it has a

Secondly, when the means of procuring that Romans 3.8. Contrary in Ahaziah, 2
Kings 1.2. Yea, Saint Austine is peremptory, that if it were possible by an
officious lie to compass the redemption of the whole world, yet so weighty and
universal a good must rather be let fall then brought about by the smallest
evil.

Thirdly, when the manner of doing it is good, and that is

1. When the care is moderate, Phil. 4.5, 6.

2. When it is with submission to the will and wisdom of God, when with David,
we can resolve not to torment our hearts with needless and endless projects,
but to roll our selves upon Gods protection, 2 Samuel 15.25, 26. So 1 Samuel 3.18.
Act. 21.12, 14. Contrary, 2 King. 6.33. and in this respect care is not a
vexation but a duty, 1 These. 5.8. Prove. 6.8. Care irregular is a cutting,
dividing, distracting care, against which we should strive for these reasons.

First, irregular cares are superfluous, and improper to the ends which we
direct (Happiness) which men, laboring to find in the creature where it is
not, do instead there of find nothing but trouble, and vexation: But even to
those lower ends which the creatures are proper and suitable to. For to us
properly belongs the industry, and to God the care: unto us the labor, and use
of the means, but to God the blessing and success of all, 1 Cor. 3.6. Luke
12.25. 1 Pet. 5.7. Psalm 55.22. Matthew. 6.32. we should therefore learn to
cast our selves upon God; and that

1. In faith depending upon the truth of his promises, Heb. 13.5. as Dan. 3.17.
2 Samuel 30.6. 2 Chronicles. 14.11, 12. and 16.9. the contrary grieves God, Numb.
14.11. Ps. 78.19, 20. and 106.24. and it proceeds from this, that we measure
God by our selves: that we conceive of his power only by those issues and
ways of escape, which we are by our own wisdoms able to forecast: and when we
are so straightened that we can see no way to turn, there we give over trusting
God, as if our sins were greater then could be forgiven, o^ our afflictions
then could be removed: the best way therefore to establish our hearts in all
estates, is to have the eye of Faith fixed upon Gods power, and to consider
what he says, Isa. 55.8, 12. So Hab. 3.3, 18. Zach. 4.6, 10. Hos. 11.9. 2 Chronicles. 20.6, 1^. Ezekiel. 37.3.

2. By prayer, which is a maine remedy against careful thoughts, Phil. 4.5, 6,
7. so we see in Hannah, 1 Samuel 1.7, 10, 18. So, 1 Chronicles. 29.9. Deuteronomy. 12.1^. and
28.47. Mal. 2.13. Isa. 38.14, 20. Hab. 3.2, 16, 18, 19.



1. In regard of their object, they are worldly cares, the cares of the men of
this world: therein we declare our selves to walk as the Gentiles, as if we had
no better a foundation of Contentment then the Heathen which know not God:
Hence, Ephesians. 4.17. Mat. 6.32. whereas we are taken out of the world, and
therefore must not be conformable to the world, nor bring forth the fruits of a
wordly spirit; but walk as a peculiar people that have heavenly promises, and
the grace of God to establish our hearts, Joh. 15.10. 1 Cor. 2.10. Romans 12.2.
Psalm. 4.3. Tit. 2.14. 1 Pet. 2.9. Illi terrena sapiant, qui promissa coelestia
non habent. Cyprian.

2. They are sinful in regard of their causes, which are principally two.

1. Inordinate lust, or coveting, the running of the heart after covetousness.
2. Distrust of Gods providence; for those desires which spring from lust, can
never have faith to secure the heart in the expectation of them, Jam. 4.3.
3. They are sinful (...) their effects. For, 1. They are murdering cares, 2
Cor. 7.10. they work sadness, suspicions, uncomfortablenesse, and at last
death. 2. They are choking cares, Mat. 13.22. they take off the heart from the
Word, and thereby make it unfruitful. 3. They are adulterous cares, Jam. 4.4.
they steal away the heart from God, and set us at enmity against him.


Quest. How may we arm our selves against them?

Answ. First make the creature no vexing creature: For which end

1. Pray for convenience: for that which is suitable to thy mind, not to thy
lusts, but to the abilities of thy mind. Labor ever to suit thy occasions to
thy parts, and thy supplies to thy occasions. A ship, out of greediness,
overladen with gold, will be in danger of sinking, though the capacity of the
sides be not a quarter filled: on the other side, fill it to the brim with
feathers, and it will still toss up and down for want of ballasting: so is it
in the lives of men, some have such greedy desires that they think they can run
through all sort^ of businesses, and so never leave loading themselves till
their hearts sink and be swallowed up of worldly sorrow and security in sin:
Others set their affections on such trivial things, that though they should
have the fill of their desires, their minds would still be as floating, and
unsettled as before: therefore if thou live in the calmest times, 1. Fill not
thy self only with light things, and such are all things in this world of
themselves: but get thy heart ballasted with faith in Gods promises, love, and
fear of his name, a foundation of good works, and then whatever becomes of thy
other loading, thy ship it self shall be safe at last: thou shall be sure in
the greatest tempest to have thy life for a prey. 2. Consider the burden of thy
vessel; as all ships are not of equal capacity, so all men have not the same
abilities: some have such a measure of grace as enables them with much wisdom,
and improvement to manage such an estate, as would puff up another with pride,
sensuality, superciliousnesse, and forgetfulness of God: Some again are fitted
to some kind of employments, not so to others, and in these varieties of state
every man should pray for that which is most suitable to his disposition and
abilities, which may expose him to fewest tentations, or at least make him most
serviceable in the body of Christ, and bring most glory to his Master. Hence,
Prove. 30.8, 9. Mat. 6.11. Give us our daily bread.


2. Labor to get Christ into thy ship: he will check every tempest, and calm
every vexation that grows upon thee. When thou considerest that his truth and
person, and honor is embarked in the same vessel with thee, thou may assure
thy self that either he will be thy Pilot in the ship, or thy plank in the sea
to carry thee safe to land. Say, if I suffer in his company, and as his member,
he suffers with me, and then I may triumph that I am any way made conformable
to Christ my head. If I am weak in body, Christ my head was wounded: If weak in
mind, Christ my Head was heavy unto death: if I suffer in my estate, Christ
my head was poor: If in my name, he was called Beelzebub, 2 Cor. 8.9. Mat.
12.24. Again, have I a great estate? this takes away all the vexation that I
have Christ with me: his promise to sanctify it, his wisdom to manage it, his
Glory by it to be advanced, his Word by it to be maintained: his Anointed ones
by it to be supplied: his Church to be by it repaired: in one word, his poverty
to be by it relieved.

3. Cast out thy Jonah, every sleeping, and secure sin that brings a tempest on
thy ship, and vexation to thy spirit. Examine thy self impartially, and when
thou have found it out, though thy choicest pleasure, or chiefest profit, yet
cast it out in an humble confession unto God, in an hearty and willing
restitution to men, in opening thy close and contracted bowels to those that
never yet enjoyed comfort from them, then shall quietness arise to thy soul,
etc.

4. To remove the vexation of the creature, keep it from thy spirit, suffer it
not to take up thy thoughts and inward man: These things are not thy business,
but thy accessories, and a man's heart should be on the first, not on the
latter, Psalm. 62.10. when the creature has raised a tempest of vexation in
your souls, pour out your corruptions by confession, abate your lusts, and the
provisions of them, live by faith, and say; It Is the Lord, let him do what
seems good to him: The Lord gives, the Lord takes, Blessed be his Name.

Thirdly, use the creatures as vexing things: For which end

1. Let not earthly things bear rule over thy affections, least they emasculate

2. Be armed when thou touchest or medlest with them. Armed against the lusts,
and against the tentations that arise from them. Get faith to place thy heart
upon better promises: enter not upon them without prayer to God, that since
thou art going amongst snares, he would carry thee through with wisdom and
faithfulness, and teach thee how to use them as his blessings, and as
instruments of his glory. Make a Covenant with thy heart, be jealous of it
least it be surprised, or bewitched with sinful affections.

3. Touch them gently: Do not hug them, love, and dote upon them, nor grasp
them with adulterous embraces: The love of money is the root of mischief, and
is enmity against God, 1 Timothy 6.10. Jam. 4.4. 1 John 2.15.

3. Use them for hedges and fences to relieve the Saints, to make friends of
unrighteous Mammon, and to defend the Church of Christ. By no means have them
in thy field, but only about it: mingle it not with thy corn, lest it choke all.

5. Use them as Gideon, for weapons of just revenge against the enemies of Gods
Church to vindicate his truth and glory; and then by being wise and faithful in
a little, thou shall be ruler over much, etc. See Dr. Reynolds.

Object: But I should not take so much care were it not for my children?

Answ. Paul says, 1 Cor. 7.29. Let those that are married, be as though they
were not: meaning in regard of this scraping of wealth together by unlawful
means, or in regard of readiness to do works of mercy. God has promised to be
a Father of the fatherless. Some go to Hell themselves to make their children
rich: but God requires no such thing at our hand: Therere is a moderate care
indeed, as 1 Timothy 4.8. He that cares not for his own, etc. but we must not make
this a pretense to excuse our sinful and immoderate cares: what ability the
creature has to help, is from God, and when the creature is taken away, God is
where he was. Dr. Sibs.

Quest. Why ought we not to be careful about worldy things?

Answ. First, because these things are good in a very mean degree; they cannot
breed Contentment, nor make a man happy.





Indeed we must have callings, and we must be painful in them: So Adam had
before and after his fall: As Solomon commends diligence, so he speaks against
idleness, Prove. 10.4. He sends the sluggard to the Ant for forecast, Prove.
6.6. Joseph in times of plenty laid up for times of want, Genesis 41.48. therefore
it is not the care, but the excess that is forbidden.

Mr. Rogers on Pet.

CHAP. XXVI. Questions, and Cases of Conscience about Charity.
Quest. WHat is Charity?

Answ. It Is that affection of love which moves us to hold our neighbors dear,
and to desire, and seek their good in every thing which is dear unto them, and
that for Christ's sake, according to the will of God, 1 Cor. 13.4, etc. where we
have the properties of charity largly described; and it must be showed by
beneficence.

Quest. What is beneficence?

Answ. It is with a bountiful heart, and hand to do good to all, who in any
kind whatsoever need our help, by our riches, labor, care, counsel,
providence, or howsoever: So that it extends it self to all good works, as
building of Schools, and Colleges, maintaining the Ministry, and Gods worship,
erecting of Hospitals, allowing yearly Pensions to Parishes, and corporations
for relief of the poor: Or if we want ability to do these, then by counselling
those that want it, by being eyes and feet to the blind and lame, Act. 9.39.
Job 31.16, etc.

Quest. Are these duties then required of all?

Answ. Yea, Heb. 13.16. they are numbered amongst the fruits of the Spirit, Gal.
5.22. and are joined with love and faith, 1 Timothy 6.17, 18.

Quest. Who are the object of beneficence?

Answ. First, all men, 1 These. 5.15. yea, it must extend to our enemies, Prove.
Mat. 5.44, 45. Luke 6.32, 33.

Secondly, yet chiefly to the household of faith; Gal. 6.10. Christ Matthew.
25.33. So David, Psalm. 16.3. Ephesians, c. 1.15.

Quest. What are the properties of benificence?

Answ. First, it must be liberal and bountiful: Da multum multis. we must do
good to many; as we sow our seed plentifully, 2 Cor. 9.6. Prove. 11.24, 25. Non
qui habet, and servat, sed qui impertit est dives, and impertio, non possessio
divites facit. Clem. Alex. Not he that has wealth, and keeps it, but he that
bestows it is rich, etc. otherwise he puts it into a broken bag, Hag. 1.6. Its
a duty required by God, Deuteronomy. 15.11. Job 31.16, 17.

Eccl. 9.10. Tit. 3.1. 2 Cor. 9.7. Romans 12.8. Prove. 11.25. 2 Cor. 8.12. Deuteronomy.
15.10.

Quest. How does this cheerfulness show it self?

Answ. First in countenance, which adds a grace to a good deed. Dat been, dat
multum, qui dat cum munere vultum. Where the eye of the giver tells the
receiver that its a token sent him from a loving heart, Prove. 22.9.

Secondly, In our words, when we speak comfortably to the party to whom we do
good. Quando adjicimus bona verba, bonis rebus, 2 Cor. 9.5.

Thirdly, in the action. (1) When a man does good speedily and readily.
Beneficentia est virtus quae moram non patitur. It dislikes all delays: Omnis
benignitas properat. Seneca. All goodness is quick of hand, and swift of foot.
Bis dat qui cito dat. Et qui moratur, neganti proximus est. He that delays a
benefit is next door to him that denies. Proprium est libenter facientis cito
facere. S^n. Its the property of him that gives willingly to give speedily,
Isa. 21.14. We must prevent men's suits with such a readiness, as God does,
Psalm. 21.2, 3. Nam illud beneficium jucundum, quod obviam venit. Sen. that
benefit is most delightful to the receiver, which stays not till he comes to
seek it, but meets him in the midst way, 2 Cor. 8.4.

(2) When at least we entertain the first motion; and if our benefit has not
found him out before he sued, yet at least let him find it when he sueth.
Atque etiam dum rogat, erogemus: Let us give him while he asks. Nam qui tarde
dedit, diu noluit. Sen. So Prove. 3.27. and 13.12. especially we must avoid
delays in giving, after we have granted the suit: For there is nothing more
distastful, then when we are forced to ask again, and find more difficulty in
the delivery then in the grant.

Benefacta benefactis pertegentes. Plaut. making one good deed an introduction
to another: Hence, 2 These. 3.13. 1 These. 5.15. 1 Cor. 15.58. Deuteronomy. 15.11. Gal.
6.9. hereby we imitate our heavenly Father; Yea, we must increase in doing good
that our last works may excel the first, as Rev. 2.19. for Mat. 26.11.

Ephesians, 4.28. Psalm. 112.5. Dat, non profundit. He gives but not wastes, that so
he may still give. Hence, 1 Cor. 16.1. Dabo egenti, sed ut ipse non egeam;
succurro perituro, sed ut ipse non peream. Sen.

non dat sed ditat: he relieves not his wants, but makes him rich: He that
gives less, non pa^perem sustentat, sed paupertatem. He cures not the disease,
but only gives some present ease.

Non est beneficium nisi quod ratione datur, quoniam ratio omnis honesti comes
est. Sen. It Is not a benefit which is not given with reason, because reason is
the guide, and companion of all virtuous actions, Eccl. 11.1, 2. cast thy bread
upon the waters, not water, 1 Timothy 6.18.

Quest. Who should be the object of our bounty?

Answ. The poor, Luke 14.12. they are the ground in which this seed is to be
sown if we expect an harvest of happiness; they are the Bankers to whom we
must deliver Gods talents if we will be faithful; they are Gods factors to whom
we must deliver our goods, and then God himself will acknowledge the debt, and
will surely pay with advantage.

Not canting companions, lazy lossels, sturdy rogues, profuse prodigals. For, 2
These. 3.10, 12. such should not eat; except in case of extremity: and then non
homini, sed humanitati, not to the person, but to the common nature of
mankind: But

To the honest labourer, and poor hous-keeper, who either, through the
greatness of their charge, or deadness of trade, crosses, losses sickness,
etc. are not able to get their bread, or the blind, and maimed, the aged, and
decrepid: Weak widows, or young orphans. Lev. 25.35. Pars sacrilegii est, res
pauperum dare non pauperibus. It Is a kind of sacrilege to give the poors
portion to those which are not poor. Tunpissimum g^nu^ perd^ndi est inconsulta
donatio. Unadvised giving is the worst kind of loosing: Yet we must not be
overscrupulous in making our choice: we must not be so busy in examining their
estate, and desert, that we can find no leisure to relieve their wants: Hence,
2 These. 3.13. Mat. 10.41. and 25.40.

Quest. What are the true causes from whence this charity arises?

Answ. First, Faith, which formalizes all the Christians actions, and mainly
Heb. 11.6. Romans 14.23.

Secondly, obedience to God because he has commanded it, therefore such Mat.
6.2.

Thirdly, Love unfeigned: Hence, 2 Cor. 8.4. Its called (...), because given
Cor. 13.3. such love not God, 1 John 3.17. and this must arise, 1. From our
love to God, 2 Cor. 8.5. 2. From our love to our brethren, 2 Cor. 9.5.

Fourthly, mercy, and compassion: when we relieve them as fellow members, Isa.
58.10. 1 John 3.17. Its required, Hos. 6.6. Heb. 13.3. Job 31.17, 18. such are
blessed, Prove. 14.21. 2 Cor. 8.9. else all our pity is unprofitable, Jam. 2.15,
etc. Hence, 1 John 3.18. Let us not love in word or tongue, but in deed and
truth.

Quest. How may we best perform these works of mercy?

Answ. If we not only take notice of the wants by report, but by often visiting
the poor, and so being eyewitnesses ^f their wants, and miseries, Jam. 1.27.
Mat. 25.36, 43. and that for these reasons.

1. By visiting the poor, we shall be the better enabled to make a good choice,
and to discover who are truly poor from those who are counterfeits: as also,
who are religious and industrious in their callings, from the profane and idle
drones.

2. Hereby we shall be the better enabled to fit our alms to their necessities,
both in respect of the proportion, and also the special kind of their wants,
whereby the benefit will be much increased, Psalm 112.5. and 41.1.

3. It would prevent their straggling abroad to beg necessaries, which is
forbidden, Deuteronomy. 15.4. and such as neither care for house or home, like idle
drones, would find little relief, unless they earn it with the sweat of their
brows.

4. It would provoke us to be the more compassionate, when we see their small
provision, hungry fare, thin clothes, and hard lodging: children crying for
hunger, and parents crying because they have not food for them, etc. their eye
would affect the heart.

5. Hereby we may do them double good, by distributing spiritual as well as
temporal alms to them, instructing the ignorant, blaming the faulty,
admonishing, counselling and comforting them as God has comforted us, 2 Cor.
1.4. and our words will find more easy entrance into their hearts, when as
our good works have prepared the way.

6. By seeing the wants of our brethren, we shall be provoked to be thankful to
God for his goodness and bounty to us, in not only supplying our wants, but
enabling us to be helpful to others.

7. Hereby we shall learn temperance, and sobriety in the use of Gods
blessings, and not to abuse them to superfluity and excess, seeing many as
good as our selves do want them? but to husband them frugally that we may be
the more able to relieve others.

8. Hereby we shall have occasion given us to prepare against the day of
affliction and want, which may befall us as it has done others.

9. When we visit the poor we visit Christ in them, and he accounts it as done
to himself, Mat. 25.40.

Quest. What are the right ends of giving alms?

Answ. First, the principal end is Gods glory, which should be the chiefest
motive to all Christian duties, Mat. 5.16. 2 Cor. 9.13.



Quest. What must we give?

Answ. We must give only that which is our own, by just and lawful means
derived to us; therefore to be liberal of that which is not our own, is to take
goods from the right owners and to give them to others at our own pleasure,
which is no better then plain theft in the sight of God: If the hire of an
harlot, and price of a dog might not be consecrated to God, Deuteronomy, 23.18. then
may we not offer that which we have gotten by stealth, deceit, oppression, etc.
Isa. 61.8. we must deal justly and love mercy, Mic. 6.8. Hence, Eccles. 11.1.
Prove. 3.9. Isa. 58.7. 1 Cor. 16.2. The Civilians say, Bonus usus non justificat
injuste quaesita; the good use justifies not the unjust getting of goods: such
should rather be restored to the true owners, Luke 19.8. Quale est illud munus
quod alter cum gaudio accipit, alter cum Lachrymis amittit? Aug. Hence will
follow.

1. That its not lawful for one partner to give alms out of the common stock
without the consent of the other, except he set it on his own particular
account.

2. Its not lawful for him that is indebted more then he is able to pay, to
give alms, seeing he gives not his own, but another.

3. It Is not lawful for a man to give that which he has borrowed of another,
or that which is left in pawn with him, except in such things where the
property is altered with the use, as meat, money, corn, etc. then we may give,
when we purpose to make satisfaction by restoring the like to the owner.

Yet all these cases are to be understood with this exception: if the poor ^e
but in ordinary want; not in extreme necessity, and danger to perish for want
of relief, in which case all becomes common through his irresistible necessity,
Mat. 12.1, 3, 4. Deuteronomy. 23.24, 25. Yet even then we must resolve to our utmost
to restore to the owner those goods which we have thus employed.

Quest. What should be the quantity and measure of our alms?

Answ. This is not particularly determined in Scripture, because there are so
many circumstances which may alter the case that no certain rule could be
given; but its left to Christian prudence to give as occasion is offered, more
or less as he thinks good: Hence, 2 Cor. 8.7, 8. and 9.7. Yet in general this
rule must be observed: we must give bountifully, not with a niggardly hand, 2
Cor. 9.6. Deuteronomy. 15.11. Prove. 31.20. 2 Cor. 9.5. yet herein respect is to be had
to our own ability, keeping our cisterns full that our selves may drink of
them, and setting the overplus to run abroad, as Prove. 5.15, 16. Act. 11.29.
every one according to his ability sent, etc. 2 Cor. 8.13, 14. Yet in cases of
extreme necessity we must go beyond our ability, 2 Cor. 8.3. So Christ
commands, Luke 12.33. and 3.11. Act. 2.45. and 4.34, 35. In other cases we may
have two coats, Joh. 19.23. 2 Timothy 4.13.

Quest. What rule must be observed in the quality of our alms?

Answ. We must give to the poor things wholesome, cleanly, convenient, and
comfortable for the sustentation of their lives, avoiding two extremes.

1. Of such as give them such base, and sluttish food, as a dog will scarce
eat. Remember therefore that thou relievest not contemptible creatures, but
those that are of the same nature, etc. yea, in them we lend to the Lord, who
scorns our refuse, Mal. 1.13. we relieve Christ, and will we give him swill,
and swines meat, who nourishes our souls with his precious body and blood.

2. Of such as give them superfluous dainties: but we must feed them, not
pamper them with superfluities: Christ when he fed the multitude provided not
dainties, but multiplied the barley loaves and fishes. Utantur divites
superfluis, den^ paup^ribus necessaria. Aug. Let the rich enjoy their
superfluities, and let them relieve the poor with necessaries.

Quest. What persons ought to give alms?

Answ. All of any estate, when they meet with poorer then themselves; but
principally its the duty of rich men, Luke 16.9. 1 Timothy 6.17, 18. 2 Cor. 8.14.
1 John 3.17. yet not only of them: For he that has but a bare competency is
to give to them that want necessaries: and such as have only sufficient for
nature are bound to give to them who are in present extremity, unless the like
necessity be iminent to themselves: For we must love our neighbor as not above
our selves: Charity begins at home. Now that such must give may be proved by
Scripture, Luke 3.11. and 11.41. Ephesians. 4.28. By example: The poor widow, Mark
12.43. Macedonians, 2 Cor. 8.2. Apostles, Act. 3.6. Luke 8.3. with Joh. 12.6,
8. Its the way to have our little increased, Prove. 11.24. Luke 6.38. Besides,
the alms of the poor (though they give little) are as acceptable to God, as of
the rich, Deuteronomy. 15.11. 2 Cor. 8.12. God measures the deed by the will.
Quantitatem oblationis virtute offerentium determinavit. Chrysostom. As the poor
widows gift.

Quest. What persons may lawfully give alms?

Answ. None but such as are owners of the things given: Hence,

1. Its unlawful for servants to give of their Masters goods, unless he has
given them leave, either in particular, or general. Or unless in case of
extreme necessity in the absence of their governors, having a purpose to make
it known to them, resolving to restore out of their own what they have given in
case their Governors mislike it.

2. Its unlawful for children, under the government of their parents, or tutors
to give alms without the consent of their parents, or governors, either
expressed by words, or allowed by the continual custom of the family, except it
be out of their own allowance.

3. Its unlawful fot such as are not of sufficient age, or discretion to give
alms, because they may waste their estates, or give to unworthy persons for
want of discretion.

Quest. Whether is it lawful for the wife to give alms without the consent of
her husband?

Answ. In diverse cases it is lawful for her to do it: As

1. If he be a fool, or a madd man, and not able himself to manage his estate.

2. When as he is far absent, and so his consent cannot be asked, especially if
she conceive that if her husband were present, he would like of her doings.

3. When he has committed the administration of his household expenses to his
wife, his heart trusting in her.

4. When having a certain allowance made her by her husband, she spares
somewhat out of it to relieve others.

5. When she or her friends for her, have before marriage, over, and above her
dowry reserved something to be at her disposal.

6. When she gets something by her own labor, she may dispose of part of it to
charitable uses, if the Laws of the Country be not against it.

7. If the alms which she gives be but of small value, as bread, bear, cast
apparel, and such like.

8. If her husband be so basely miserable, as having much, he will part with
nothing; or if he be so wicked, that though he spend much vainly, and wickedly,
yet he will give nothing to those that want; or if to any, yet not to them that
fear God.

9. When its a received custom of the Country that the wives should give alms
to the relief of the poor.

Object. But the propriety of the goods being wholly in the husband, its theft
in the wife to give any part of them away without the consent of her husband,
either expressed, or implied?

Answ. If the case be so between man and wife, it were good for the woman not
to marry: Indeed it is granted, that as God has made them yoke-fellows, so she
must endeavor to persuade her husband to draw with her in all Christian
duties: for which end, she must use toward him all duty, respect, reverence,
loving and sweet behavior, that she may move him to love all goodness, at
least for her sake: she must also show such care, faithfulness and good
huswifery that the heart of her husband may trust in her, Prove. 31.11. Yet if
after all this her husband be a Nabal, that will neither be charitable himself,
nor consent that she shall be so; she may do it her self, only herein these
cautions are to be observed.

1. She must observe the former rules, and give discreetly, not exceeding her
husbands ability, the which if it be unknown to her, she must give sparingly,
and things of smaller value. For, Prove. 31.12. She must do him good, etc.

2. She must perform this duty with all meekness and humility of spirit, with
all reverence and due respect to her husbands authority, with acknowledgement
of her subjection in all things lawful, that she may win him by her Christian
carriage, 1 Pet. 3.1.

3. In the manner, she must so do it as not to give her husband any just cause
of offense, she must not usurp authority over him, 1 Timothy 2.10. nor cause the
word of God to be blasphemed, Tit. 2.5.

4. She must not disgrace her husband by publishing his faults: reporting her
Prove. 12.4. But for the further clearing of this point three things are to be
considered.

1. Its acknowledged that the husband has authority over his wife to rule and
govern her as her head, 1 Corinthians. 11.3, 8, 9. 1 Timothy 2.14. Genesis 3.16.

2. Yet the husbands government, and wives subjection must be in the Lord, Col.
3.18. Ephesians. 5.22. 1 Cor. 11.7. He bears the image of God, and she is to yield
obedience to him as unto God in all honest, lawful, and indifferent things. But
if he command what is forbidden, or forbid what is comman^ed, she is not to
obey him therein: Now works of mercy are enjoined, and therefore he may not
forbid them, or if he do, she may not obey.

3. Consider the communion which is between man and wife by reason of the bond
of marriage which extends both to their persons and goods: For their persons,
they are no longer twain, but one flesh: Hence they have not an absolute power
to dispose of their own bodies, but either over other, 1 Cor. 7 4. so also
there is such a communion in goods that there is no absolute prop^iety in
either of them, but it rests in them both: So, Genesis 31.16. All that God has
taken from our father is ours: not that it was their dowry, but through Gods
blessing on their husbands labor, it was theirs through the communion of
marriage. Hence at marriage the husband used to endow his wife with all his
worldly goods.

Object. But this communion of goods extends to her use only: For the
propriety is in the husband, and for the common use which the wife has in her
husbands goods, it only extends to meat, drink, apparel, and such necessaries
for her maintenance?

Answ. A husband indeed may dispose of, or alienate his estate without his
wives consent, except it be her jointure: But this he must do for the good of
his wife and family, not for their hurt, else he is a thief to her and them.

Again, if the wife may dispose of her husbands goods for her bodily use, may
she not much more do it for the good of her soul? and thereby lay up treasure
in heaven: Good works being enjoined to the wife, as well as to the husband, 1 Timothy 2.10. and therefore its better to obey God then man, Act. 5.29.

Object. But under the Law, if a wife made a vow, though of consecrating any
things to Gods service, yet the husband had power to disannul it?

Answ. Vows were of two sorts. 1. Of things absolutely commanded, and

2. I prove it further; because alms-deeds, and works of mercy are no less
Prove. 31.20. and not without good cause is it made the note of a gracious
woman, because ordinarily alms deeds are done out of household store, and
provision, the disposing whereof does more properly belong to the woman then to
the man, as the whole current of the chapter shows. So Paul would have younger
women marry and guide the house, 1 Timothy 5.14. the which when the husband allows
her to do, he honors his wife as he ought, 2 Pet. 3.7. and disgraceth her,
when he turns her out of this office: which he ought not to do, unless she
has forfeited her privilege, by her unjust and indiscreet abusing of it.

Genesis 2.18. therefore if he neglect religious and charitable duties, she must
not only persuade him to them, but if he still neglect, must do them her self
for him, lest the sin and punishment lie not only upon him, but upon her, and
the whole family, Zipporah, by performing a duty which belonged not to her, but
to her husband, diverted Gods judgment from him, Exodus 4.25. and Abigail saved
her husband and family by the like.



Matthew. 25.34. therefore she, as well as he must feed Christ in his members,
etc.

Abigail, 1 Samuel 25.18. of those godly women that ministered to Christ, Luke
8.3. and of that good woman, Pro. 31.20.



Ob. Yet this Doctrine is dangerous, because indiscreet women will abuse it, it
may be to the undoing of their husbands, and ruin of their estates?

Answ. Its but a carnal reason to think that evil will come by the discovery of
a religious truth, or though they should, let truth be maintained though the
inconveniences be never so great. Tbough one abuse a sword, yet all must not be
disarmed for that. Though the Gospel be to some a savor of death, yet must not
Ministers therefore forbear to preach it. Because some women will abuse this
Doctrine, yet they which are discreat and virtuous, must not therefore be kept
in ignorance of their duty, and have their consciences ensnared, and burdened
with that which is not sinful, yea, with that which is honest and commendable.
Many wives undo their husbands with their daintiness in fare, curiosity in
furnishing their houses, and costlinesse in their apparel, but few in doing
works of charity.

Quest. To whom are alms to be given?

Answ. Almsdeeds are to be extended only to the poor and needy, Deuteronomy. 15.11.
1 John 3.17. Ephesians. 4.28. 2 Cor. 8.14. Luke 3.11. Now these poor are of diverse
kinds, Christ reckons up six, Mat. 25.35. Hungry, thirsty, harbourlesse,
naked, sick, and poor prisoners. To which add, the oppressed and exiled, Isa.
58.6, 7. especially if they suffer for the constant confession of the truth.
Add also such as are indebted above their means, the lame, blind, aged,
decrepid, the poor Widow and distressed Orphans, etc. Isa. 58.6, 7. Nehem.
5.11. Luke 14.12. Jam. 1.27.

Quest. What order are we to observe in giving alms?

Answ. First, they which are in extreme necessity, and near perishing, are
first to be relieved, be they acquaintance or strangers: friends or foes, Mat.
5.42. Romans 12.23. Luke 6.30. yet if we cannot relieve all such, we are to
prefer our kindred and friends, and the godly in the first place. We must also
have respect to those, who by Providence are first cast upon us, who thereby
seem by God himself to be preferred before others, Luke 10.33.

1. Again, the whole Church and Commonwealth is to be preferred even before
our selves, if there be such a necessity: for its better that one member
perish, then that the whole be destroyed: therefore the Primitive Christians
sold all they had to relieve the common necessitys.

2. We must take care to provide necessaries for ou^ selves: For charity begins
at home: then for our second selves, our wives: then for our Parents. Contrary
reproved, Mar. 7.11, 12. then for our children, and the rest of the family 1 Timothy 5.8. then our spiritual kindred, except our kindred in the flesh be godly
also, and then they are to be preferred, Gal. 6.10. 1 John 3.17. Romans 12.13.
Mat. 10.41. and 25.40. So David, Psalm. 16.3. Then our Benefacto^s, to whom we
formerly have been beholding, 2 Cor. 8.14. Prove. 18.24. Then to our kindred in
the flesh, Genesis 29.13, 14. Then common friends and neighbors: For Prove. 27.10.
Better is a neighbor that is near, then a brother afar off: Then out
Countrymen, and strangers, Lev. 25.35. Romans 12.13. H^b. 13.2. Genesis 18.3. and
19.2. Isa. 58.7. Mat. 25.35. Deuteronomy. 15.7, 11. Then it must extend to our very
enemies, Romans 12.20. 2 Kings 6.22.

Quest. In what manner may we most conveniently distribute our alms?

Answ. Alms are either more public and common, or more private and particular.

First, in the former, our best course is to follow the Laws and Customs of

Secondly, for our private alms, we may give them to such poor, as upon

Quest. What may be thought of giving alms at our doors?

Answ. It cannot be condemned, till the good Laws made, be put in execution,
for the reformation of this disorder; yet with these cautions.

First, the whole stream of our charity must not run that way.

Secondly, we must give to such as are in apparent misery, as to the aged,
decrepid,

1. Because they which are truly poor, will by this means be neglected whilst
idle drones devour that which belongs to them.

2. Hereby the bold and impudent will often speed better then the modest and
shamefast.

3. Our alms shall by this means be distributed unequally; some having all,
and others none, neither can they be fitted to the quantity or quality of their
wants.

4. Such giving increases the number of idle vagrants, encoura^ing them to
continue in their wicked courses, without any fear of God, or subjection unto
men.

5. It crosses Gods Ordinance, who would not have a beggar in Israel, Deuteronomy.
15.4. Proclaiming both the negligence of Magistrates in not reforming this
disorder, and the hard-heartednesse of private persons, who through the want of
mercy and compassion, thrust their neighbors into such sinful courses.

6. Hereby those excellent Laws, which are made to prevent such disorders are
transgressed, and so the Christian Magistrate is justly offended.

Quest. What are we to judge of such alms as are given by men at their death?

Answ. They are to be esteemed and censured according to the quality and
condition of the persons by whom they are performed. For

1. Either they are done by such as according to their abilities, have
exercised such charity in their whose lives after their Conversion, out of
love, and obedience to God, and mercy toward men. Or

Secondly, out of self-love, vainglory, or servile fear, by such as have
utterly neglected them in their lifetime, and now think to make satisfaction
for their former neglect.

For the former we are to judge, that they proceed from their love to God and
their neighbors, being not content with what they have done in their lifetime,
but also take care that they be continued even after their death. Neither are
we to take exceptions, though the quantity now given does exceed all that they
have done in their lives, seeing herein they deal no otherwise with the poor
then with their own children and friends, upon whom they bestow more by Will,
then ever before they gave them; and its just that men should keep the largest
part of their goods while they live for their own maintenance, giving to the
poor what they can conveniently spare, and they are very charitable, if they
design a great part of their estate to religious uses, when as themselves shall
have no further use of it.

But for those who wholly neglect works of mercy in their lives, and think it
sufficient to give something at death, they are not absolutely to be condemned,
-lest hereby they take occasion to neglect both: Besides, these may be
after-fruits of their late repentance: They are also good to the receivers, and
for the givers, they are better then such as neither do good in life, nor
death: neither can they be taxed for doing them now, but because they did them
no sooner.









1. We may be stripped of our goods before death, and so have nothing to
bequeath then. 2. Death may surprise us suddenly, and give us no time to
dispose of our goods. 3. Our sickness may be such as may deprive us of our
understanding and memory, whereby we shall be disinabled to do it. 4. If we
make our Will beforehand, it may be concealed or made void by some trick in
Law, or unjust testimony of false witnesses, or not be performed through the
dishonesty of Executors, therefore do as Solomon advises, Prove. 3.27. and Gal.
6.10.




there is great cause of suspicion, that they proceed not from those right and
religious causes which set Christians on work to do them, but from sinister
ends, and worldly respects* which before prevailed not with them, till now they
see that they can keep them no longer.

Quest. How may the alms of Christians be differenced from those which are
done by worldlings?

Answ. First, they differ in the causes or fountain from which they arise:

First, the alms of Christians are the fruits of a lively and justifying
faith, and are done out of unfeigned love, and obedience unto God, and
therefore he is merciful, because he is assured that God is merciful to him,
and he gives small things to men, because he receives great things from God.

Secondly, they spring from charity and mercy toward the poor, because they
are members of Christ, and of the household of faith, or at least creatures of
God, of the same flesh with himself: whereas worldlings alms arise from
self-love, whereby he aims at some temporary good, to be derived to himself
thereby: or out of pride and vainglory to get praise, Mat. 6.1. etc. or out of
an opinion of merit to get a greater reward from God: or out of a servile fear
to escape the wrath of God here or hereafter, and therefore they profit
nothing, 1 Cor. 13.3.

Secondly, a Christian shows mercy, being inclined thereto by the motion

Thirdly, they differ in their ends: the end of a Christian being principally

Fourthly, they differ in the matter, and that

In regard of Propriety, a Christian gives liberally, out of his own store,
which God has bestowed upon him by his honest labor: the worldling gives out
of that which is other men's, and having raked much together, by lying, fraud,
injustice, oppression, etc. he gives out of it some small alms to make
satisfaction for his sins, and to stop the Cry of Conscience, that he may go
more quietly to Hell.

Fifthly, they differ in the quantity: a Ch^istian gives liberally, not only
out

Sixthly, they differ in the quality: a Christian gives things profitable and

Seventhly, they differ in the object and extent. A Christians mercy extends
Gal. 6.10. imitating God therein, Mat. 5.45. and David, Psalm. 16.3. But the
worldlings mercy extends usually to such as have some way deserved it, or that
may deserve it: or to kindred, or friends, therefore its rejected by God^punc;
Mat. 5.46, 47.

Eighthly, they differ in the manner of giving, and in the minds of the

1. A Christian gives with a plain, and honest heart, as Romans 12.8. seeking
therein only to please God, as Matthew. 6.3. But the worldling hunts after his
own profit, or praise, Matthew. 23.5. neither is it an act of mercy, but of
self-love.

2. A Christian does works of mercy with great humility, remembering that
whatsoever he thus gives to God, he has first received it from God: and so
confess that he does far less then his duty, and that he is sufficiently
rewarded, if his failings are pardoned: But the worldling is puffed up with
pride, thinking that hereby he has satisfied for his sins, merited heaven, and
made God his debtor: and hence he is so supercilious toward his poor brother,
that he makes his gift unacceptable.

3. A Christian does all with cheerfulness, as knowing that God loves a
cheerful giver, 1 Timothy 6.8. they proceed from an inward habit, and therefore
flow freely from him: This he shows by his pleasant countenance, sweet words,
speedy giving, etc. But the worldling does it churlishly, Dum manu dat, vultu
negat: whilst his hand gives, his looks denies: He gives with reproaches,
taunts, harsh expostulations, etc. not so much comforting the poor with his
gifts as afflicting his soul with his words.

Ninthly, they differ in time: For a Christian gives all his life long: But the
worldling for the most part only when death is approaching, when he can keep
his goods no longer.

Quest. How many ways must our charity be expressed?

Answ. Principally three ways. 1. In giving. 2. In forgiving. 3. In lending.

Quest. When must we forgive debts?

Answ. When we see our neighbors decayed in their estates, whereby they are
disenabled to pay what they borrowed; we must show mercy to beasts when they
lie under their burden, much more to men. Hence, Exodus 22.26, 27. Neh. 5.11.
Luke 6.35. Isa. 58.6. Mat. 18.28, 34.

Quest. How must we relieve by free lending?

Answ. When their estates are decayed, and our lending may probably recover
them again. Hence, Deuteronomy. 15.8. Mat. 5.42. Luke 6.35. Psalm. 112.5.

Quest. Whether are alms-deeds arbitrary, or an act of righteousness?

Answ. By righteousness we understand not generally all righteousness which
consists in a total conformity to the whole Law, nor that part of legal
righteousness which consists in obedience to the second Table; but certain
special fruits of this righteousness in works of mercy which by the Hebrews
are called by the name of righteousness, as Dan. 4.27. which is a grace that
rests not only in an internal habit, or bare affection of the heart, but also
in the outward action of relieving the poor. Which also is called Justice,
which is a virtue that gives to every one those things which are due to him,
Mat. 6.1. when thou do thine alms, which the Syriack renders, when thou do
thy Justice. Called also righteousness, 2 Corinthians. 9.9. Prove. 11.18. Psalm.
113.3. Now that almsdeeds are not arbitrary, but absolutely necessary is
proved: For that,

1. They are not only works of mercy, but fruits of righteousness, which are
straightly enjoined in the Law, Deuter. 15.11. Esaias 58.7. Ezekiel. 18.7. Luke 3.11.
and 11.41. Matthew. 4.42. Ephesians. 4.28. Luke 12.33. Acts 4.34.

2. Our riches are not absolutely our own, but Gods talents committed to us,
not for the satisfying of our lusts, but for the honor of our Master, and good
of our fellow servants. Hence, Heb. 13.16.

3, Such as neglect works of mercy commit three heinous sins, Theft,
Sacrilege, Murder: For they that have received much, and communicate not to
the wants of others, shall be arraigned and condemned for thieves against God
and their brethren: Besides what we are commanded to give to the poor is
consecrated to Gods service, called therefore sacrifices. So that its
Sacrilege to rob them of it: and lastly, if we suffer the poor to perish in
their wants we are guilty of murder against the sixth Commandment. Si non
p^visti, occi^isti, Ambrose. Thou have killd the poor, if thou have not fed
