CHAP. XXXV. Questions, and Cases of Conscience about Self-Commendation.
Quest. IS it lawful for a man to commend himself?

Answ. It is lawful in some cases for a child of God to commend himself: to
declare what God has done for him or by him to speak of the graces God has
bestowed on him, of his labors, of works which God has wrought by him, yea,
and of his sufferings for God; as will appear by these examples: Of Nehemiah,
chap. 13.1. to 14, etc. Of Job, chap. 29. and 31. of Paul, Act. 20. Phil. 3. 1
These. 2. 2 Cor. 11. and 12.

Quest. In what cases is this self-commendation allowed?

Answ. First, of afflictions from God; wherein they have professed their faith
Job. chapter 13.14, 15. and 23.10, 11, 12. and the Church, Psalm. 44.17, etc. and
Jeremy, chapter 17.16, 17.

Secondly, of injuries from men in word or deed.

1. In word, by scoffs, and reproaches, as David, 2 Samuel 6.20, 21. By slanders
of their good conversations: So did Paul, Act. 22.1, etc. and 23.1. and 24.5,
6. and 26.2, etc. So Jacob, Genesis 31.36, to 42. yea, Christ himself, Joh. 8.46,
48, 49.

2. In deed: then we may protest our innocence to prove we suffer wrongfully;
as Daniel did, Dan. 6.22, Christ, Joh. 10.31, 32. and 8.40.

Thirdly, when thereby we may show forth the infinite riches of Gods free Paul,
1 Cor. 15.9, 10. 1 Timothy 1.13, 15, 16.

Fourthly, to give others occasion, and to provoke them.

1. To pray for us. So Paul, Heb. 13.18.

2. To praise God for us, and glorify him in our behalf. So Paul, 2 Cor. 1.11,
12. Gal. 1.24. Ephesians. 1.15, 16.

3. To glory on our behalf before others, especially those that seek to
traduce, and slander us. So Paul, 2 Cor. 5.11, 12. 2 These. 1.4.

Fifthly, when others require an account of our faith, holiness, obedience, or
Pet. 3.15.

Sixthly, when we would propound our selves as examples to others of faith,
etc. to draw others to follow our steps: so David, Psalm. 66.1^. Paul, Phil.
3.17. Christ, Mat. 11.29.

Paul, 2 Cor. 12.11.

Paul, 2 Cor. 5.11. that we may make it appear that we seek not theirs but
them, 1 These. 2.4, 5, 6. 1 Cor. 10.33. Thus we may commend our selves.

1. To uphold the credit of our calling, as Paul did of his Ministry.

2. To further the success of our labors: So Paul also.

3. To promote the efficacy of the counsel, or charge we give to others, and
make it more prevalent. So Paul, 2 Timothy 1.8.

4. To manifest our love to others by opening our hearts to them, to let them
look in and see the treasures of grace, comforts, and experiences which God
has laid up in them: Also to gain their love to us, to insinuate into their
bosoms, and so be a means of doing them the more good: So did Paul, 2 Cor.
7.2. We may also commend our selves in some things, to approve our sincerity in
other things: So David, Psalm. 18.23. and 119.98, 100. and Nehemiah, chapter 5.15.

Paul even to magnify his office, etc. Romans 11.13.

Samuel, 1 Samuel 12.2, 3, 4. So Paul, Act. 20.25.



1. Either against God by declaring to them that they see no such evil in us,
but the contrary graces and practices; that we dare not say, or do, as they do
for a world, thereby to draw them to repentance.

2. Or against our selves, when they reject or abuse us, by appealing to their
consciences what iniquity they have found in us to deserve the same at their
hands.

Object. But is not this condemned? Prove. 27.2. 2 Cor. 10.18. was it not Simon
Magus his sin? Act. 8.9. and that Pharisee's, Luke 18.11. So Prove. 20.6.

Answ. Self-commendation which proceeds from pride, and hypocrisy, or from
distrust of providence, as if God would not take care of our good names, etc.
is vain, and sinful. Laus proprio sordescit in ore: and hereby such do others a
treble wrong.

1. They take other men's office out of their hands; or take that to our selves
which is another right to give us.

2. They give to others a bad example, who will learn to imitate them.

3. Its tedious to an ingenuous spirit to hear others to boast of themselves:
Yet

The abuse of a thing takes not away the lawfulness and use of it.

Quest. How then shall we know when self-commendation is lawful?

Answ. First, by the matter, when the thing for which we commend our selves is,

1. Good in it self, and praise worthy: For if it be evil, we glory in our
shame: Again, it must not be for our temporals, as Riches, honors, etc. But
for spirituals, as the righteousness of Christ, the grace, love, and favor of
God: the work or service of God, or for doing, or suffering for God: So, Jer.
9.23. so in Paul, Phil. 3.4, 5, 6. 2 Cor. 11.21, 22, 23. Romans 15.17. Phil. 4.8.
1 Cor. 4.9. to 14. 2 Cor. 6.4, 5, 8, 9, 10.

2. When for the matter we speak only of such things as are really ours, or
that we have in truth, and do in deed, so that for the truth of our words we
can appeal to the testimony of Gods Spirit, and our own consciences: as Paul,
Romans 9.1, 2, 3. 1 These. 2.10, 11. 2 Cor. 12.6.

Secondly, By the measure, when it is our care, and fear not to overreach
herein, Cor. 10.13, etc. Romans 15.18.

Thirdly, by the manner, and that in a threefold respect.

1. Of our selves, when we commend our selves forcedly, humbly, and modestly.

1. Forcedly, not forwardly: when we are necessitated, or strongly moved
thereto; as Paul, 2 Cor. 12.11. and v. 1. 2. Humbly, out of the sense of our
own infirmities and unworthiness, notwithstanding all the good we have or do;
and out of fear lest others should think better of us then we are, or deserve:
So with Paul, 2 Cor. 12.6. For Gods humble servants take notice of the evil as
well as of the good that is in them; as Isa. 59.2. Job 40.4. and 42.5, 6. 1
Cor. 15.8, 9. Ephesians. 3.8. 1 Timothy 1.13, 14, 15. 3. Modestly, when we speak of
our graces, and performances soberly, not in a boasting way, as Nebuchadnezzar
did, Dan. 4.30. How modest was Paul in speaking of matters that concerned his
own praise? 2 Cor. 11.5, 24, to 29. Heb. 13.18.
2. Of God, when we speak of the good we have, or do thankfully, and that 1.
With a free acknowledgement of God as the sole author of all, from whom we
have received all we have, 1 Cor. 4.7. Phil. 4.13. Isa. 26.12. 2. Out of a
sense of Gods goodness to us therein, with high and honorable thoughts of
God, and fear of his name, and with an heart inflamed with love to God and joy
in him.


3. Of others, when we commend our selves charitably, and tenderly, not to
despise, disgrace, or discourage others who are weak: as the proud Pharisee
insulted over the Publican, whom God justified, when he condemned the other.

Fourthly, by the end: Self-commendation is lawful when the end is good,

1. In respect of our selves to do our selves right, and to preserve our good
Luke 17.10. When you have done all that you can, say we are unprofitable
servants, etc. Hence Paul ascribes all to Gods grace, 1 Cor. 15.10. and see
what Christ says, John 5.44. Hence Paul, 1 These. 2.6.

2. In respect of God; when, whatever we speak of our selves that is good, we
do it that God may be glorified in us, and by us, and for us, and we give God
the praise of all our praises: Yea, if God may be glorified, and his name
exalted, we can be content to be abased, and to have our honors laid in the
dust. So John the Bap. Joh. 3.29, 30. So, 1 Cor. 1.31.

Mr. Reyners Rules for the Government of the tongue.

To these foregoing, add one rule more.

That when a man is urged to a necessary self-commendation, and is forced by
the importunity of others to vindicate himself; yet to qualify his speech as
much as may be, its good to use a word of the plural number; as Paul does, 2
Cor. 5.20. We the Ambassadors, etc. where he distributes the honor to many,
that he may not seem to attribute too much to himself, and so that plural
number is a phrase of singular humility. Dr. Stoughton.

CHAP. XXXVI. Questions, and Cases of Conscience about our communion with God.
Quest. What is it to be in communion with God?

Answ. When we are made one with him, or united to him, as a child to his
Father, 1 John 1.3. So that our communion with God, is 1. To see him in his
works. 2. To hear him in his Word. 3. To speak to him by prayer, and praise. 4.
To walk with him in meditation of his presence.


Quest. What are the evidences, or signs of our communion with God, and with
Jesus Christ?

Answ. First, The holy spirit of God, and of Jesus Christ given to us, 1 John
Hereby we know that he abides in us, by his Spirit which he has given us. So
1 John 4.13.

Quest. How do we know this our communion with God, by his Spirit given us?

Answ. First, As the inward, immediate, efficient cause of this divine
communion Ephesians. 2.22. 2. Christ supplies his absence from his Church by his
Spirit, Joh. 14.15, 17, 25, 26. and 16.17, 18.

Secondly, As an Anointing, teaching us all things, 1 John 2.27. Revealing to
us the things that are given us of God, 1 Cor. 2.12. and illuminating us with
Joh. 14.21, 22, 23.

Thirdly, As a witness with our spirits, Romans 8.15, 16.

Fourthly, As a seal upon our hearts, Ephesians. 1.13.

Fifthly, As the earnest, and first fruits of our adoption, and endless
communion with God in glory, Ephesians. 1.14. Romans 8.23.

Sixthly, As the original cause, and root of all these spiritual fruits, which
are only found in them that have communion with God, Gal. 5.22, 23.

Quest. But by what signs may we know that the Spirit of God is given us?

Answ. If the Spirit of God be given us, then

1. We are, or have been effectually convinced by the spirit of our own
natural misery, and of Christ's supernatural alsufficiency to remove it, Joh.
16.7. to 12.

2. We are washed, and sanctified by the Spirit, 1 Cor. 6.11. mortifying the
old man, and quickening the new man in us, Romans 8.13, 11.

3. We are acted, guided, and led by the Spirit of God, Romans 8.14.

4. We mind the things of the Spirit, Romans 8.5. our thoughts, projects,
contrivements, etc. do habitually fix here.

5. We bring forth the fruits of the Spirit, which spirit cannot bring forth
bad fruit, not be barren, Ephesians. 5.9. Gal. 5.22, 23.

6. We combat by the Spirit against the flesh, Gal. 5.17.

7. We are strengthened to every good word and work, with might in the inward
man by the Spirit, Ephesians. 3.16. Col. 1.10, 11. and particularly by the spirit
we are notably enabled unto prayer against all our infirmities, Romans 8.15, 26,
27.

Secondly, The true abiding of the ancient, Primitive truth, and Doctrine of
Ioh. 2.22, 23, 24. All novelties in Doctrine are to be censured by Primitive
truths, and brought to the ancient standard for their regulation.

Quest. How shall we know that we sincerely abide in the truth?

Answ. First, if we have a cordial love to the truth, 2 These. 2.10. Contrary in
those, 2 Timothy 4.3, 4.

Secondly, A conscientious care to do nothing against the truth, but any Cor.
13.8. 2 Ioh. 10.11.

Thirdly, an earnest contending for the faith once delivered to the Saints,
Jude

Fourthly, A bearing witness to the truth, both verbally, and really in the
worst Paul, Phil. 1.17. and so Rev. 2.13. yea, Christ himself bore witness to
the truth even unto death, Ioh. 18.37.

Ioh. 4.15.

Object. But how can this be? did not the Devil confess Christ to be the Son of
God? Mar. 1.24. Luke 4.34, 41. and Hypocrites? Mat. 7.22.23.

Answ. There is a double confessing that Jesus is the son of God.

1. Dogmaticall, arising merely from the assenting act of Faith that believes
the truth of Gods word, touching Jesus Christ. So Devils, and Hypocrites may
confess Christ, Tit. 1.16. and in opinion they know him, Luke 4.41. this may be
without any communion with God and Christ.

2. Fiduciall, arising not only from the assenting, but also from the applying
act of Faith, when we confess Christ with confidence, and trust in him for
salvation: This is here meant.

Quest. How shall we know when we fiducially confess Jesus Christ?

Answ. 1. If we assent to the truth of Gods record touching Christ, 1 Ioh.
5.10, 11. 2. If we appy Christ to our selves, resting and living upon him
according to that record, Ioh. 1.11, 12. Gal. 2.20. 3. If we confess Christ
thus applied, not only in words, but in deeds also, Tit. 1.16. Mat. 7.21. 4. If
we confess Christ even to sufferings, and to death, Acts 20.23, 24. and 21.13.
Rev. 2.13.
Fourthly, Not doing, or practicing of sin, is a sign of our communion with
God, 2 Ioh. 3.6, 8.

Fifthly, Unfeigned love to God, and dwelling therein, is a sign of our true
Ioh. 4.16. For

1. Our true love to God denotes a reciprocation of mutual affections betwixt
God and us, 1 Ioh. 4.19.

2. It implies a reciprocation of the genuine fruits, and effects of love
mutually. God loving us, adops, redeems, calls, sanctifies, justifies, and
glorifies us: we loving God, trust in him, fear, obey him, etc. both these
import spiritual communion with God.

Quest. How may we know that we truly dwell in Gods love?

Answ. 1. When we love God with an intensive love, Luke 10.27. that is, with
all within us. 2. When we love God with a predominant love, that overcomes our
love to all other objects besides God, Psalm. 97.10. Mat. 10.37. with Luke 14
26. Rev. 21.11. 3. When we love God obedientially, so as willingly to obey all
his commands, Ioh. 14.15. 1 Ioh. 5.3. 2 Cor. 5.14. 4. When we love him
invincibly, so that our love cannot be quenched, or conquered, but we are ready
to endure any thing for his sake, Cant. 8.6, 7. Acts 20.23, 24. and 21.13. 5.
When we love him continually, Ephesians. 6.24.
Sixthly, walking in light, and not in darkness, evidenceth our communion with
God, 1 Ioh. 1.5, 6, 7.

Quest. How shall we know that we walk thus?

Answ. 1. When we are effectually translated from darkness to light, Acts
26.18. Col. 1.13. Ephesians. 5.8. 2. When we cast off the works of darkness, and
put on the armor of light, Romans 13.12. etc. when we bring forth the fruits of
light, Ephesians. 5.9. 3. when we shun all fellowship with works of darkness in
others. Ephesians. 5.11. 4. When we love the light, and come to it, that our deeds
may be manifested to be of God, Ioh. 3.20, 21.
Seventhly, Walking as Christ, or chief Captain, Heb. 2.10. walked, is another
sign of our communion with God, 1 Ioh. 2.6.

Quest. How did Christ walk, that we may know whether we walk as he walked?

Answ. 1. Christ walked holily, purely, and inoffensively toward God and man,
Heb 4.15 and 7.26. Isa. 59.9. So should we, 1 Cor. 10.32, 33. Act. 23.1. and
24.16. 1 These. 2.10, 11, 12. 2. Christ walked most humbly and meekly, Mat.
11.28. Phil. 2.5, 6, 7. 3. Most self-denyingly; though rich, he became poor for
our sakes, 2 Cor. 8.9. So Mar. 14.36. 4. Most zealously, Ioh. 2.15, 16, 17. 5.
Most obedientially to his heavenly Father, Romans 5.19. Ioh. 4.34. Heb. 5 8, 9.
Phil. 2.8. 6. Most profitably, he went about doing good, Act. 10.38. 7. Most
lovingly, tenderly, and compassionately to poor sinners to win, and save them,
Luke 4.18, 19, 20, 21. Mat. 12.19, 20. and 11.28, 29, 30. Luke 7.37. to the
end. 8. Most spiritually and Heavenly, he lived on earth, as if he had been in
heaven, extracting heavenly contemplations, and spiritual lessons from all
sorts of earthly objects, and occasions presented before him, as Ioh. 4.10,
etc. and ver. 31.32. and 6.26, 27, etc. and 15.1. etc.
Eighthly, Keeping his word, and commandments, discovers our communion with
him, 1 John 2.5. and 3.23, 24.

Quest. How shall we know whether we keep his commandments as we ought?

Answ. If we practice righteousness, 1 John 2.29. and 3.10. and that.



Luke 12.33, 34. 2 Kin. 10.30, 31. which is 1. From a pure heart: 1. Purified
by the blood of Christ for our justification, Zach. 13. 1. Psalm. 51.7. Act.
15.9. 2. By the spirit of Christ for our sanctification, 1 Cor. 6.11. Psalm.
66.18. 2. From a good conscience, purged by Christ from dead works, to serve
the living God, Heb. 9.14. and when its habitually exercised to an
inoffensiveness toward God and man, Acts 24.16. with 23.1. and when it
endeavors to be completely, and universally good, Acts 23.1. Yea, when it
approves it self good in Gods sight, 1 Pet. 3.21. and when from all this the
heart gives in a comfortable testimony of its simplicity and godly sincerity,
able to support under greatest distress, 2 Co. 1.8. etc. 3. From faith
unfeigned without which there is no pleasing of God, Heb. 11.6. Faith washes
all out duties, and acts of obedience, in the blood of Christ, and so renders
them acceptable to God, 1 Pet. 2.5.

Sincerely, and uprightly, Genesis 17.1. as David, Psalm. 18.22. and 66.18. Paul, 2
Cor. 2. ult. Peter, Joh. 21.15, 16, 17. 3. Obedientially, because God commands
it, as in Noah, Heb. 11.7. Abraham, Heb. 11.8, 17, etc. David, Psalm. 40.8. and
119.143. Paul, Romans 7.22. 4. Universally, without reservations, and exceptions,
Psalm. 119.6. Numb. 14.22. Luke 1.6. 5. Constantly, Psalm. 1.2, 3. and 92.13, 14.
and 119.20.


Cor. 10.31. and our own, and others spiritual and eternal good, Mat. 5.16. 1
Pet. 4.2, 3, 4. Romans 2.7.

CHAP. XXXVII. Questions, and Cases of Conscience about communicating in other
men's sins.
Quest. HOw many ways may we communicate in other men's sins?

Answ. First, by Counsel, and advise, when Sam. 16.21. Absalom committed
incest, but Achitophel counseled it, Mark 6.25. The Damsel desired John
Baptists head, but her mother advised her, v. 24.

Secondly, by command, whether by word or writing, 1 Samuel 22.18. Doeg murdered
the Priests, but Saul commanded him, Act. 23.3. the servant struck Paul, but
the High Priest commanded it: The Judges condemned Naboth, but Jesabel
commanded them by her Letters: So David by Letters killed Uriah. So, 2 Samuel
1^.28. 1 King. 12.30. and 13.34. Jer. 28.16.

Thirdly, by permission: Thus all Governors are guilty* when their inferiors,
Eli, 1 Samuel 3.13. Qui non prohibet malum cum potest, facit. He that forbids not
sin when its in his power, commits it: Pilate was guilty, because he
restrained not the Jews from putting Christ to death: So, Nehem. 13.17. Numb.
35.31.

Fourthly, by provocation. Gal. 5.26. Ahab was most wicked whom Jesabel King.
21.25.

Fifthly, by consent, and countenancing wicked actions: as Saul, Act. 8.1. by
Stevens death. So Number. 16.19.

Quest. How many ways is sin countenanced?

Answ. First, by participation in the action: as the Receiver to the Thief, the

Secondly, by silence and concealment: when a man has a calling public, Ezekiel.
3.17, 18. or when we conceal sin from such as should reform it.

Eli dear, 1 Samuel 2.29.

Fifthly, by praising and flattering men in sin, Prove. 29.5.

Why are Superiors guilty of such sins as they permit?

Answ. First, because every man is commanded to reprove his brother, Lev.

Quest. How then may such keep our selves free from other men's sins?

Answ. First, they must pry, and enquire into the lives of those that are
committed to them, that they may see what is amiss; this a private man is not
bound to, but public are, Prove. 27.23.

Abraham, Genesis 18.19. Joshuah, chap. 24.13. so its commanded. Exodus 20.10.
Masters must come with their train to the House of God, Psalm. 42.4.

Quest. What motives may provoke us to avoid communicating in other men's sins?

Answ. First, we must be responsible to God for all our own sins, and

Jacobs resolution: Into their secret let not my soul come, Genesis 49.6. so we
are exhorted, Prove. 1.10. If sinners entice thee, consent thou not. Nicodemus
stands up for Christ when all were against him, Joh. 4.51.

Psalm. 50.18. the Actors and consenters are in the same case; and its all one
whether we be defiled with our own, or others filthiness.

scorns that Noah, Lot, etc.

Sixthly, the want of conscience in this duty sets, and continues all things

Dr. Tho. Tailor.

Quest. How else may we communicate in other men's sins?

Answ. According to Mr. Baines on Ephesians. it may be done eight ways.

1. By provoking to sin; as such as stir up lust, anger, pride, etc. in
others. These are worse sinners then they which commit it; as the devil
tempting our first parents, was deeper in the sin and judgment then they.
Ringleaders in sin shall be ringleaders in judgment.

2. By commanding sin: For he that commands it, is the chief offender. Thus
David murdered Uriah.

3. By counselling: As Jonadab to Ammon, 2 Samuel 13.5.

4. By consenting; as Ahab in the murder of Naboth, 1 King. 21.19. So Hosea
5.11.

5. By carelesseness to prevent sin: We must not say as Cain: Who made me my
brothers Keeper? but we must watch over, exhort, reprove, etc. For when Achan
sinned, all Israel is said to sin, Jos. 7.1. and the whole body of them was
punished.

6. By not suppressing sin: Thus Eli sinned, 1 Samuel 3.13.

7. By applauding sin: so, Romans 1.32. This strengthens the arms of the
wicked.

8. By not testifying against it, Lev. 5.1.

Quest. Are not all men guilty some way or other of the sins of the times?

Answ. Yea truly, we all receive some taint, and soil from the times we live
in, either our zeal is weakened, or we do not grieve so much for the sins of
the times as we should, This made the Corinthians guilty of the sin of the
incestuous person, 1 Cor. 5.2.

Quest. Whether is it lawful for a man to rejoice at another man's sin?

Answ, We may never rejoice at sin as it is sin: but as God turns it to an
occasion of good, so we may rejoice: as when a proud man by falling into some
shameful sin, is thereby brought to repentance, and humbled; or when by the
occasion of some soul impiety, a good Law is made against it, which otherwise
would not have been made, Phil. 1.15, 16, 17, 18.

Ames. Cas. Consci.

CHAP. XXXVIII. Questions, and Cases of Conscience about the choice and use of
Company.
Quest. WHat rule are we to observe in the choice of our company?

Answ. Never cast thy self into wicked company, nor press amongst the profane,
especially upon choice, voluntarily, and delightfully: And abide no longer with
them at any time, upon any occasion, then thou have a sound warrant, and
calling thereto. Fo its uncomly, and incompatible with a good conscience: Its
not for the honor, or comfort of Gods children. to keep company, or familiarly
to converse with graceless men.

Object. But may we not make use of such company?

Answ. That we may the better understand it, we must distinguish of our
companying with them: For

1. There is a common, cold, and more general society, in trading, buying,
selling, saluting, eating, and drinking together, and in other passages of
humanity, and entercouse of civil society, to which charity, nature,
necessity, or the exigents of our callings, general, or particular, do
warrantably lead us. This may, nay must be, 1 Cor. 5.10.

2. Special, dear, intimate society, in consultations, and counsels about
matters of special secrecy, greatest weight, and highest consequence: In
spiritual refreshments, Religious conferences, prayer, marriage, etc. In a free
communication of their souls, their spiritual estate, etc. Now Gods children
are bound by the Law of God, and prudence, from conversing with delight, and
from the exchange, and exercise of those special passages of dearest
acquaintance with profane men, and enemies of God.

Quest. What reasons may be rendered for this?

Answ. First, by such society he incurs a double hazard.

1. Of being infected with sin: Can a man touch pitch, and not be defiled? or
go upon coals and not be burnt? Pro. 6.27, 28. Indeed there is a strange
attractive, 1. By familiar correspondence with such, there steals upon a man a
secret and insensible dislike of his former sober courses, as having thereby
too much abridged himself of his liberty. 2. There slily insinuates into his
heart a pleasing approbation of, and assent to the sensual courses of his lewd
companions. 3. There follows a resolved, and habitual change of his affections,
and conversation into the manners of those which he so familiarly converses
with. 4. He grows out of conceit with good men, and good exercises, because he
daily hears them railed on, jested at, and slandered: and so by degrees is
himself transformed into a scoffing Ishmael, and a breathing Devil.


Quest. But I hope we may keep company with such as are civil?

Answ. Christians which have any fear of God in their hearts, will shun the
society of such grossly profane persons, knowing that their souls are a thousand
times more capable of the contagion of sin, then their bodies of an infectious
disease, and therefore their danger is greater by conversing with merely civil
men, whose society they unadvisedly entertain for kindred, old acquaintance,
advantage, or such carnal respects, and thereby cool in their zeal, loose
their comfort, feelings of Gods favor, joyful springings of heart, boldness in
the ways of God, cheerfulness in the exercises of Religion, and that
comfortable fruition of other Christian prerogatives, which many other of their
brethren do, and themselves, by the benefit of Religious companions, and
delightful conversing with the Saints, might plentifully enjoy.

2. A Christian is every hour which he is in their company without a
warrantable calling, and just dispensation out of the Word of God, in great
danger of being involved within the flames of the just confusions, and inwrapt
within the compass of those outward curses, and plagues which Gods indignation
inflicts upon wicked men. All profane men, being unreconciled to God, are every
moment liable to all those miseries, and fearful judgments, which either man,
or Devil, any of Gods creatures, or his own immediate hand can bring upon
them, they are only respired by Gods mercy, and deferred to those
opportunities, and seasons which seem fittest to his holy wisdom. Now when at
any time they light upon them, if any of Gods Children be unwarrantably in
their company, and with delight, its righteous with God, that he receive his
portion amongst them at that time, 2 Chronicles. 20.37. Be ye not therefore
companions with them, Ephesians. 5.7.



a good name is better then great riches, Prove. 22.1. Eccle. 7.1. It makes the
bones fat, Prove. 15.30. therefore we should much prize it.



1. Because of that irreconcilable enmity, and antipathy between the seed of
the woman, and the seed of the Serpent: between light and darkness, Christ and

2. Because every unregenerate man, though furnished with the best perfections
attainable in that state, thinks that his lukewarmnesse, and formality is

what heart then can a Christian have to converse intimately with such as hate
him for his goodnesse-sake.

2. He is a stumbling block to the weak Christian, who by looking upon his

Quest. May we not converse with our unconverted kindred, friends, neighbors,
etc.

Answ. Yes, But then you must observe these rules*

First, labor for more power of grace, knowledge, sanctification, Christian

Secondly, See that thy heart be sincere, and that in the singleness thereof



Quest. What must we do when we come into Christian and good company.

Answ. Prize it as thy only Paradise, and heaven upon earth: the very flower,
and festival of all thy refreshing time in this vale of tears, and therefore
ever bring with thee.

1. A cheerful, and delightsome heart, and though thou wast formerly sad, and
overcast with clouds of heaviness, yet let the presence, and faces of those,
whom hereafter thou shall meet in heaven, and therewith incomparable joy behold
for ever, disperse, and dispell them all, and infuse comfortable beams of
heavenly, and spiritual joy.



Thirdly, An humble heart, ready, and rejoicing to exchange, and enjoy mutual
Romans 1.12. and 15.24. Mr. Boltons directions for a comfortable walking with God.

Quest. What must we do when we come into the company of the wicked?

Answ. First, thou must vindicate the power, and truth of Religion from the
mistakings of those which are ignorant, and undervaluers of it; as for example:
Thou art in company where thou hear a mea^ civil man, or formal Professor
commended for his religion, which commendation if he carry away without
contradiction, the rest of the company may be drawn to resolve not to go
beyond his pitch, seeing his estate is approved by wise and understanding men
as hopeful, and comfortable. Now in this case thou must, with as much wisdom,
and charity as thou can possibly, disrobe such a fellow of his undeserved
applause, and reputation of holiness which he never had, left the bystanders
be hardened, and the power of Christianity be disparaged.

Belial, and the sinful evaporations of wicked wits, and therefore unmeet for
the children of God.

Thirdly, pray for, and practice an holy dexterity to divert them from their
wicked, or too much worldly tal^ to more savoury conference, and heavenly

1. Observe wisely all opportunities, and occurrencies, which may minister
matter of digression into divine talk, and acquaint thy self with the Art of
abstracting holy instructions from the book of the creatures, and businesses in
kind. As was Christ practice, Matthew. 16.6, etc. John 6.26, etc. and 4.7, etc.

2. Have ever in readiness some common heads of stirring, and quickening
motives to mind heavenly things: as the cursed condition of our natural state,
the incomparable sweetness of Christian ways, the vanity and vexation of all
earthly things, the miseries of this short life, the everlastingnesse of our
state in another world, the terrors of death, the dreadfulnesse of the last
and great day, etc. which (through Gods blessing) may sometimes soften the
hardest hearts, and work in them some remorse and heavenly impressions.

3. Above all, get into thine own heart an habit of heavenly mindedness, by
much exercise, intercourse, and acquaintance with God in pouring out thy soul
ever and anon before him, and in holy meditations, and if thou be thus
blessedly busy at home with thine own heart, thou shall find thy self much
more pregnant, and plentiful in holy talk when thou come abroad. Idem.

Quest. What is meant by this that we must not familiarly converse with the
wicked?

Answ. First, Negatively: the meaning is not,

1. That we may not be in the same place with them, for then we must go out of
the world, 1 Cor. 5.10.

2. Nor that we may not do them common courtesies, as to lend to them, salute
them, Matthew. 5.47. where Christ implies that we should salute others besides
our brethren.

3. Not that we may not sometimes, upon some occasions, come into more familiar
meetings with them: as to Feasts, etc. 1 Cor. 10.27.

Secondly, Affirmatively, the meaning is,

1. That we may not upon choice, without just occasions, frequent their
company; which for their sins we should hate, Psalm. 139.21, 22.

2. That we may not delight in their society, which cannot but be a grief to a
godly heart, Psalm. 120.5. and 119.136.

3. That we may not choose them for our familiar friends.

Quest. Who are such wicked men as we may not make our companions?

Answ. First, Negatively. 1. Not such an one as is unfound at heart, but not
discovered: For one whom we may lawfully choose for our friend, may afterward

2. Nor such an one who has many weaknesses, whom we must rather restore with
the spirit of meekness, Gal. 6.1.

Secondly, Affirmatively. 1. Such as are out of the Church, as Jews, Turks,
Pagans,

2. Such as are justly excommunicated out of the Church for blasphemy, heresy,
or profannesse, 1 Cor. 5.5, 6, 7.

3. Such as, though they continue in the Church, yet by their works they show
that they are mere carnal.

Quest. But what if our near relations, ^s husband, wife, etc. are wicked?

Answ. We must distinguish of wicked persons: who are,

1. Such as are not bound to us by any special bond, and these we may not make
our companions.

2. Such to whom we are bound by consanguinity, affinity, or our civil
callings: For these we must afford them our outward presence familiarly, 1 Corinthians. 7.12, 13. Though we cannot be of one heart, and mind with them; as,
Act. 4.32.

Quest. How may it be further proved that we may not make the former our
companions?

Answ. First, because its expressly forbidden by God, Ephesians. 5.7. Prove. 1.15. and
Act. 2.40. 1 Cor. 5.11. 2 These. 3.14. As under the Law the Leprous must be
separated from the clean, Lev. 13.44. with 14.8.

precious must be separated from the vile, Jer. 15.19.

Joseph in Pharaohs Court learned to swear by the life of Pharaoh. So, Prove.
13.20. and 22.24, 25. Hence is that precept, Isa. 52.11. 2 Cor. 6.17. Prove.
6.27, 28.

Luke 13.26.

2. It makes us unable effectually to rebuke them, when we are in such a league
of familiarity with them.



Quest. May we then have no dealing with him?

Answ. Yea, we may, 1. Lawfully enter into League with them not to do them
hurt, as Isaac with Abimelech: Jacob with Laban: For the rule is, Romans 12.18.

2. To trade, and maintain commerce with them, as David, and Solomon with
Hiram, and his men.

3. We may be sometimes in familiar meetings with them to seek to gain them to
God: For the sick have need of a Physician: upon this account Christ conversed
with Publicans and sinners.

Quest. Why must we be so careful to watch over our selves in company?

Answ. First, because we often take much hurt in company, and are in far worse
case by means thereof for want of good direction, and heedfulnesse, then we
were before we came into it.



Quest. Why so?

Answ. Because in company many occasions are offered, as of glorifying, so of
dishonouring God, and of troubling and grieving our selves and others. Besides,
the tongue is an unruly member, etc. Jam. 3.1, 2, etc. and as for the heart
which sets the tongue on work, it is uncharitable, suspicious, profane,
worldly, etc. Yea, a very fountain of evil thoughts, oaths, adulteries,
slanders, etc. Mat. 15.19. Hence comes so many idle and profane speeches
whereof we must give an account in the day of judgment, Mat. 12.36. and at
best, endless talking of matters that concern wordly profit, or pleasure:
This made Job so careful to sanctify his children after their love feasts,
Job 1.5.

Quest. What particular rules are to be observed concerning our carriage in
company?

Answ. First, seeing there is such danger in it, we are not to rush unadvisedly
into it, but with fear, and trembling, and upon good occasion.

good as we are able, and to help them forward to eternal life: purposing also
to get some spiritual good to our selves, as occasion shall be offered.

Thirdly, we must resolve, if we can do no other good, at least to be
harmless, Prove. 10.20. and 20.5. Col. 3.12. 1 These. 5.23. James 5.20. Jude 20.
1 Samuel 23.16.

Quest. How may we attain unto this?

Answ. First, we must pray for grace before we go into company, as Jacob Esau,
Genesis 32.11. so we must pray that we be not infected by them.

Secondly, we should think of some profitable matter beforehand, and entreat

Thirdly, we must wisely and carefully wait for, and lay hold on the fittest
occasions

Fourthly, we must resolve not to thwart or cross others, but in the spirit of
Gal. 6.1, 2. Col. 3.12. and for that end to put on love, which envies not,
boasts not, rejoices not in iniquity, provokes not, nor is easily provoked
unto anger: but suffers long, hops all things, etc. 1 Cor. 13.4, etc. Prove.
10.12. 1 Pet. 4.8.

Quest. How shall we be furnished with matter to edify one another?

Answ. If no present occasion be offered, as was to Christ, Luke 11.27, 28. we
must have consideration, both of the things and of the persons. The things we
are to think of are either some part of Gods word which we have lately heard
preached of, or that we have read, or meditated upon, or some work of God
lately fallen out, wherein yet we must avoid the common abuse, which is either
to turn it over as table-talk, or matter of news without making any further
use thereof.

Quest. What if we cannot thus furnish our selves?

Answ. Then let us read, or cause to be read, some portion of Scripture, out of
which we may be the better furnished: And as for persons, we must consider
whether they be superiors, inferiors, or equals, whether good or bad, whether
they need instruction, reproof, quickening, or comfort, etc. that so we may
accordingly apply our speeches to their, and our own edification: as Christ
did, Luke 14.7, 8. and 11.27, 28.

Quest. Why must we be so careful thus to furnish and exercise our selves?

Answ. Because we are commanded to provoke one another to love, and good works,
Heb. 10.24. To exhort one another daily, Heb. 3.12. To redeem the time, Ephesians.
5.16.

Now a wo^ spoken in due season is like apples of Gold, etc. Prove. 25.11. Our
speec^ must be gracious always, etc. Col. 4.6. No corrupt communication must
pr^^^ed out of our mouths, etc. Ephesians. 4.29, 30. we must edify one another, 1
These. 5.11. So did Paul, Act. 26.27, 28, 29.

Quest. What if for all this we cannot bring our hearts to it?

Answ. Its better for such to keep home, to look to our families, and attend
our callings, then to go into company where we neither do, nor receive good.

Quest. What if we meet with such brutish and scornful persons as will not
endure good communication?

Answ. Then follow Christ's rule: Give not that which is holy unto dogs, etc.
Mat. 7.6. and have no fellowship with the unfruitful works of darkness, Ephesians.
5.11. Yet withal, we must wisely bear, and seek to win them: but if we cannot
prevail, we must follow Solomon's rule, Prove. 14.7. Depart from the company of
a foolish man, when thou see not in him the words of wisdom.

Practice of Christianity.

Quest. What other reason may be rendered why we should so carefully shun evil
company?

Answ. Because the Scripture teaches us to shun all sinful occasions, as well
as actions: therefore we must keep out of the way.

Quest. Seeing there is so much danger by bad company, what must we do that
live in bad times and places?

Answ. First, look to thy grace that it be true, and then thou may be sure
Joseph did in the Court of wicked Pharaoh: Nehemiah in the Court of Artaxerxes:
Obadiah in Ahabs Court: Daniel in Nebuchadnezzars: Abijah in wicked, and
idolatrous Jeroboams house: and the Saints in Nero's household.

Isaiah, chapter 6.5. and David, Psalm. 120.5. and Lot, 2 Pet. 2.7, 8.

Phil. 2.15. As stars shine brightest in a dark night, and fire burns hottest
in a frosty day: so should our profession shine brightest in the darkest
places; and our zeal burn hottest when the love of many waxes cold?

Abraham did his lie by his being in Gerar, Genesis 20.11. Its the badnesse of thy
heart, not of the place that makes thee bad. As no place, though never so good,
can exempt a man from sin: the Angels sinned in heaven, Adam in Paradise,
Judas in Christ's family: so no place, though never so bad, can excuse a man
from sin.



Noscitur ex socio qui non cognoscitur ex se, Deuteronomy. 22.10.

Master Love of Grace.

Quest. Whether is company better then solitariness?

Answ. Though there be a fit time for solitariness, and every thing is
beautiful in its season: yet civil conversation is to be preferred before
solitariness, as tending more to the glory of God, the advancement and
enlarging of the Kingdom of Christ, the good both of Church and Commonwealth
with all the members of them, and our own present comfort, and future joy,
which is much augmented, when by our Christian conversation, and virtuous
actions, our holy profession, and good example, our admonitions, exhortations,
counsel, consolation; our works of justice, and charity, and by all other good
Offices mutually performed, we build up those that are about us in their most
holy faith, and draw many to accompany us to the Kingdom of Heaven: Hence,
Genesis 2.18. Its not good for man to be alone, Eccles. 4.9, 10. Two are better
then one, etc. and Saint Paul lays it as a charge upon all. Heb. 10.24, 25. To
provoke one another to love and good works, etc.

Quest. How may this be further proved?

Answ. First, God commends it to us by his works of creation: For he has made
us in our natures political, and sociable creatures, who take comfort in
conversing together.

Secondly, in his wise providence he has so disposed of us that we should not

Thirdly, God has linked all men together into society, as it were particular

Fourthly, in our renovation, we are, as it were, anew created into one body,
Corinth. 12.1, 15, 25, 26.

Quest. What are the benefits which redound to the whole body, and to all
particular members hereby?

Answ. First, hereby they are linked together by the same Spirit, and in the
bond of love to perform all mutual Offices of Christian charity which may
advance

Secondly, they communicate in the same blessings, and rejoice in one another

Thirdly, they stir up Gods graces in one another, both by word, and good
example, helping to remove impediments that lie in the way, and exhorting

Quest. How must we prepare our selves before we go into company?

Answ. First, when we are free, and left to our choice, we must choose such
company as in all likelihood may either do us good, or at least receive some

Secondly, we must also pray to God to give us his grace, and holy Spirit,

Thirdly, seeing the enemy of our salvation lays nets and snares to entrap us
in

Fourthly, we must not propound this as our end, to pass away the time, and to

Fifthly, we must put off, and cast from us turbulent passions, and disordered
affections, love; See the benefits of it, 1 Cor. 13.4, 5, 6, 7. and with it we
must put on the spirit of meekness, and patience to put up injuries, and pass
by offenses, and to bear with infirmities: The spirit of humility, etc.

Quest. Being thus prepared, what must our carriage be in company?

Answ. First, we must sincerely seek Gods glory, and our own salvation;
shunning

Matthew. 5.16. so we are exhorted, 1 Pet. 2.12. so did Paul behave himself, 1
These. 2.10.

Phil. 4.8, 9. This the Gospel teaches us, Tit, 2.12.

Romans 13.8, 10. Col. 3.14.

Pet. 3.8. Romans 12.15. Phil. 3.16. and to walk by the same rule, so far as
will stand with truth and justice.

Romans 12.16. but condescending to men of low degree in the truth, and in things
indifferent, and of small moment: or if we dissent, to do it in a meek and
peaceable manner.

Romans 12.17, 21. For which end we must follow Saint Paul counsel, Col. 3.12, 13.

Quest. But what if through accident, or our necessary occasions, we fall into
ill company?

Answ. Then we must not hide our profession, lest Christ be ashamed of us, Mat.
10.33. nor applaud them in their wicked courses, endure their reproaches and
ta^nts at Religion, countenance their swearing, or profane jests with our
smiles, much less run with them into the same excess of riot, 1 Pet. 4.4.
but rather labor to reclaim them, and gain them to Christ. For which end we
must.

1. See that in all our carriage we be unblamable, Phil. 2.15. that they may
have nothing to say against us, Tit. 2.7, 8. Thus we are exhorted, 1 Pet. 3.15,
16.

2. We must walk worthy our high calling, Ephesians. 4.1. adorning our profession by
our holiness, and righteousness, that if possible we may win them to Christ,
Matthew. 5.16. 1 Pet. 2.11, 12.

3. If by all this they will not be reclaimed, yet we must not mingle spleen,
and choler with our zeal, but behave our selves meekly, with patience and
forbearance. For, Jam. 1.20. the wrath of man does not accomplish the
righteousness of God. Hence we are so much pressed to peaceablenesse, Romans
12.18. yet may we not for peace-sake betray the truth, or forgo our own piety.
We must follow peace with holiness, Heb. 12.14. and not neglect the things
whereby we may edify one another, Romans 14.19. We must not bear with those
that are evil, Rev. 2.2.

4. We must not by such wicked company be discouraged from any good, not be
moved to neglect any Christian duty which present occasion makes necessary.

Mr. Downams Guide to godliness.

Quest. Why must we at other times carefully shun the society of the wicked?

Answ. First, Because its frequently forbidden in the Scripture: As Prove. 4.14,
15^ Ephesians. 5.11. 2 These. 3.6. 1 Cor. 5.11. 2 Cor. 6.14. See the danger of it in
David's matching with scoffing Mechol, 1 Samuel 18.21.

Jehorams marrying with Ahabs daughter, 2 Samuel 6.16, 10.

Secondly, we have the examples of the godly studiously declining such company:
Of Elisha, 2 King. 3.14. of David, Psalm. 26.45. and 101.4, 7. and 6.8. and

Thirdly, There are many reasons to enduce us to it: For

1. We are in great danger in a short time to grow, like unto them: For sin is
of a contagious nature, and we are most apt to receive infection, and they will
endeavor to entice us, Prove. 1.10, 11, 12. This David know, and therefore
resolves against such company, Psalm. 119.115. and prays to God for assistance,
Psalm. 141.4. See the danger of keeping such company in these examples, Act.
13.8. Pro. 22.24, 25. Gen 42.15, 16. the reason is rendered by Paul, 1 Cor. 5.6.

2. Such society argues strongly that we are not truly religious, and upright
in heart, but that we still halt between God and the World, For Prove. 29.27. An
unjust (...) is an abomination to the just, and be that is upright in his way
is an abomination to the wicked. See also, Joh. 14.9. Joh. 1.15.

Quest. Whom then must we consort ourselves with all?

Answ. First, With those that are godly, and virtuous, as being a singular
furtherance to all christian duties, Prove. 13.20. Hereby we may edify one
another, Heb. 10.24. For the more we converse with such, the greater increase
we shall find of one piety, faith, love, zeal, etc. as coals laid together do
kindle one another. So we see in the example of David, who rejoiced in the
society of such Psa. 16.3. Psa. 119.63, 79. Hence Psalm. 222.1. when the Church
flourished most, and did thrive in grace, and godliness they thus conversed
together,, Acts 2.46. and 9.31.

Quest. What other arguments may provoke us to make choice of such company?

Answ. it takes away the tediousness of our journey, when we have such Mat.
18.20. where two or three are gathered together in his name, Christ is in the
midst to make himself known to them.

Secondly, Good company preserves us from falling into many sins, and inciteth
Prove. 27.17. For as iron sharpens Iron, so does the face of a man his friend:
Saul himself prophesied by keeping company with the Prophets, much more are
Gods children inflamed, and provoked to good by such company.

Thirdly, Hereby we are the better fitted, and enabled to perform all Christian

1. Of watching one over another, that we may take all occasions of doing good,
by restraining such as are ready to fall, and provoking each other to all
virtuous actions, Heb. 10.24. we must strengthen our brethren, Luke 22.32. So
Phil. 2.4.

2. Of instruction, whereby with all readiness we inform the ignorant, and
enlighten them in the knowledge of God, and his truth, Act. 26.18. Reclaim the
erroneous: exhorted to, Jam. 5.20. Turn many to righteousness, and therefore
shall shine in the kingdom of God, Dan. 12.3.

3. Of admonition, whereby we put our brethren in mind of their duty, Romans
15.14. 1 Th^s. 5.14. either when through forgetfulness they fall into sin, or
omit the duties of Gods service.

4. Of reproof, whereby we rebuke them that wilfully fall into sin, and
continue in it without amendment, required, Epes. 5.11. otherwise we make our
selves accessory to their sins. So Mat. 18.15. Yea otherwise we hate them, Lev.
19.17.

5. Of Exhortation, whereby we incite, and provoke them to all duties of
godliness, quickening those which are dull: dissuading from sin those which are
ready to fall, and encouraging those that run well in their Christian course:
as Heb. 3.13. Exhort one another daily, etc.

6. Of Consolation, whereby we strengthen the weak hands, and feeble knees,
Heb. 12.12. and refresh with seasonable comforts such as are ready to faint
under the burden of their afflictions: as 1 These. 5.11, 14. Romans 12.14. For its
an ease to those that are in misery, to have companions in their sufferings.

7. Of Counsel, whereby we advise those, who of themselves know not what to
do: and this sometimes the weaker may perform to the stronger, as Abigail did
to David: because lookers on being free from prejudice, and passion, can see
more clearly then those that are interested in the business.

8. Of good example, by which, shining before them in the light of an holy
conversation, we do not only show them the way to Heaven, but (as it were) take
them by the hand, and lead them in it. So Mat. 5.16. 1 Pet. 2.12. and 3.1.

Mr. Downams Guide to godliness.

CHAP. XXXIX. Questions, and Cases of Conscience about Confession.
Quest. IS confession a duty that God requires of Christians?

Answ. Yea, its a Gospel-duty that we should confess with our mouths as well
as believe with our hearts, Romans 10.10.

Quest. What is this confession required?

Answ. Its an open profession of Christ, and his Gospel, his truths and ways,
and a pleading for the same.

Quest. What must we confess concerning Christ?

Answ. First, his Natures; as his Divinity and Humanity: So did the woman
Canaan, Matthew. 15.22. John the Baptist, Joh. 1.20, 27, 34. the Eunuch, Act. 8.
37. Peter, Joh. 6.69.

Secondly, his Offices: so did Nathaniel, Mat. 16.16. the woman of Samaria,
John the Baptist, John 1.29.

Thirdly, his beauty, excellency, and dignity: So did the Church, Cant. 5. John
the Baptist, Joh. 1.20, 27. and 3.28. to 33. so the Saints, Rev. 5.11, 12, 13.

Fourthly, especially such things concerning Christ as others deny, or doubt
of: Act. 4.2. Romans 10.9. Act. 24.15. and 23.6.

Quest. What else must we confess in reference to Christ?

Answ. First, our faith in him, and his Gospel: So, Mark 9.24. Joh. 9.38. Act.
24.15. Isa. 45.23, 24. Our interest in God and Christ. So, Job 19.25, etc. Joh.
20.28. Cant. 2.16.

Secondly, our grace received from Christ, and of the work, and workings of it:
Cor. 15.10. 1 Timothy 1.13, 14. 1 King. 18.12. John 21.16. Psalm. 43.4. Gal. 6.14.
2 Cor. 12.10.

Thirdly, our worshipping of God after a Gospel manner, purely, and spiritually
Acts 24.13, 14.

Fourthly, our practice, or manner of life: what is the constant bent of our
resolutions, Psalm. 66.16. 1 John 1.1, 3. Thus relations of experiences are
confessions of Christ before men: So also to bear witness aagainst sin,
though with our own danger: So did John the Baptist, Mark 6.18, 27.

Quest. When must we thus make confession?

Answ. When we are called thereunto either publicly, or privately.

Quest. How may we be called publicly to it?

Answ. Either by the Church, or by the Magistrate.

Quest. When are we called to it by a Church?

Answ. Either at the constitution of it; or at our admission into it.

Quest. How are we called to confession at the constitution of a Church?

Answ. As Christ makes the confession of Faith to be the foundation upon which
his visible Church is built, Mat. 16.16. to 19. whence two things may be
collected.

1. That a good confession of faith in Christ should be made, and laid as a
foundation at the gathering, or constituting of a Church, which may be
effectual to keep the Members sound in the faith, and to engage them to hold
fast their principles.

2. That those are the fittest stones for the building of a Church, that can
give the best account of their faith in Christ.

Quest. How are we called to confession at our admittance into a Church?

Answ. At our admission into a Church, to which we desire to join our selves,
being required to give an account of our faith and holiness, we should be free
and ready to do it.

Quest. How may that be proved?

Answ. First, because, as to believe with the heart, makes a man a member of
the invisible Church, so to confess with the mouth, qualifies him to be a
member of the visible Church of Christ.

Jerusalem was of Paul, Act. 9.26, 27.

Act. 2.41.

Pet. 2.5.

Quest. How are we called to this public confession by a Magistrate?

Answ. When we are brought before Rulers, and Governors for Christ's sake, and
examined about our religion, then we ought to bear witness to Christ, and his
truth, as Christ, and his Apostles did, John 18.37. 1 Timothy 6.1. Luke 22.70.
Mark 14.61, 62. So Act. 4.5, to 16. and 5.27, to 33. Act. 6.12.15. and 24.14.
to 22. and 26.2, etc. and 24.25, etc.

Quest. When are we called to it privately?

Answ. First, when we are asked by a single person, who desires information,
and lays not a snare for us, 1 Pet. 3.15. so did Christ, Joh. 4.15, 26. and
10.24, etc. and 7.35, etc.

Jude 3. we are set for the defense of the Gospel, Phil. 1.17. Act. 19.29. and
17.18, 24, etc. and 15.2. and 6.9, 10, etc. Hence, Phil. 1.27.

etc. and to speak as much for them as others do against them, yea, to outspeak
them, and put them to silence.

Quest. Why ought we to make confession with the mouth?

Answ. First, in regard of God: and that,

1. Because its an homage, and service that God requires of us, Isa. 45.23.
with Romans 14.11.

2. God the Father did confess, and give testimony by a voice from heaven to
his Son Christ Jesus, Matthew. ^.17. and 17.5. So Christ says, John 5.32, 37.
and 8.18. and herein we should be followers of God, as dear children, Ephesians.
5.1.

3. Hereby we give glory to God, Phil. 2.11. Joh. 7.19. Romans 15.6.

Secondly, in respect of Christ, and that

1. Because its Christ's privilege to be confessed, or an honorary that was
conferred on him by God for his deep humiliation, Phil. 2.9, 10. and not to
confess him, is to rob him of that glory which is peculiar to him.

2. It was Christ's practice, both in life and death. He confessed his Father,
John 1.18. and 8.38. that God is a spirit, John 4.24. How he will be
worshipped: John 15.15. and 3.32. He did bear witness to the truth, Joh.
18.37. Hence Rev. 1.5. and 3.14.

Thirdly, in regard of our selves: and that,

1. Because we are Gods witnesses, Isa. 43.10. To this end God gives us more
Mat. 13.16. Its our honor to be witnesses of Christ, Joh. 1.7. and 21.24. 2
Cor 11.5. Act. 26.16. and 9.15.

2. If we confess God, and Christ, and his truth, we shall be confessed by
both.

1. By the Father, who will own and avouch us to be his people, portion,
jewels, friends, etc. and that, 1. Before men: If we testify for God, he will
give testimony of us, as he did of Abraham, Abel, Moses, Daniel, Enoch, etc.
Heb. 11.4, 5. Hence Gods servants have appealed to God to be their witness,
Job 16.19. Psalm. 139.23, 24. and 7.8. and 26.1, 2. If we plead for God, he will
plead for us; as, Numb. 12.8. Job. 42.7. Lam. 3.58. Psalm. 37.6. 2. Before
Devils. So, Job 1.8. and 2.4.


2. By the Son: If we confess Christ, he will confess us, Mat. 10.32. Luke
12.8.

3. If we confess God and Christ we shall be encouraged, defended, and
honored even here.

1. We shall be encouraged and strengthened by Christ too, and in our testimony,
Act. 18.9. and 23.10, 11. 2 Timothy 4.^6, ^7. 2. We shall be defended, and
delivered from the assaults, and designs of our enemies, Acts 18.9, 10. and
26.16, 17. and 23.10, 11, 20, 21. 2 Timothy 4.17. 3. If we honor God by
confession, he will honor us, and that 1. With favor, affection, and respect
from men, 1 Pet. 4.14. Act. 4.33. Rev. 3.8, 9. 2. With victory over Satan, Rev.
12.10, 11. 3. Yea, God will honor us with mutual inhabitation, which implies
intimate communion, 1 John 4.15.

4. If we confess Christ aright, we shallbe saved. Confession tends to
salvation.

1. As a way appointed us to God, to walk in toward heaven. 2. As a character,
property, and practice of such as shall be saved. 3. As a furtherance of our
salvation, because its a means, or help to our perseverance in the faith, even
to the end: and then, Mat. 24.13. Heb. 10.23.


Quest. How must this confession be made?

Answ. First, freely, without compulsion* as water flows out of the Fountain.

Joh. 1.19, 20. Hence our confession of Christ should flow from faith as the
fountain, and that

1. From our Faith in Christ. Confession with the mouth should proceed from
Faith in the heart, 2 Cor. 4.13. Psalm. 116.10.

Object. But, Romans 14.22. Have thou Faith, have it to thy self, before God,
therefore we need not confess it before men?

Answ. Paul there speaks not of a justifying Faith, but of a Faith, or
persuasion of Christian liberty in things indifferent: This Faith a man may
keep to himself, or so show or use it, as thereby not to offend his brother.

2. From out experience in some measure of Christ, and his grace, or of what we
confess: This will provoke us to a confession before men, as Act. 4.18, etc. So
1 John 1.1. Christ gave his Apostles experience, and Paul, Act. 26.16.

Acts 23.6. with 24.21. and 20.23, 24. and 21.13. Phil. 1.20. Its our honor so
to do, Act. 5.41. and 4.8, etc. Psalm. 119.46, 2 Samuel 6.20, etc.

Rev. 11.7. and Paul, 2 Timothy 4.7. Act. 23.25. Hence, Rev. 3.3. This Christ
takes kindly, Rev. 2.13. and 3.8, 10.

Act. 24.20 and 23.9. For which end we must do it.

1. With meekness, from an humble spirit, without any show of pride,
ostentation, passion, or bitterness.

2. With fear of God, of offending him whilst we are confessing him, or doing,
or saying any thing which may cause the way of truth to be evil spoken of: And
with reverence of men, by giving all due respect to them before whom we speak.



1. Out of love to Christ, and his truth: For what we love we will own openly
Cant. 5.9. Love is strong as death, etc.

2. Out of zeal for God, his glory, the credit of his cause, the honor of his
truth, the propagation of his Gospel, the encouragement and comfort of his
friends, and the conviction of his enemies.

Mat. 10.37, etc. Joh. 9.22. Rev. 1.9. and 11.3, 7.10. and 12.17. and 20.4.

Mr. Reyners Government of the tongue.

Quest. Whether is it lawful for a man being urged to go to Idol-service, and
to hear Mass, so he keep his heart unto God?

Answ. It is not, as may be proved by these reasons.

Paul, 1 Cor. 8. and the 10. Chap. disputes this question, whether they might
go into the Idol temples, and there eat of meat offered to them, so they did
not partake with Idolaters in the worship of their Idols? This he concludes
utterly unlawful; for they could not partake of the Lords cup, and the cup of
devils: so is it unlawful for a Protestant to go to the Popish Mass.

Romans 12.1. we must give up our bodies a living sacrifice unto God.

Object. Against this some object the example of Naaman, 2 Kin. 5.18, 19* where
they infer, that the Prophet gave Naaman leave to worship in an Idol-Temple?

Answ. First, Some answer that Naaman speaks only of civil, and Politic
worship: For his Office was to kneel down that the King might lean on his
shoulder: and Naaman makes open protestation, ver. 7. that he will Worship no
God but the God of Israel.

Secondly, Others answer better, that Naaman acknowledges it a sin to go the
Rimmon, and therefore craves pardon for it twice, verse 18. and withal, vows
that thenceforth he would offer sacrifice to no God, save only to the Lord.

Thirdly, Naaman entreats the Prophet to pray for him, that he might be
constant in the service of the true God: and that in case, through humane
frailty, he

Object. But if I do not go to mass, I shall give offense to the Papists?

Answ. We are to do our duty, though men be never so much offended, Mat.
15.14. Again* we ought not to do evil, that good may come of it.

Quest. Whether may a man, especially a Minister, with a good conscience fly in
persecution?

Answ. Sometimes it is lawful, though not always: For

First, Christ commands it, Matthew. 10.15. neither was this command ever
repealed.

Secondly, We have many examples for it in Scripture, of Jacob, Genesis 27. and
Moses, Exodus 2.15. Heb. 11.27. of the Prophets hidden by Obadiah, 1 Kin. 18.13.
of Elijah, 1 Kin, 19.3. of Christ himself, Joh. 10.39. of Paul, Act. 9.25.29,
30.

Object. Persecution is good, and therefore it may not be eschewed?

Answ. First, Some things are simply good of themselves, as virtues, and all

Object. Persecution is sent of God for the trial, and good of his Church?

Answ. First, Evil things sent of God, may be avoided, if he show us a way, or
means to escape them.

Secondly, There is a two fold will of God, his revealed will, and his secret

Object. To fly in persecution is a kind of denial of Christ, and against
confession?

Answ. Christian confession is twofold: first, Open. Secondly, implicit.

1. Open confession is when a man boldly confesses his faith before the
adversary even unto death: as the Martyrs did.

2. Implicit, which though it be inferior to the former, yet its a true
confession, and acceptable unto God: and this is when a man to keep his
religion, is content to forsake his Country, friends, and goods.

Object. But Christ bids us not to fear them that can but kill the body,
therefore we may not fly? Mat. 10.28.

Answ. First, This forbids not all fear, but such a fear as tends to
Appostacy, causing men to renounce faith, and a good conscience.





Quest. When may a man, Minister, or other fly?

Answ. First, When there is no hope of doing good by his abode in that place,
where the persecution is: but not when there is hope: at such a time God forbad
it Paul, Act. 18.10.



Quest. But what if the people will not suffer him to fly?

Answ. They should be so far from hindering him, that they should rather further
him: So Acts 19.30. But if the persecution be public, then he is not to fly:
For then the strong should support and confirm the weak.



Mat. 10.23.









Quest. When may not a Pastor, or other man fly?

Answ. First, when God puts into their heart the spirit of courage, and Paul,
Act. 20.22. and 21.13. One in Queen Mary's days having this motion to stand
out, and yet flying, for the very act, felt such a sting in his conscience,
that he could never have peace till he died.



Quest. Whether then may a man imprisoned, break prison if he can.

Answ. No man being in durance may use any unlawful, or violent means to
escape: for we may not resist the Magistrate in our sufferings. Servants must
submit to the unjust corrections of their Masters, 1 Pet. 2.19. the Apostles
would not so escape when they might; till the Angel brought them forth, Act.
5.19.

may glorify God, and do good to his Church: For the discharge of the duties
of our callings must be preferred before our very lives.

Fourthly, When God by his Providence cuts off all lawful means,

Mr. Perkins Vol. 2. p. 86*

See more of the lawfulness of flight in Persecution in the life of Athanasius
in my first part of Lives.

CHAP. XL. Questions, and Cases of Conscience about confession of sin.
Quest. IS confession of sin a necessary duty?

Answ. Yea, or else God would never have promised so great a reward to it, as 1 John 1.9* Job comforted himself with it, Job 31.33. So Psalm. 2.5. Ut somnium
narrare vigilantis; Sic peccata confiteri viri paenitentis est. Aug. To tell a
man's dream is the sign of a waking man, so to confess his sins, of a true
penitent.

Quest. May not a wicked man confess his sins?

Answ. Yea, as we see Pharaoh, Saul, Judas, etc. did.

Quest. How then shall we distinguish between the confession of a regenerate,
and unregenerate man?

Answ. By these signs.

First, True confession comes from a troubled soul, as we see in the Publican:
David's: From a melting heart, as did Josiahs. But the other knows it not: the
racking pain only wrings it from him, not the mercy of that God whom he has
offended.

Secondly, The first proceeds from a bleeding heart, laying hold upon mercy: as
Dan. 9.9. Ezra 10.2. the other wants this, therefore Christ says, Repent and
believe,

Thirdly, It comes from an honest heart in the first, purposing not to sin: He
confesses, and forsakes, Prove. 28.1^. Hence Ezra 10.2, 3. The other though he
Deuteronomy. 1.40, 41. Dike on the Heart.

Quest. Why must we remember, and confess our sins?

Answ. First, Because promise of forgiveness is made to it, Prove. 28.13. 1 John

Secondly, God has made good this promise upon the right performance of it,
Sam. 12.13. Psalm. 32.5.

3. Threats are denounced against those that confess not their sins, Prove.
28.13. Joh. 1.8, 10. Dr. Gouge on Heb.

Quest. In confessing our sins, must we descend into particulars?

Answ. Yea, so did David, 2 Samuel 24.10. So Ezra 9.6, 11. Nehem. 9.1. etc. Dan.
9.5, 6, 11, 13. Mat. 3.6. 1 Timothy 1.13. Act. 19.18, 19.

Quest. Why must we do this?

Answ. First, This is the next way to bring us to that measure of humiliation
which is necessary: Hence Acts 2.36. and 3.14, etc.

Cor. 11.31. If we would judge our selves, we should not be judged, etc. Hieron
^n Psalm. 51.

Quest. Is it a (...) to confess our sins to men also?

Answ. Yea, so Jam. 5.16. confess your faults one to another: not only to the
Elders of the Church, but to your brethren also: therefore its no ground for
Popish auricular confession, wherein they require that every one, at least once
a year, should in the ear of a Priest confess all his sins, together with the
circumstances of them: a politic invention to know the secrets of others, to
keep them in awe, and to enslave their consciences.

Quest. In what cases then is confession to be made to others?

Answ. First, In case of scandal given by persons before, or after their
reception into the Church and fellowship of the Gospel.

1. Before their admission: such as desire admittance, having formerly
committed gross sins, should solemnly acknowledge their sinful courses, and
godly sorrow for them, and their resolution against them for the future, to
give satisfaction to the Church, that God has wrought a change in them. So
Matthew. 3.6. Act. 15.18, 20.

2. After their admission, such as give offense by walking disorderly, either
to the whole Church, or to some particular members of it, they (...) to confess
their faults to the whole society, or to the persons to whom the ^ame is known,
to testify their repentance, that such as know their sin, may know their
sorrow also: And 1. If the offense be public: by their open confession to
preserve the credit of the society, and roll away the infamy from it, that it
may not be accounted an ulcerous body: and also thereby to warn others to fear,
least they offend. 2. If the offending brother be cast out, or the brethren
withdraw from him they may receive satisfaction by the free, and hearty
confession of his offense, and receive him to fellowship again, and renew their
love toward him, as 2 Cor. 2.6, 7.8. yea, to forgive, and comfort him, lest he
be swallowed up by overmuch sorrow.


Matthew. 5.23, 24. Luke 17.34.





1. Of a common judgment, when a man by his sin has had a special hand in
pulling down the same: as Achan, Josh. 7. then he must confess it both to God,
and before men, So Jon. 1.10.

2. Of a particular affliction: as sickness, etc. then also its good not only
to confess our sin to God, but to men also: as Jam. 5.14, 15.16.

Fifthly, In case of reproof from others, when they tell us of our faults, Sam.
12.7, 8.13.

Sixthly, In case of co-partnership with othe^s in sin: when any one of their
consciences are awakened, he should confess his sin to his fellow-drunkard,
thief, etc. to awaken them, and so to help them out of the snares of the Devil.
So Genesis 42.21, 22. Luke 23.39, 40.

Seventhly, To magnify the riches of Gods free grace to us, though we have
Paul, 1 Timothy 1 13. Acts 22.4, 5. and 26.9.10.11.

Eighthly, To prevent sin in others: when by confessing the sins, and the evil
we have found in them, we may make them to beware thereof. So its useful for
Malefactors at their execution to confess their sins that others may be warned.

Quest. Are we bound to confess every sin to others?

Answ. First, We are bound absolutely to confess every known sin to God, but

Secondly, We are bound to confess such sins to others, as are open, or known
to them, not our secret sins: as 1. Our bosom-sins, we need not to confess but
to God alone, Psalm. 19.12. 2. Secret sins, unknown to men, we may conceal
them. 1. Whilst Providence covers them. 2. Whilst Conscience is quiet: But when
God in his Providence brings them to light, or our consciences, being awaked,
terrify and affright us, so that we can have no ease till we have acknowledged
them, then we are to confess our sins, though we suffer for it.
3. Yet sometimes we may confess our secret sins to others, to obtain ease,
comfort, counsel, prayers, etc.


Quest. Who are the persons, to whom we must confess our faults?

Answ. First, to such persons, or societies, whom we have injured, and
scandalized, or consociated in sin with them.

Secondly, Our secret sins we should confess to ministers, as to our Spiritual
Physicians, or to such others as we judge wise, godly, and faithful.

Quest. But hereby we may loose our credit, and lie under a blot?

Answ. If thou choosest such to confess to, it will not prejudice thy credit:

1. Such will consider themselves, that they also may be tempted, and may be
forced to do the like, and therefore what they would that others should do to
them, they will do to thee, Mat. 7.12.

2. It will rather tend to our credit: For it will represent to them the
tenderness of our consciences, humility, hatred of sin, and fear of offending.

Quest. From what principles, or in what manner should we confess our sins to
others?

Answ. First, Out of zeal for God, to give him glory before men, and that 1.
Of his Omnisciency, in knowing our most secret sins. 2. Of his Providence in
detesting them. 3. Of his justice in punishing, or righteousness, and
faithfulness in afflicting us for them. 4. Free grace in pardoning them, and in
accepting, employing, and saving us from them. 5. Patience in sparing us, and
mercy in doing us good, notwithstanding our sins against him.


Secondly, Out of hatred against sin, we must confess with grief, hatred, and



Paul, 2 Cor. 12.6.

Quest. Why are men so backward to confess sin?

Answ. First, because it brings shame, and grief along with it, which sin
cannot endure. For sin has so perverted the soul, as to misplace shame in the
acknowledging offenses, which should be placed in offending.



Joh. 3.20. Sin loves to wear a veil of secrecy, or a vizard of counterfeit
piety, or a garment of excuses: to wrap it self (like the Devil in Samuels
Mantle, that the filthy shame of its nakedness may not appear.

Quest. Why should we confess sin, seeing its so filthy, and shameful a thing
that it becomes not Saints once to name it?

Answ. First, though sin be filthy it it self, yet the confession of it is
clean, and commendable.

1. With delight, and boasting of it, and indulgence to it: This is prohibited
to Saints. 2. With detestation of it, indignation at it, and grief for it: this
is commanded.


Prove. 28.13. and 29.1.

Origin, Austin, etc. have been free in publishing their sins, and errors in
judgment to the world.

Mr: Reiners Government of the tongue.

CHAP. XLI. Questions, and Cases of Conscience about carnal Confidence.
Quest. WHat carnal confidence is particularly forbidden in Scripture?

Answ. First, trusting in riches, Job. 31.24. 1 Timothy

Secondly, in men, Psalm. 118.8. Though Princes, v. 9.

Thirdly, In strength of a City, Prove. 21.22.

Fourthly, in our relations, Mich. 7.5.

Fifthly, in Gods enemies, Jer. 2.37. Hos. 14.3.

Sixthly, in places of idolatrous worship, Jer. 48.13.

Seventhly, in the flesh, Phil. 3.3.

Quest. What reasons does the Scripture give against it?

Answ. First, all such confidence shall be rooted out, Job 18.14.

Secondly, its punishable, Job. 31.28.

Thirdly, it argues great folly, Prove. 14.16.

Fourthly, its deceitful, Prove. 25.19.

Fifthly, its rejected by God, Jer. 2.37.

Quest. Why have men naturally confidence in outward things?

Answ. Their hearts being not filled with grace, they relish not Christ, but
fly to these outward things for refuge. Thus the Jews boasted in the name of
Holy people, their Law, Temple, Holy Land, etc. and many amongst us, of hearing
the word, receiving the Sacrament, uncovering the head, bowing the knee, etc.
Yet all these could not save them from captivity, nor us from destruction.

Quest. Why are men taken up with carnal confidence in these things?

Answ. First, because outward things are easy, and men cannot endure to apply

Secondly, they are glorious, and men desire to be taken notice of.

Thirdly, men have a foolish conceit that God is pleased with the outward act,

Fourthly, men want knowledge of themselves, an inward change, a sense of their

Quest. How shall we know whether our confidence is carnal, or no?

Answ. First, Where this carnal confidence is, there is bitterness of spirit
against sincerity: None persecuted Christ more then the Scribes and Pharisees
which sat in Moses chair, etc.



Dr. Sibs on Phil. 3.3.

Isa. 30.1, 2, 3, etc. and 31.1, etc.

Fourthly, when we rest our souls upon meaner things, never seeking to Divine

Fifthly, when men love to sleep in a whole skin, and therefore will take the

1. The creature yields not that we expect it should: there is falsehood in
these things; they promise much, and perform little, and so deceive them that
trust in them.

2. They are mutable, and subject to change: All things come to an end save God
who is unchangeable.

3. They are snares and baits to draw us away from God by reason of the vanity
of our hearts, which are vainer then the things themselves, Psalm. 62.9. Eccl.
1.1.

Quest. How may we prevent or cure this carnal confidence?

Answ. A right apprehension of God will do it. For the more, or less that we
conceive of God as we should do, so the more, or less we disclaim confidence
in the creature, They who in their affections of love, joy, affiance, and
delight, are taken up too much with the creature (say what they will) they
profess to all the world by their practice that they know not God: But the who
know and apprehend him in his greatness and goodness, in that proportion they
withdraw their hearts from the creature, and all things else. As in a pair of
balances, so where God weighs down in the soul, all other things are light; and
where other things prevail, there God is set light by. Dr. Sibs on Hosea.

Quest. What is confidence?

Answ. Its a certainty that we conceive of a future desired good, or of the
love, and fidelity of a person, whereby the heart is filled with joy and love.

Quest. What is the only subject proper for man's entire confidence?

Answ. God, All-good, Almighty, and All-wise, without him all things that men
use to repose their confidence upon are waves and quicksands. Men are mutable,
and though they could give good security for the constancy of their wills, they
can give none for the continuance of their life. The goods of the earth fail
our expectation, or come short of our satisfaction, or slip from our
possession: they will leave us, or we them: No wonder then if they that repose
their full and whole confidence in them are seen so often to fall into
despair. Here then the true counsel for tranquillity is to trust wholly upon
none but God, on other things according to their nature and capacity: they
shall never deceive us if we require nothing of them above their nature.

Confidence is good according to the goodness of the subject that it reposeth
upon: wherefore confidence in God the only sovereign good, perfect, solid,
immutable, is the best of all, and the only thing that can give assurance, and
content to the soul. He that is blessed with that confidence is half in Paradise
already: He is firm, safe, meek, serene, and too strong for all his enemies,
Psalm. 84.12. God is to him a Sun to give him light, heat, life, and plenty of
all goods: and a Shield to guard him, and shelter him from all evils: He gives
him grace in this life, and glory in the next. O Lord of Hosts, blessed is the
man that trusts in thee.

Dr. Du Moulin of contentment.

CHAP. XLII. Questions, and Cases of Conscience about the Conflict, or combat
between the flesh, and Spirit.
Quest. HOw will it appear that there is such a conflict in every regenerate
person?

Answ. By plain Testimonies of Scripture, as Gal. 5.17. The flesh lusts
against the Spirit, and the Spirit against the flesh, etc. Romans 7.19, 22.23.

Quest. What is the Spiritual conflict?

Answ. Its nothing else but a continual combat between the unregenerate part,
the flesh, with the lusts thereof, and the part regenerate, the Spirit, with
all the holy qualities, graces, and motions thereof, by reason of their
contrariety in nature, and conjunction in place, whereby they mutually lust,
and strive one against the other, the flesh willing, and embracing that evil,
which the Spirir nilleth and hates: and nilling, and shunning that good, which
the Spirit wills, and affects, and contrariwise. For in this conflict they
mutually assault each other with irreconcilable hatred, so that as the one
gets, the other loses, as one gath^rs strength, the other is weakened: as
in a pair of Scales, when own rises the other falls: they are like light, and
darkness, etc.

Quest. What are the causes of this Conflict?

Answ. The principal cause is Gods will for the manifestation of his own
glory: For which purpose he does not perfect our sanctification in this life;
but in part regenerating, and leaving us in part unregenerated.

Quest. But why did not the Lord (who could easily have done it) perfect
sanctification in us at first, as he did by his only word at first create, and
make us perfect?

Answ. Were there no other reason but that good pleasure of his most wise will,
it were sufficient to satisfy us. For he best knows what to give, and when to
give: But yet diverse reasons may be assigned for it: as

First, This course is most profitable, both for the setting forth of Gods
glory,

Quest. How does it more manifest, and magnify Gods glory?

Answ. that the weaker we are in our regenerate part, and the stronger the
flesh is, and all other the enemies of our salvation, the more clearly Gods
wisdom shines forth in strengthening this weak part, and enabling it to stand
in the day of battle: Yea, in causing it to obtain a full and final victory,
putting all its mighty enemies to flight. This moved the Lord to suffer the
prick in the flesh to molest Paul, 2 Cor. 12.9. that his grace might be
perfected in the Apostles weakness.

2. God is more glorified when as we, seeing the strength of our natural
corruptions, and our frailty, and the many infirmities of our spiritual part,
are moved hereby to attribute all the glory, and praise of our salvation to the
alone mercy of God, both in the respect of the beginning, and perfecting
thereof, and utterly denying our own selves, and all our righteousness, do
wholly rely upon the perfect righteousness of Christ: whereas if there were in
us perfect sanctification, we should hardly acknowledge the Lord to be all in
all in our salvation.

3. The wisdom and power of God is more manifested, and glorified, when as he
does his great works by contrary means, and causes, which in their own nature
would rather hinder them: therefore he will have us blind, that we may see; and
foolish, that we may be wise, etc. He will give blessedness to us, who have
so many wants, and corruptions, yea make our imperfections to serve as means
for the increasing of our happiness, this does exceedingly magnify his power,
and wisdom.

4. We are hereby made more thankful to the Lord, and more cheerful in seting
forth his praise, when notwithstanding our wants and imperfections, we are
supported, and saved, then if he should at first endue us with all perfection:
For the more we have found the want of Gods benefits, the more we prize them,
and so are the more thankful for them. So it was with St. Paul, when through
the violence of the flesh, he had been led captive to sin, Romans 7.24, 25. how
does he break forth into thankfulness. I thank God through Jesus Christ my
Lord.

5. Hereby we more glorify God when we are assured by our growth in grace, by
which we are enabled to resist the flesh, and the lusts thereof, that they are
the free gifts of God, and that he begins, increases, and continues them
in us, whereas otherwise we would think them to be some natural faculties, and
abilities, and not given us of God.

Quest. How is this conflict profitable for our good?
