able to stand against the assaults of the flesh in the day of battle.

2. To the Ministry of the Word, we must join the frequent use of the Lords
Supper, which is a spiritual feast, purposely ordained by our Savior Christ,
for the strengthening our communion with him by the Spirit, and for the
replenishing of us with all those sanctifying graces, whereby we may be enabled
to resist the flesh.

3. We must use the help of holy conference, instructing, exhorting,
admonishing, counselling, and comforting one another, that we may be further
edified in our holy Faith, Jude 20.

Thirdly, If we will strengthen the Spirit, we must nourish the good motions

Fourthly, We must be careful of maintaining our peace with God, and our Psalm.
42.1, 2. and 84.1. etc. when we labor daily in the mortification of our sins,
which separate between God and us, and exercise our selves in all holy duties
of his service, thereby glorifying his Name, and edifying our neighbors by our
good example.

Fifthly, We must carefully preserve our bodies, and souls, which are his

Sixthly, If we would strengthen the Spirit, and increase in us the gifts and
are necessary for preserving the life of our bodies: So fruitful working, and
holy walking in all Christian duties is for preserving, and cherishing the life
of the Spirit, Gal. 5.25. If we live in the Spirit, let us walk in the Spirit,
Let the fire of the Spirit have fit vent to send out its flames in holy, and
righteous actions, it will live and blaze, but if we stop its vent, it will
presently die. Let Faith exercise it self in apprehending the promises, in
waiting for performances, fighting against doubting, and in bea^ing the fruits
of good works, it will from a grain of mustard seed, grow to be a great tree,
from smoking flax, to a burning flame, and from a feeble assent to a full
persuasion. Let love be exercised in doing, and suffering for Gods sake, in
performing all holy services, and Christian duties to God and our neighbors,
it will grow from a spark to a great fire. Let the shoulders of patience be
inured to bear the Cross of Christ, and suffer afflictions: to put up wrongs,
and overcome evil with good, though they be weak at first, they will become
hardy, and strong. Exercise increases graces, but ease and sloth weakens them,
we should therefore resolve with David, Psalm. 119.32, 33, 34.

teaches our hands to war, and our fingers to fight, Psalm. 144.1. and that
gives us at the last a full, and final victory, and then adds the Crown of
victory, even everlasting glory. Mr. Downhams Christian warfare.

Quest. But the flesh and Spirit being but qualities, how can they be said to
fight together?

Answ. Because the flesh and Spirit are mixed together in the whole regenerate
man, and in all the powers of his soul: as light and darkness are mixed in the
air in the dawning of the day: and as heat and cold are mixed together in
lukewarm water: we cannot say that one part of the water is hot, and another
cold, but heat and cold are mixed in every part: so the man regenerate, is not
in one part flesh, and another spirit, but the whole mind is partly flesh, and
partly spirit, and so are the will and affections, etc. Now upon this mixture
it is that the powers of the soul are carried, and disposed diverse ways, and
hereupon follows the combat.

Quest. How does the lust of the flesh show it self?

Answ. First, it defiles, and suppresses the good motions of the Spirit: Hence
Paul says, Romans 7.21, 23. when I would do good, evil is present: and the Law
of the flesh rebels against the Law of the mind, Hereupon the flesh is fitly
compared to the disease called Ephialtes, or the mare, in which men in their
slumber, think they feel a thing as heavy as lead to lie upon their breasts,
which they can no way remove.

Secondly, It brings forth, and fills the mind with wicked cogitations, and
rebellious Jam. 1.14.

Quest. What are the contary actions of the spirit?

Answ. First, To curb, and restrain the flesh: Hence St. John says, the
regenerate cannot sin, 1 John 3.9,

Secondly, To beget good motions, inclinations, and thoughts agreeable to the
David, Psalm. 16.7. My reins instruct me in the night season: and Isa. 30.21.
thine ears shall hear a voice behind thee, etc. and thus by the concurrence of
these contrary actions in the same man is the combat made.

Quest. Why is there such a contrariety between the flesh and spirit?

Answ. Because the Spirit is the gift of righteousness, and the flesh stands in
a double opposition to it.

1. In the want of righteousness. 2. In a proness to all unrighteousness.

Object. But natural men also have a combat in them. For they can say, video
meliora, proboque, deteriora sequor. I see and approve of what is good, but do
that which is naught?

Answ. This combat is between the natural conscience, and rebellious
affections, and its incident to all men that have in them any conscience, or
light of reason.

Quest. Have all believers this combat in them?

Answ. No: For 1. Only such as be of years have it: for Infants, though they
have the seed of grace in them, yet do they want the act, or exercise of it,
and

Secondly, This combat is in the godly in the time of this life only. For in
death the flesh is abolished, and consequently this combat cease.

Quest. What are the effects of this combat in the godly?

Answ. It hinders them that they cannot do the things that they would, Gal.
5.17. and that three ways.

1. It makes them that they cannot live in the practice of any one sin, 1 John
3.9.

2. If at any time they fall, it stays and keeps them that they sin not with
full consent of will, but they can say, the evil which I hate, that do I, Romans
7.19.

3. Though in the ordinary course of their lives they do that which is good,
yet by reason of this conflict they fail in the doing of it, Romans 7.18. Hence
it follows that all the works of regenerate men are mixed with sin, and in the
rigor of justice deserve damnation.

Object. Sin is the transgression of the Law: but good works are no
transgression of the Law, and therefore they are no sins?

Answ. I answer to the Minor: The transgression of the Law is twofold. One
which is directly against the Law, both for matter and manner: 2. When that is
done which the Law requires, but not in that manner it should be done: and thus
good works become sinful.

Object. Good works are from the Spirit of God: but nothing proceeding from the
Spirit of God is sin?

Answ. Things proceeding from the Spirit of God alone, or from the Spirit
immediately, are no sins: but good works proceed not only from the Spirit, but
also from the mind, and will of man, as instruments of the Spirit: and when an
effect proceeds from sundry causes that are subordinate, it takes unto it the
nature of the second cause: hereupon our works are partly spiritual, and
partly carnal, as the mind and will of the doer is.

Object. But good works please God, and what pleases God is no sin?

Answ. They please God, because the doer of them is in Christ. Again, they
please not God before, or withour pardon. For they are accepted, because God
approves his own work in us, and pardons the defect thereof.

Object. No sins are to be done, therefore if good works be sin, they are not
to be done?

Answ. They are not simply sins but only by accident. For as God commands them,
they are good, and as godly men do them they are good in part. Now the reason
holds only thus, that which is sin, so far forth as it is a sin, or if it be
simply a sin, is not to be done.

Mr. Perkins, Vol. 2. p. 326.

CHAP. XLIII. Questions, and Cases about Conscience Good and Bad.
Quest. WHat is Conscience?

Answ. It is a faculty of the soul, taking knowledge, and bearing witness of a
man's thoughts, words, and works, excusing them when they be good, and accusing
them when they be evil, Romans 2.15. If the Conscience be not deceived, but
bears a true witness, then its no erroneous Conscience; Yet it may be an evil
Conscience if it be not sanctified as well as enlightened. Or,

Conscience is a particular knowledge which we have within us of our own deeds,
good, or evil, arising out of the general knowledge of the mind, which shows
us what is good, or evil, and Conscience tells us when we have done the one or
the other.

Conscience is a word of great latitude, and infinite dispute. Its taken
sometimes properly, sometimes generally. Its both a faculty, and a distinct
faculty of the soul: the Schools reject that, others this: but besides reason,
the word bends most that way, 1 Timothy 1.19. its distinguished from the evil,
Tit. 1.15. from the mind. And if we mark it, Conscience is so far from being
one of both, or both in one, as that there is between them: 1. A jealousy,
then an open faction: the other powers of the soul taking Conscience to be but
a spy, do what they can, first to hide themselves from it, next to deceive it,
afterward to oppose it, and lastly, to depose it. Conscience on the other
side, labors to hold its own, and (till it be blinded or bribed) proceeds in
its office in spite of all opposition: It cites all the powers of nature, sits
upon them, examineth, witnesses, judges, executes, hence come those (...)
self-conferences, or reasonings spoken of, Romans 2.15. Thence those Apologies,
and exceptions amongst themselves when Conscience sits.

Quest. What is the common subject of conscience?

Answ. The reasonable soul: Indeed there is some shadow of it in a beast, a^
th^e ^s of reason: but it is but a shadow: the proper sea^ of it, is the
highest part of the soul: its usually referred to the practical understanding,
because its busied about actions, and drives all its works to issue by
discourse: but as that ground is too weak (for neither is every discourse
Conscience, nor every act of conscience a discourse) so is that room too
straight: Conscience is therefore rather to be placed somewhat higher, under
God, but over all in man, distinct from other faculties, ye^ still sheathed in
the body.

Quest. What is its end, or office?

Answ. It is set in man to make known to man, in what terms he stands with God,
thence its name, and therefore is fitly termed, the souls glass, and the
understandings light.

Conscience therefore is a prime faculty of the reasonable soul, there set to
give notice of its spiritual estate in what terms it stands with God. The soul
is ranked into three parts, and those into as many Courts, and Offices. The
sensitive part has its Court of Common Pleas: the intellectual, of the Kings
Bench: the spiritual, a Chancery: in this Court all causes are handled, but
still with special reference to God: Here sits Conscience as Lord Chancellor,
the Synteresis as Master of the Rolls: To this Court all the powers of man owe,
and pay service till the Judge be either willingly feed, or unwillingly
resisted. And this of Conscience strictly taken.

2. Its taken sometimes more generally: Sometimes for the whole Court, and
proceeding of Conscience, by the Fathers: Sometimes for the whole soul of man,
either stooping to Conscience, or reflecting upon it self; So the Hebrews ever
take it: You never find that term (Conscience) with them, but Heart, Spirit.
So St. John (who abounds with Hebraisms) If our heart condemn, or condemn us
not, 1 John 3.19, etc.

Dr. Harris, St. Paul's Exercise.

Quest. What is the Scripture word for Conscience?

Ans. (...), which is a compound word: 1. of the verb (...), which signifies to
see, Mat. 2.2. and to know, Joh. 13.18. 2. of a Preposition, (...), which
signifies with: So as Conscience implies, knowledge with: viz. with some other
thing.

Conscience then implies a double knowledge: One of the mind, which is a bare
understanding of a thing: Another of the heart: So as the heart witnessing a
thing together with the mind, is Conscience, 1 Cor. 2.11. -- save the Spirit,
(i. e. the Conscience) of a man which is in him. Or

The double knowledge that is comprised under conscience, may be of God, or a
man's self. God knows all things, even the most secret thoughts, Psalm. 139.2.
and every man knows the most secret things of himself, 1 Cor. 2.11. the
testimony therefore of a man's heart, with his mind, or rather with God, is
Conscience. Hence its said to bear witness, Romans 9.1. and Paul rejoiced in the
testimony of his Conscience, 2 Cor. 1.12.

Quest. Where is the seat of Conscience;

Answ. Within a man: For its applied to the heart, Heb. 10.22. yea, its styled
the heart, Prove. 15.15. 1 Samuel 24.5. and the Spirit, 1 Cor. 2.11.

Quest. Why is it seated in a man?

Answ. That it may the better perform the function which belongs to it: It
being within, may see all within, and without. As a man within a house full of
windows, 1 Kin. 2.44.

But Conscience cannot be discerned by others without, as is employed, Jer.
17.9. 1 Cor. 2.11.

Quest. What is the Office of Conscience?

Answ. To witness, Romans 2.15. For this end it has ability to know the things
of a man. The witness of Conscience is the surest witness that can be. Its a
faithful witness that will not lie, Prove. 14.5. A man by his tongue may belie
himself, but Conscience cannot do so.

Quest. How manifold is the witnes^ of Conscience?

Answ. Twofold: Either to accuse, or to excuse, Romans 2.15. To accuse for evil,
to excuse by freeing from evil unjustly laid to ones charge: the Jews
Conscience accused, Joh. 8.9. St. Pauls's excused, Act. 23.1. Hence follows
trouble, or peace to a man's soul, as Matthew. 27.4. Romans 5.1.

Quest. What is a good Conscience?

Answ. That Conscience is said to be good, when it obeys such light, and
direction, as it does think, and take to be true and sound light, and
direction, Act. 23.1.

Quest. How many things concur to make up a good Conscience?

Answ. First, the matter whereupon it works, which is a conformity in the
whole man to the whole will of God: Gods will made known to man, is man's

Secondly, The proper act of it, where this matter is to be found, the
Conscience will bear witness, and give a true testimony thereunto.

Thirdly, The Consequence following thereupon, which is peace, and quietness to
the soul.

Such a good Conscience was perfect in man's innocence: but by his fall it was
clean lost, and became an evil conscience. For Genesis 6.5.

Quest. How does an evil Conscience fail in the proper works thereof?

Answ. Sometimes in defect: Sometimes in an excess.

1. In the defect when it suffers a man to run into all evil, and does neither
check, nor trouble him for the same. Called a seared conscience, 1 Timothy 4.2.

2. In the excess, when it does so out of measure trouble him, as it takes away
all hope of pardon, and hinders sound and true repentance: yea, and makes his
life a burden to himself: So Judas's, Matthew. 27.3, 4, 5. Hence, Isai. 57.20, 21.

Quest. What must concur to the renovation of Conscience, and making it good?

Answ. First, Faith in Lord Jesus Christ, whereby the Conscience is purged,
Heb. 9.14. Hence we are exhorted, Heb. 10.22. to draw near with a pure heart,
etc.

Secondly, A sanctified work of the Spirit, whereby the heart is alienated from
sin, and made watchful against it: and withal it is put on to conform Romans
9.1. 2 Cor. 1.12. This is styled a pure Conscience, 1 Timothy 3.9. 2 Timothy 1.3. and
a Conscience void of offense, Act. 24.16.

Quest. What then since man's fall is counted a good Conscience?

Answ. First, That which gives a true testimony of a man's Faith in Christ, for
the pardon of his sins, and reconciliation with God, Heb.

Secondly, Which bears witness to his conformity in the whole man to the holy
will of God in all manner of duties to God and man, Act. 24.16. particularly,
Matt. 25.21.

Thirdly, That which works peace, and quiet in the soul, Romans 5.1. 2 Cor.
1.12.

Dr. Gouge on Heb.

Quest. What other definitions may be given of Conscience?

Answ. Conscience is the judgment of a man concerning himself, and his own
ways, in reference, and subordination to the judgment of God: Dr. Ames. Or

Its the souls recoiling on its self. Ward, Dike. Or

Its the souls acting, and reflecting on it self, and on all a man's own actions.

Quest. How many sorts of good consciences are there?

Answ. A good troubled conscience: Bona turbata.

Secondly, A good quiet Conscience: Bona pacata.

Quest. What goodness must concur to a right good Conscience?

Answ. First, a goodness of sincerity.

Secondly, a goodness of security: It must be honest bona, and pacate bona.

Quest. What then is a truly good Conscience?

Answ. A good Conscience is that which is rightly purified, and rightly
pacified by the Word, Blood, and Spirit of Christ, regularly performing all the
Offices unto which it is designed.

Quest. What must it be purified from?

Answ. First, Ignorance: A Conscience void of knowledge, is void of Tit. 1.15.

Secondly, From error, the Erroneous Conscience is ever a desperate, and Herod
under an Opinion of piety, to destroy John to save his wicked Oath, Mat. 14.9.
Others make void Gods commands to make good their own vows, Jer. 44.16. It made
Paul to persecute the Church, Act. 26.9. others to compass Sea, and Land to
make Proselites, Matthew. 23.15.

Heb. 9.14. A dead Conscience is not for a living God.

Quest. How must conscience be purified?

Answ. First, The word of Christ is the great heart-searcher, and
Conscience-purifier, Heb. 4.12. Joh. 15.3. and 17.17. This removes ignorance,
Psalm. 119.105, 130. It rectifies Error, being a voice behind us, Isa. ^0.21.
ends all controversies, Isa. 8.26. Resolves all doubts, Luke 10.26. Removes
deadness and hardness, Jer. 23.29. Its an Hammer to soften: Its immortal seed,
etc. 1 Pet. 1.23. Hence Psalm. 119.25, 50, 93.

Heb. 9.14. and 10.22. 1 John 1.7.

Thirdly, The Spirit of Christ, together with the Word, and blood of Christ
Joh. 6.63. Heb. 9.14. the Spirit heals those diseases before mentioned. 1.
Ignorance, being the Spirit of illumination, Ephesians. 1.17. 2. Error, being the
Spirit of truth, Joh. 14.17. 3. Deadness, being the Spirit of life, Romans 8.2.
Its Refiners fire, etc. Mal. 3.2. Hence, Isa. 4.4.

Quest. What must Conscience be pacified from?

Answ. First, It must be at peace from the dominion of sin: there is a peace
when sin, and Satan are strongly armed, and keep the house, Luke 11.^1. But
this is the peace of a sleepy, not of an awakened Conscience: woe to them, Luke
6.25. Amos. 6.1, 3. Conscientia pacate optima, may be, vitiose pessima. In tali
pace amaritudo mea amarissima: Ber. there is no peace to the wicked, Isa. 57.
ult. 2 Pet. 2.3.

Matthew. 16.18. the sum of that promise, Romans 16.20. the God of Peace shall
bruise Satan under your feet shortly.

Thirdly, From the displeasure of God, when we can say, Romans 5.1. being
justified by Faith, we have peace with God: This is the best part of our peace:
John 14.27. So, Phil. 4.7. This guards the soul from all fears, and assaults
of the Law, Sin, Guilt, Death, Hell, and Satan.

Quest. What must Conscience be pacified by?

Answ. First, By the Word of Christ its pacified, and restored to peace: hence
Word of Peace, etc. Acts 10.36. Romans 10.15. 2 Cor. 5.18. Isa. 57.19. and 52.7.

Secondly, By the blood of Christ. This is the procuring cause of all our Col.
1.20. Romans 3.23, etc. This blood gives the soul all boldness to enter into
the holiest, etc. Heb. 10.19. and gives us assurance before God.

Thirdly, By the Spirit of Christ, which is the procreating cause of peace in
us: Advocate, 1 John 2.1. So is the Holy Ghost, Joh. 14.16. Only here is the
difference: Christ is our Advocate to God, prevailing with him to grant us
peace: the Holy ^host is Gods Advocate to us, to prevail with us, to entertain
peace. He applies the Word, and promises which proclaim our peace: He applies
the blood of Christ which procures our peace: He has the last hand in
consummating our peace; whence its called, Joy in holy Ghost, Romans 14.17. So
Gal. 5.22.

Quest. What are the Offices of Conscience?

Answ. First, Prophetical, or Ministerial, i. e. To do the Office of a
Minister, mouth of the Lord, the Candle of the Lord, Prove. 20.27.

Secondly, Regal, or Magistraticall. It has a commanding, and Legislative
Romans 2.14. they were a Law to themselves, therefore what Conscience commands,
or forbids is more to a godly man, then what Kings command, or forbid. Hence,
Dan. 3.16. But though it has a Kingly power, yet it has not an Arbitrary
power: It self is subject to God.

Thirdly, Testimonial, or to bear witness, Romans 2.14, 15. 2 Cor. 1.12. This is
a testimony which Gods Spirit does attest to, and consent with, Romans 9.1. and
Joh. 3.19, 20, 21. Conscientia mill testes.

Turpe quid acturus, te sine test time. Fourthly, Juridicall, and Judg-like:
It passes sentence on thee, and reads thy doom: Hence we are said to be
convicted of our own Consciences, Joh. 8.9. Tit. 3.11. Romans 14.22. 1 John 3.20,
21. Consciences sentence is the forerunner of the last judgment, Job 31.35,
36. Isa. 50.8. 1 Samuel 2.25.

Fifthly, Registeriall: For its the great Register, and Recorder of the World.
Its to every man his private Notary, keeping Records of all his Acts, and
deeds. It has the pen of a ready Writer, and takes from thy mouth all thou
speak: yea from thy heart all thou contrivest, and though its writing may
for the present, like the writing with the juice of a Lemon, be illegible: yet
when thou come into the fire of distress, it will then appear: or at
farthest, the fire in the great day of judgment will discover it.

Its the poor man's Historiographer, who has no Chronicler to rite his story,
Jer. 17.1. So that Conscience is then good when it does officiate well, and
does the part of a Minister, of a Magistrate, of a Witness, and of a Judge.

Quest. How many sorts of good Consciences are there?

Answ. First, The good Conscience of Faith: without which its impossible Heb.
11.6. Therefore St. Paul joines Faith, and a good Conscience together, 1 Timothy
1.5, 19. and 3.9. There is no good faith, where there is not a good conscience:
nor yet a good conscience where true faith is wanting, therefore look to thy
Faith, if thou would find a good Conscience, Heb. 10.22. 1 Timothy 3.9.

Secondly, A pure Conscience, the clean, pure, and undefiled Conscience is Tim.
1.5. and 3.9. 2 Timothy 1.3. As faith makes the Conscience good before God, so
purity makes it good before men. Such are blessed, Mat. 5.8. 1 John 3.3. Great
are the comforts, benefits, and privileges of a pure Conscience, and high are
the promises made to it, Psalm. 18.26. and 24.3, 4, 5. In pure water thy face
may be seen, not so in muddy: So in a pure Conscience Gods face may be seen,
and no where else in the Earth.

Noah, and Job are called perfect, because sincere, Genesis 6.9. Job 1.1. of this
Conscience, Paul speaks, 2 Cor. 1.12. The Greek word for sincerity, (...) used,
1 Cor. 5.8. 2 Cor. 1.12. signifies such things as are tried by the light. Or,
as a Chap-man opens his wares to see if there be any deceit in them.

Quest. But how may this sincerity of Conscience be known?

Answ..1 It makes a man abhor all guile, and fraud, and to renounce the hidden
things of dishonesty: like Jacob, a plain downright man: or Nathaniel, an
Israelite, in whom was no guile: Such was Paul, 2 Cor. 2.17. and 4.2. and
Michaiah, 1 Kin. 22.14. and Caleb, Joh. 14.7, 8.

2. Sincerity brings all to the light, Joh. 3.20. He that does the truth,
comes to the light that his deeds may be made manifest that they are wrought
in God, and therefore, as of sincerity, and as of God, and as in the sight of
God, are put together, 2 Cor. 2.17. Such an one owns nothing but what will
endure the Sun. Hence, Psalm. 26.2. Joh. 21.16, 17. Job 6.24. 2 Cor. 4.2. 1
These. 2.10.

3. The sincere man is still one, and the same, whether alone, or in company:
yea, he is rather better then he shows: as the Kings daughter, all glorious
within, Psalm. 45.13. He is just, and faithful, being a Law to himself.

4. The sincere man may have his failings, and is subject to tentations, yet he
never allows himself in any known evil: therefore he is called perfect in
respect of his intention, and aim, 2 King. 20.3. He resists every known will,
and rejects every known Error: He purifies himself as God is pure, 1 John 33.
So Romans 7.16, 17.

5. A sincere man holds on his course, and he that has clean hands shall be
stronger and stronger, Job 17.9. as the vessel of gold wears brighter, and
brighter by use, therefore sincerity is the best seen in times and places when,
and where Satan is let loose, Rev. 2.13. where there are few encouragements to
persist in a godly way: So Nichodemus in sticking to a condemned Christ, Joh.
7.51. Joseph of Arimathea to a crucified, forsaken, and naked Christ, Joh.
19.38.

6. Universality is a certain note of sincerity, when we walk in all the
commandments of God, as Luke 1.6. Heb. 13.18. Dan. 6.22. To be partial is to
corrupt the Law, Mal. 2.9. To make Conscience of one duty, and not of another,
is to make no Conscience of the one, or of the other. So Mat. 23.5, 23. Romans
2.22.

7. A sincere man carries himself ever as before God, 2 Cor. 2.17. Psalm. 16.8.
and 44.21. He carries an awful apprehension of God with him whithersoever he
goes: Hence, Col. 3.23.

8. A sincere man consults with his duty more then with his commodity, and
resolves against sin, more then against any danger: He undervalues all losses
to the loss of Gods favor, and his own peace, Psalm. 25.21.

9. Such an one cannot skill of fleshly wisdom, or worldly Policy: He is no
time-server, 2 Cor. 1.12. Simplicity is the sincerity, and sincerity all the
policy of a conscientious man. He desires no more wisdom then will make him
honest, and sincere, Romans 16.19.

10. Sincerity is known, 1. By the original, and principle it moves from:
Pharisees pray for ostentation, not from devotion, Mat. 6.1, 2, 5. So, Phil.
1.16. A sincere person does all out of a principle of piety to God, and charity
to man. 2. By the rule it constantly walks by, viz. Gods Word. So Josiah, 2
Kin. 22.2. Come commodity, or discommodity, he keeps on his way: but unsound
persons cast their eye on their own interest. So 2 Chronicles. 27.2. and 26.4. and
25.2. 2 Kin. 10.31. 3. By the end it aims at, God is the sincere man's end, and
his glory his aim: the Hypocrite makes himself his own end, and so himself his
own god, Zach. 7.5, 6. Hos. 10.1.


Fourthly, An inoffensive Conscience, which Paul highly esteemed, Act. 24.16.

1. Avoid giving offense, either to God or man. 1. He strives to prevent
offenses to God, and takes up purposes against them, Psalm. 17.3. and if he has
displeased God, he is displeased with himself for it. So Jer. 31.19. Job 42.6.
Ezekiel. 6.9. and 36.31. and he is careful to break off his sins by repentance,
Job 34.31, 32. and 40.4, 5. He is resolved rather to offend all thee world,
then to offend God, Gal. 1.10. Dan. 3.16. Act. 4.19.

2. Avoid giving offense to man: especially such an offense as may cause him to
sin, and then such an offense as may cause him to take offense: in the first we
tempt him, in the second we try him: in both we offend him, and do the Devils
work in both. By the former he is stumbled, by the Second he is made weak, and
by both offended, Romans 14.21. we must therefore take heed that we do nothing
that should cause others to offend by sinning, as Elies sons did, 1* Sam. 2.24.
and Jer^boam, 1 Kin. 14.16. and Ahab, 1 Kin. 21.25. woe to such, Luke 17.1. we
must give no offense to the godly, be they stronger, or weaker, Matthew. 18.6,
10. nor to the wicked. Hence, Col. 4.5. 1 Timothy 6.1, 2. 1 Pet. 2.18. and 3.1. we
must not offend our selves, but must regard what Conscience calls for to
satisfy our duty, and to keep in with our selves, rather then to gratify any
others requests.

2. An inoffensive Conscience will not be apt to take offense, either 1. From
God, who can never give any: yet to some, Christ is a rock of offense, Romans
9.33. yea he was so to his Disciples, Math. 26.31. 2. From Gods way: as when we
receive the Word with joy, but meeting with persecution we are offended, and
turn back, Math. 13.21. 3. From Gods Children, and their weakness, so far as
either to condemn their persons, or dislike their profession, Matthew. 18.5. True
godliness makes a man apt to take all in good part, 1 Cor. 13.5. 4. From the
evil World, because all men speak evil of the ways of God, and forsake them,
we must not therefore be offended, Isa. 8.12, 13.


Pharisees were full of eyes without, and none within: full of eyes before* but
had none behind: they could censure others actions, not see their own: Hence
called fools, and blind, Mat. 23.17, 19, 24.

Sixthly, A well-spoken Conscience, which can make the soul a good answer,
Quaries, 1 Pet. 3.21.

1. It makes a good and ready answer to God, as Psalm 27.8. and 40.8.

2. It makes a good answer for God, as is commanded, 1 Pet. 3.15, 16. Its ready
to give an account of its Spiritual estate when it is required

3. It makes a good answer for ones self, when under the greatest clouds of
censures, suspicions, or reproaches, Romans 9.1. 2 Cor. 6.8, 9.

4. When any business of Conscience is under consideration, Conscience puts the
best answer into thy mouth, and will readily resolve what is to be done.

Paul glories, Heb. 13.18. Act. 23.1. 1 Pet. 3.16. Peter exhorts to it, a good
conversation without, proclaims a good Conscience within, Phil. 4.8. Notes of
an honest Conscience are,

1. He has engraven on his heart this maxim, I must be a Law to my self:
Hence its said, 1 Timothy 1.9. The Law is not witten for the righteous: And if
others were as honest as he, fewer Laws, and Magistrates would serve turn.

2. He makes Christ's rule his Oracle, Matthew. 7.12. what ever you would others
should do to you, etc. which is the Epitome of the Law, and Prophets: the voice
both of Scripture, and nature.

3. You may be bold to take his word, and trust him: He dares not deceive,
though he may be deceived: His word is as good as his bond: his bond as his
oath: and his oath as his soul.

4. You need not fear to take his wares, his weight, or his measure, all are
current, and warrantable: He is faithful, and punctual in his reckonings,
disbursments, and receipts, as they, 2 Kin. 12.15. etc.

5. He respects not a person so much as the cause: the cause of the poor,
fatherless, and widows is more to him, then the face of the rich, or the letter
of the mighty: Like Levi, Deuteronomy. 33.9.

6. He will sooner suffer any prejudice himself, then prejudice his neighbor,
Psalm. 15.4. He swears to his own hurt, and damage, and changes not.

heart of flesh promised, Ezekiel. 36.25. the c^ntrite spirit in which God
delights, Isa. 66.1, 2. commended in Josiah, 2 King. 22.19, 20. and David, 1 Samuel 24.5. 2 Samuel 24.10. and in Ephraim, Jer. 31.19. and in the Publican, Luke
18.13.

Quest. But is there not a faulty tenderness of conscience?

Answ. Yes, as, 1. When one is so tender that he cannot endure to be touched
with a reproof; Prophecy to us smooth things, say they, Isa. 30.10. Give us of
your softest pillows, Ezekiel. 13.18. Such was Amaziah, Amos 7.10. and they, Jer.
38.4. and they, Act. 5.33. and 7.54. whereas the right tenderness is to be very
sensible of the evil of sin, and the danger thereof: and thereupon impatient of
the sin, but very patient of reproof, Psalm. 141.5. Act. 2.37.

2. When he is scrupulous. As when one has got gravel in his shoe, he cannot
set his foot on the ground without complaint. The Apostles rule will help such,
Romans 14.5. Let every one be fully persuaded in his own mind, i. e. rid himself
of unnecessary, and unprofitable scruples: unnecessary scruples are when a man
makes a stir about things wherein Gods word is silent, and makes sin where
the Scripture makes none: as the Priests did about going into the judgment
Hall, Joh. 18.28. lest they should be defiled ceremonially, but made no scruple
to defile themselves morally, by bringing upon them the guilt of innocent
blood. Again, they made a great scruple of putting the money into their holy
Corban, because it was the price of blood, but questioned not the giving money
for the same, and taking the blood it self upon themselves and children, Mat.
27.25. such are condemned by Christ, Matthew. 23.23. Mark 7.11.

Unnecessary and vain scruples the Apostle would have us lay aside, 1 Corinthians.
10.25. asking no question (in such cases) for conscience sake.

3. When he is of too facile, and flexible a spirit, so as to yield to every
one that counsels and entises him to sin: For this Ephraim was broken in
judgment, Hos. 5.11. Thus tenderhearted was Rehoboam, 2 Chronicles. 13.7. and
Zedekiah, Jer. 38.5.

4. When the conscience is weak and sickly, as Paul calls it, 1 Cor. 8.12. and
is easily cast down and discouraged. This was the disease of the stony ground,
it was so tender as to be offended at the Cross, Matthew. 13.21. Outwardly
tender, and inwardly hard: whereas the good ground was inwardly soft to give
rooting to the seed, but outwardly hardy to endure all weathers. This picks a
quarrel at the Gospel for some circumstances, Mark 7.2. Such was the conscience
of the mixed multitude, Numb. 11.4. and of the spies, Numb. 13.31. that started
at the ^ight of the Anakims, and would not have the people endanger themselves:
The properties of it are.

1. Its apt to scruple things lawful. It eats nothing but herbs, Romans 14.2.
2. It puzzles and perplexes it self about things of no great moment: as Days,
m^ats, etc. Col. 2.21. 3. Its apt to judge him, that upon better grounds is not
of his mind and practice, Romans 14.3. 4. He is apt to stumble, Romans 14.21. 5.
Or to be grieved, and distasted, Romans 14.21.
5. When the conscience is so awakened that it cannot take any more rest, Psalm.
77.^*3, 4. So Psalm* 51.3. my sin is ever before me, and Psalm. 38.17. This is
a sad and painful, if not sometimes also, a sinful tenderness, when the soul
sees nothing but sin, guilt, and misery in it self, nothing but anger, wrath
and frow^ in God, and no hopes of redemption by Christ, or of recovery by the
spirit of grace. But the right tenderness is that due proportion of sense in an
awakened conscience which labors to keep the soul guarded, and unmolested.
Taking up Jobs resolution, Job 27.6. This tenderness shows it self.

1. In respect of God: In every thing to which God is entitled, and has
interest in; Moses stands for an hoof, Exodus 10.26. Christ is tender for the
least tittle of the Law, Matthew. 5.18. He is all on a flame with the zeal of
Gods house, and would not endure to have it profaned in the least, Joh. 2.17.
Yea, 1. Principally he is tender of those things wherein Gods glory is
concerned, Joh. 17.18. and 8.49, 50. This makes a man regardless of self, in
respect of name, credit, family, estate, yea, and of life, Act. 20.24. so the
Martyrs: and Nehemiah, chapter 13.15, 18, 19. 2. He is tender in respect of Gods
truth, which must be bought, not sold. So was Paul, Gal. 2.11. So Rev. 2.2. He
shows his tenderness in retaining, and contending for old truths, and in taking
heed how he vents any new doctrines: So 2 Cor. 13.8. and 2.17. 2 Pet. 1.16. 3.
He is tender of whatsoever does proceed from God, as to submit to every command
of God, for he trembles at his Word, Isa. 66.2. So Christ, Luke 2.49. John
6.39. 4. He yields, melts, and breaks under any threat of Gods Word, or sense
of Gods displeasure: So Josiah, 2 King. 22.19. contrary in Jehoiakim, Jer.
36.24. 5. He much more yields and humbles himself under the afflicting hand of
God: He comes forth of the furnace, like gold, all melted, and refined, Job
23.10. and 42.6. whereas others walk contrary to God, Lev. 26.41. 6. He kindly
thaws, and melts under the sense of the free favor, and abundant love of God,
as the ice before the warm Sun. So, Ezra 9.14. This was the gracious temper of
that poor woman, Luke 7.38. so we are required, Hos. 3.5.


2. In respect of men, this tenderness must show it self to all in general, and
to each in particular: To the godly, to the wicked; to strong, to weak.

1. To the godly: and that, 1. By not grieving them, and forbearing to offend
them: He is ever tender of the peace, and studious of the satisfaction of every
honest man. If his meat, apparel, hair, company, etc. make his brother to
offend, he will eat no such meat, wear no such apparel, or hair, keep no such
company whilst the world stands, rather then to make his brother offend, 1
Cor. 8.13. 2. He is tender of their reputation, not to expose them, or rather
Religion in them, to reproach. So Joseph would not bring a reproach upon Mary,
Mat. 1.19. 3. He is tender of disagreeing with, or dividing from any that is
godly, upon unnecessary and frivilous grounds. Enters not upon doubtful
disputations; falls not out about questions that nourish jangling, but destroy
edification: the common sin of our times: contrary to the Apostles precept,
Ephesians. 4.13, 32. 4. He is especially tender of weak Christians, no ways to
discourage them, despise them; or impose any burdens, much less to lay
stumbling blocks before them: but to bear their infirmities, Romans 15.1. To
condescend to their terms, Romans 12.16. This makes us like Christ, who is tender
of all his little ones, Mat. 8.17. Isa. 40.11. Mat. 12.18, 19. Luke 22.27.
2. To the wicked, who must see that we are tender of his good, more then he is
of his own. So, 2 Timothy 2.26. 1 Pet. 2.15. and we are to endeavor to take away
occasion from them that seek it to speak reproachfully of us, 1 Timothy 5.14. 3.
We must be tender of the good of those that are nearest to us: that we, and our
houses may serve the Lord, Jos. 24.15. So, Job 1.5. and Paul of the
Corinthians, whom he had espoused to Christ, 2 Cor. 11.2. and 6.11.
3. In respect of self: and that,

1. In respect of sin already committed: for which his heart smites him, 1 Samuel
24.5. 2 Samuel 24.10. and gives him no rest till he has made his peace with God
by repentance, and with man by restitution, or other satisfaction: as, Zacheus,
Luke 19.8.

2. In respect of sin not yet committed: He fears and departs from evil, and
shuns all occasions and provocations tending to it. So Joseph, Genesis 39.9.

3. He shuns small as well as great sins: He will not be found, no not in an
officious lie: as Gehazi's was, 2 Kings 5.25. Flies lesser oaths, Eccles. 9.2.
idle words, Matthew. 12.36. wanton looks, vain thoughts, etc.

4. He flies secret sins as well as open, and is most known by his closet,
and solitary carriage: He says with David, Psalm 44.21. Shall not God search
this out?

5. He shuns as well sinful omissions, as sinful commissions, as knowing that
in the day of judgment these will be charged upon him, Mat. 25.42. Omissions
are sins that bring a curse, Mat. 2.10. the slothful servant is called an evil
servant, Mat. 35.26, 30. negative holiness will not commend us to God, though
it may to man.

6. He flies and avoids the common sins and prevailing errors of the times: So
did Nehemiah reform the profanation of the Sabbath, and usury, Neh. 10.31. and
13.15. to 23. and 5.9, etc.

7. He flies as well all sinful occasions as actions: He keeps out of the way,
and and company of wicked men, Psalm. 1.1. Eccl. 7.26. For, Prove. 6.27, 28.
Judas took no hurt amongst the Disciples, but going to the High Priests, he was
for ever lost. Peter took no hurt in the garden, but in the High Priests Hall
was ensnared. Din^h walking out to see the daughters of the Hivites, and
Sampson to see the daughters of the Philistines, neither of them returned so
well as they went out. Many now adays by leaving Ministers, Ordinances,
Assemblies, etc. have made themselves a prey to seducers, and have been
corrupted: Hence, 1 John 2.19.

8. He flies not only what is simply evil, but whatsoever has an appearance of
evil: as he is commanded, 1 These. 5.22. Romans 12.2. Phil. 4.8. Ephesians. 5.3, 4, 11.

9. As he flies whatsoever has an appearance of evil, so he dares not always
trust whatsoever has an appearance of good. He therefore tries all things, and
holds fast only what is good, 1 These. 5.21. knowing what Christ says, Luke
16.15. That which is highly esteemed amongst men, is abomination in the sight
of God. He suspects that action, person, and state of life of which all men
speak well: He still knows that Satan deceives more easily, and destroys more
dangerously when he assumes the shape of an Angel of light. Hence we are
commanded to mistrust many things, 2 These. 2.2. Revel. 2.2. Gal. 1.6. 2 Peter
2.1. Matthew. 24.24. 1 John 4.1.

10. He takes heed even of what he knows to be lawful: He dares not do all that
he may do, knowing that he that will do all he may, often does more then he
ought, 1 Cor. 6.12. and 10.23. In use of things lawful he observes three rules.

1. It may be lawful, but is it expedient? when? how much? how far? and how
often is it expedient? 2. It is lawful, but will it edify, or offend? 3. Its
lawful, but I must not suffer my self to be brought under the power of any
thing though lawful: He knows its a true saying, Licitis perimus omnes: all the
world is undone by lawful things abused, and mistimed. It was the undoing of
the old world, and Sodom, Mat. 29.38. Luke 17.27, 28.
11. He dares not do always what is in his power. Joseph did not what he might
have done to his unkind brethren, Genesis 42.18.

12. Nor dare he do what others have familiarly done before him in his place:
So, Nehemiah, chapter 5.14, etc.

13. He does not only avoid sinful actions, but takes sad notice of, and
bewails his sinful affections, and the depraved disposition of his nature. He
mourns under the sin that dwells in him, Romans 7.20, 23, 24. He would neither
have his sin reign, nor remain in him: He hates his sin in every degree with a
perfect, and impartial hatred.

14. He ever rather consults with honesty, justice, and duty, then with honor,
commodity, and safety: If he once engages, he changes not, though it be to
his prejudice, Psalm. 15.4.

15. He alone, in the cause of Christ and Religion, dares stand it out against
the whole world. Unus Athanasius contra totum mundum; and so did Luther,
regarding neither the favor, nor the frowns of his adversaries. He considers
not so much the danger that lies before him, as the duty and necessity that
lies upon him, to appear in such a time and cause. So Elijah, 1 King. 19.10.

Dan. 3.16. We are not careful to answer thee, O King, in this matter. This is
commended by Peter, 1 Pet. 2.19, 20. and truly without this all other things
are nothing: not the conscience of faith, purity, sincerity, etc. This
commended the Christians of old times: they were content to be bound, that
truth might be at liberty, and to die, that religion might not die.

Quest. But can all that suffer say that they suffer for Conscience, and for
God?

Answ. No, there are four kinds of sufferings, which a good conscience can have
no comfort in.

1. When we put our selves upon voluntary, and arbitrary sufferings, and then
place religion and conscience in it: as the Baalites of old, who cut and lanced
themselves, 1 King. 18.28. and the Circumcelions of later time. But who
required these things at their hands? they cannot say with Saint Paul, They
bear the marks of the Lord Jesus in their bodies, Gal. 6.17. but rather the
marks of their own folly, and rashness.

2. When we pull upon our selves unnecessary and unwarrantable sufferings, by a
preposterous, and precipitate meddling in businesses out of our way and calling:
This is to suffer as busy bodies in other men's matters. Not as a Christian, 1
Pet. 4.15, 16.

3. When we pull upon our selves deserved sufferings from the hand of Justice
for our evil doings. These may say with the Thief, Luke 23.41. we suffer
justly, etc. These (like Zimri) are burnt with fire which their own hands have
kindled.

4. When we bring our selves into worse sufferings then any of the former, viz.
sufferings in conscience and from conscience, by shunning any other sufferings
for God and conscience: as Judas, Spira, etc. These are run from the fear, and
are fallen into the pit, Isa. 24.18. The first of these sufferings are foolish,
the second sinful; the third shameful; and the last dreadful.

Quest. What rules then are to be observed in the sufferings of a good
conscience?

Answ. First, see that thy sufferings be ever, and only for well-doing. As thou
must not shun sufferings by choosing evil, so thou must not seek, and procure
Pet. 2.15. A good conscience must not go out of Gods way to meet with
sufferings, nor out of sufferings way to meet with sin. Its not Poena but
Causa: the cause, not the punishment which makes a Martyr.

2. If thou suffer for ill-doing, yet be sure that it be wrongfully, 1 Pet.
Mat. 5.11. that thy conscience may say, we are as deceivers, yet true, as
unknown, yet well konwn to God, 2 Cor. 6.9, 10.

Thirdly, if thou desire chiefly, and especially to suffer in the cause, and
for Daniel was careful to carry himself unreprovably, but in the matters of God
he cared not what he suffered, Dan. 6.14, 5. Life as it is too little worth to
be laid out for Christ, so its too precious to be laid out in any other cause.
Its an honor if we can call our sufferings, the sufferings of Christ, Col.
2.24. and our scarrs, the marks of the Lord Jesus, Gal. 6.17. and can subscribe
our selves, the prisoners of Christ, Ephesians. 3.1.

Fourthly, if thou love to see the ground thou go upon: that thy cause be
clear, the grounds manifest, that thou be not thrust forward by a turbulent
I suffer according to the will of God, 1 Pet. 4.19.

Fifthly, if thou be careful not only that the matter be good, but that the
Pet. 2.19, etc. If thou suffer wrongfullly, yet thou must suffer patiently.
This is to suffer as Christ suffered, 1 Pet. 2.21, 22, 23.

Sixthly, if thou committest thy self in thy sufferings to God in well-doing,
Pet. 4.19. suffering times must not be sinning times: He is no good Martyr that
is not a good Saint. A good cause, a good conscience, a good life, a good
death, a good matter to suffer for, a good manner to suffer in, make an
honorable Martyr.

Tenthly, a conscience of charity. This the Apostle speaks of as the end, and
perfection of the Law, and Gospel too* 1 Timothy 1.5. where there is the truth of

1. External, or civil, which respects

1. The poor to whom is to be showed the charity of beneficence. 2. To the
neighbor and friend, a love of benevolence. And, 3. To the enemy a love of
forgiveness.

1. To the poor a love of beneficence, and well-doing: this kind of charity is
the worlds grand benefactor: the poors great Almoner: the widows Treasurer: the
Orphans Guardian: and the oppressed man's Patron: This lends eyes to the blind,
feet to the lame, deals out bread to the hungry, clothes the naked, and brings
upon the Donor the blessing of him that was ready to perish. This Zacheus
showed, Luke 19.8. and Job Chap. 30.12, etc. and Obadiah, 1 King. 18.13. and
Nehemiah, Chap. 5.15. Hence Psalm. 112.5. Prove. 31.20, 26. So Cornelius, Acts
10.2, 4. Isa. 32.8.

2. To our neighbors must be showed the charity of benevolence: we must love
them as our selves, Matthew. 22.39. Romans 13.8. For Prove. 18.24. He that has a
friend, must show himself friendly. Its a pleasant thing to see friends and
neighbors living in this mutual love, and benevolence, Psalm. 133.1. etc.

3. To our enemies a love of forgiveness. This is the hardest, and therefore
the highest pitch of love: a lesson only to be learned in the School of Christ.
The Pharisees taught otherwise, which Christ labored to reform, Matthew. 5.46.
Luke 6.32.33. This makes us like our Father in Heaven, who is kind to the
thankful, and unkind, Luke, 6.35. and like his Son on Earth, who prayed for
his enemies. This we are exhorted to, Col. 3.12, 13.

2. Spiritual, or Ecclesiastical, which is to be showed in the love we bear
to the Church and truth of Christ, and to the souls of our brethren. This
Charity is to be preferred before all the former: the former may be amongst
Heathens, and civilized Christians, but this is the peculiar badg of the people
of God: A love of Symphonie in judgment, and opinion: of Sympathy in heart, and
affection, and of Symmetrie, or Harmony in an offensive conversation: This is
often, and earnestly pressed, Phil. 2.1, etc. 1 Pet. 3.8. Its the end of the
Law, the adorning of the Gospel: the lively Image of God, and of Christ: the
first fruit of the Spirit: the daughter of Faith: the Mother of hope: the
sister of peace: the kinswoman of truth: the life and joy of Angels: the bane
of Devils: Its the death of Dissentions: the grave of Schisms, wherein all
Church rupture, and offenses are buried, 1 John 4.8, 16. Joh. 13.34. Gal.
5.22.6. Yea, its the very bond of perfection, Col. 3.14. and that which covers
all sins, 1 Pet. 4.8.

Quest. What is the excellency, and benefit of a good Conscience?

Answ. First, The excellency of it appears in the honorable titles given to

1. It has this proper denomination given it ordinarily of a good Conscience,
Act. 23.19. 1 Timothy 1.15. 1 Pet. 3.16, 21. whereas other graces, though
excellent in their place, and kind are seldom so called. Where do we read of
good Faith, good Love, Holiness, etc. whereas Conscience is good of it self,
and makes the good Faith, the good Love, the good repentance, etc. which all
cease to be good when severed from the good conscience. Again, compare it with
all other good things, and it has the better of them, what good is there in a
chest full of goods, when the Conscience is empty of goodness? Quid prodest
plena bonis Area, si inanis sit Conscientia? said St. Austin, What if he has
good wares in his shop, a good stock in his ground, good clothes to his back,
etc. if he has not a good Conscience in his heart? This man is like Naaman, a
rich and honorable man, but a Leper. What are all great parts, and abilities,
without a good Conscience? but as sweet flowers upon a stinking carcass. Its
above all Faith alone, therefore they often go together in Scripture, 1 Timothy 1.5,
19. and 3.9. If this be put away Faith is shipwract. Nothing profits alone
without this; not Baptism, 1 Pet. 3.21. not Charity, 1 Timothy 1.5. not coming to
the Lords Supper, Heb. 10.22. not any serving of God, 2 Timothy 1.3. not obedience
to Magistrates,, Romans 13.5. not all our sufferings, 1 Pet. 2.19, 20. Let all
duties be performed, and Conscience nor regarded, and the man is but an
Hypocrite. Let all gifts remain, and profession stay, and the man is but an
Apostate. Hence Bernard, Vtilius est currere ad conscientiam, quam ad
sapientiam, nisi eadem sit sapientia quae conscientia. Its better running to
Conscience then to all your wisdom, unless you mean by your wisdom nothing but
Conscience. The unlearned man with a good conscience (says Saint Austin) will
go to Heaven, when thou with all thy Learning shall be cast into Hell. Surgunt
indocti and rapiunt regnum Coelorum, etc.

2. Its absolutely necessary to the very being of a Christian, whereas many
other things serve only to his better being. To suppose a Christian without
Conscience, were to suppose the Sun without light, and fire without heat. Its
of the very same consequence to spiritual life, as the sense of feeling is to
natural life, which has the pre-eminence of all other senses: For 1. Feeling
is the first sense in being: So is Conscience in the new Creature. 2. Feeling
is of absolute necessity. If a man want that, he is a dead man: So is
Conscience absolutely necessary to the very being of a Christian: A man may be
short in parts, weak in duties, defective in knowledge, and yet be a good
Christian: but if he has lost his Conscience, he is altogether dead. 3. Many
creatures excel man in other senses: but in feeling man excells most other: So
the best Christian excells in the tenderest, and quickest touch of Conscience.
4. Other senses have a particular Organ of their own, and lie in a narrow room:
as hearing in the ear, seeing in the eye, etc. but feeling is extended all the
body over, both within, and without. So is Conscience of a vast, and universal
extent over all our actions, intents, words, and motions from first to last.
Faith looks to promises: Fear to Threats: Hope to futures: Obedience to duties:
Repentance to sins, etc. but Conscience looks to all.


3. It most fortifies the soul with strength against, and gives victory over
all Adversaries. Its like the Ark with a window in the top to let in light from
Heaven. Like Elias Mantle, it divides the waters, and carries the godly soul^
through a flood of miseries as on dry Land. It encourages in the midst of
fire, and fagots, accompanies into Dens, and Caves, and made the Martyrs sing
in Dungeons, and flames. Its like the Anvile that breaks whatsoever is beaten
on it, but is it self by all strokes made more firm. It makes a man like a
brazen wall, Jer. 1.18. Its devoid of fear, as Job 5.22. It will encourage a
man to hold up his head before any judgment seat, Act. 23.1. yea, before Gods
Tribunal. 1 John 3.21. A cheerful Conscience makes a cheerful countenance,
Prove. 15 13. Tranquilla conscientia, tranquilla omnia.

4. It annoints the head with oil, and makes the cup run over with joy, and
consolation. Good Conscience's peace, is the peace that passes all
understanding. It makes a Heaven upon Earth: Its a continual feast, Prove.
15.15. the stranger intermeddles not with his joy. His feast is above
Ahasuerus's, Est. 1, 4. Its the greatest good a man can have, and the procurer,
and maintainer of all the good that a man is capable of here. Its the only
Paradise that God loves to walk in: the only Throne which Christ sits in: the
only Temple which the holy Ghost dwells in: the golden pot which the hidden
Manna is kept in: the white stone which the new name is written in, etc.

5. Its not only a real good it self, but makes all other things better where
it has to do, whence it deserves the title of a good Conscience. Riches,
Honor, Learning, etc. are not good really, but only in opinion, nor do you
alone make any man the better: But a good Conscience makes all good, and good
better where it comes. It finds some sinful, and leaves them holy: proud and
leaves them humble: covetous, and leaves them content, etc. It mends
Magistrates, Ministers, poor, rich, yea all. Its the treasury of good, and
therefore brings out nothing but what is good. Good communication, good
conversation: yea it makes actions indifferent in their own nature to become
good, and actions good to become better.

Quest. What is the danger, and mischief of an evil Conscience?

Answ. First, Here commonly is the first decay of a Christian. Hymeneus,
Alexander first put away a good Conscience, and then sunk in their Faith, 1 Timothy 1.20. when the Conscience is once corrupt, then presently so is the
judgment, then the affections, then the life, and then all. Corruption in the
Conscience is like poison in the Spring head. No man aims at the height of
impiety at once; and this is commonly the first step, when Conscience likes not
to retain the knowledge of God, he gives up to vile affections, then to a
reprobate mind, and at last to be filled with all manner of unrighteousness,
Romans 1.26, 28, 29. A hopeful professor by this means soon becomes a
dangerous Apostate, and at last a downright Atheist, Tit. 1.15, 16. The Sun
beginning to set in Conscience, night hastens on in the affections: Then
farewell grace: and when the Sun goes back in the heaven of Conscience, the
shadow goes back many degrees in the Dial of Comfort, then farewell peace.

Secondly, As the first decay usually begins here, so it proves the worst, and
Paul tells of some that had given themselves over to lasciviousness, etc.
Ephesians. 4.19. but they came to this height of impiety by blinding their minds,
and deadning their Consciences. In the last days many depart from the Faith,
and give heed to seducing spirits, etc. 1 Timothy 4.1. but they first feared their
Consciences, ver. 2. Its the ready, yea the only way to the sin against the
holy Ghost.

Job 9.4. If Conscience be disregarded in his two first Offices, he will be
known in his two last. If his ministerial reproofs, and Magistraticall rods be
slighted: He will as a witness, and a Judge, chasten thee with Scorpions.

Zach. 11.9. Rev. 22.11. 2 These. 2.10, 11, 12.

Quest. Is it so hard then to get, and keep a good conscience, and to escape a
bad?

Answ. Yes truly, as will appear in these three respects.

First, in respect of Satan, all whose spite is at a good Conscience, and all
his Pharaoh his Kingdom: nor Achithophel his policy: nor Absolon his beauty:
nor Haman his honor, and Offices, nor Dives his wealth, etc. he could make use
of all: yea he will offer his help to men to get these things, so they will
quit a good Conscience. But if a man be plundered of all his estate, and
stormed out of all his outworks of his riches, friends, children, power,
places: yea, out of his nearer comforts, out of his Faith, and hope: out of his
prayers, and promises, if he retreat to a good Conscience, and make good this
last refuge, Satan will be repelled with shame, and loss. Job when he had lost
all else, manfully defending this piece, he recovered all again at last, and
his last state was double to his first, Job 42.12, 13.

Secondly, In respect of thy self, or the work it self, thou shall find it a
hard Acts 24.16. Herein exercise I my self always, etc. i. e. I use all my
skill, diligence, and constancy together, (...).

Thirdly, In respect of others its still more difficult: many miscarry in it:
Tim. 1.19.

Quest. May a man's Conscience be quiet, yet not good?

Answ. Yea, there are four sorts of quiet Consciences, and never a one of them
good:

First, An ignorant Conscience: For as a blind man eats many a hair, and
drinks many a fly: so these know not that they do evil, and therefore are not
disquieted, but commit all uncleanness with greediness, Ephesians. 4.18, 19.
Abimelech boasts much of his integrity, Genesis 20.4, 5. when it was but morality,
or ignorance, therefore glory not of such a blind, deaf, and silent
Conscience: the dumb and deaf Devil was hardest to be cast out, Mar. 9.25,
26, 29.

Secondly, A Conscience that was never yet well awakened: But sin lies Jer.
51.39, 40. Or else it will awake, and cry out like a traveling woman, it will
destroy, and devour at once, Isa. 42.14. the Consciences of Joseph's brethren
were long asleep, but awaked at last, and made them tremble: So with Jonas, chapter
2.2.

Thirdly, A deluded Conscience, by Satan, or his instruments, which dreams Luke
11.21. when the strong man armed keeps possession, all is at peace, Lam. 2.14.
Ahab deluded speaks of nothing but peace, 1 Kin. 22.27. So Zach. 1.11. many
live and dye in this condition: the world says, they dye like Lambs, Psalm.
73.4. when its tather like Solomon's Ox, Prove. 7.22. So Jer. 51.38, 39. But its
better to dye the most dreadful death of the righteous, then the most
hopeful, and peaceful death of the wicked. These dye so securely, not because
the sting of death is taken out, which were their happiness, but because the
Conscience is taken out, which is their misery.

Fourthly, A hardened Conscience; This treasures up wrath against the day Romans
2.4, 5. Job 36.13. there is no greater plague on earth then this, no judgment
in Hell beyond it.

Quest. How manifold is this hardness of heart?

Answ. Its sixfold, as appears by the several expressions in Pharaohs
hard-heartedness: as

1. A natural hardness, and insensibleness of Conscience, which is part of
the sin, and punishment of Original sin, which is alike in all: called the
heart of stone, Ezekiel. 36.25.

2. An attracted, and acquired hardness, through frequent reiterations of sin,
and the secret curse of God upon it. Hence, Heb. 3.13. Ephesians. 4.17, 18, 19.
where are eleven steps by which the poor soul goes to hell: as 1. Vanity of
mind, wherein men think there is little hurt, but its the first step to Hell.
2. Darkness of understanding, which follows the former. 3. Alienation from the
life of God, Alienation actively on their part, they loathing God, a sinful
alienation: and passively on Gods part, his soul loathing them, a judicial
alienation. 4. Blindness of ignorance, one sin begetting another in
infinitum. 5. This blindness leads to further hardness, viz. judicial,
because of the hardness of their heart. 6. Then they are insensible, and past
feeling. 7. Then desperate, giving themselves over to sin, as Ahab, 1 Kin.
21.25. then they are quite lost. 8. Then they are brutish, turned into beasts,
they give themselves over to lasciviousness. So, 2 Pet. 2.14. Jer. 5.8. Romans
13.13. Philip. 3.19. 9. Then they work uncleanness: they draw sin with
Cartropes, etc. Isa. 5.18. 10. Then they are insatiable in sinning. So, Romans
1.23, 25. 11. Then the delight in it, committing all uncleanness with
greediness. Thus a man is trasnformed into a beast at first, and into a Devil
at last.


3. A judicial hardness, as

Then the Conscience, or heart is further hardened by Impostors, or Seducers.
So, Exodus 7.22. God gives them over to strong delusions to believe a lie, 2
These. 2.11. Hence God is said to lay a stumbling block before Apostates, Ezekiel.
3.20. to deceive false Prophets, Ezekiel. 14.9. and to put a lying spirit into
their mouths* 1 King. 22.23.

4. A Ministerial hardening. God lets them enjoy the Gospel, and means of
grace, but they having added to natural, voluntary hardness of heart, and to
contempt of the truth, a love of Error, God sends leanness of soul, under
fatness of Orninances: Hence Isai. 6.9, 10. then preaching proves the savor
of death, 2 Cor. 2.16. So Pharaoh grew worse and worse under Moses Ministry.

5. A Divine hardening: a penal hardening by Divine vengeance: called Gods
sending all his plagues upon the heart, Exodus 9.14. A heart hardened by the
curse of God is an Epitome of all plagues in the world, yea of all the plagues
of Hell. Yet here in God does not infundere malitiam, pour in malice, but non
infundere mollitiem, not put in softness. Hence, Romans 1.28.

6. A Satanicall hardening: Indeed Satan has his first, or second hand in
every sinful act, and an hand from the first hardening to the last. He
persuades, and prevails, 1 King. 22.22.

Quest. What are the marks of an ill troubled Conscience?

Answ. First, Troubles are then evil, when the root whence they spring is
evil. Thus Ahab was troubled till he was sick, not because his lust of
covetousness was unmortified, but because it was unsatisfied. So was Ammon. So,
Prove. 4.16. Some cannot sleep if they have done no mischief all day. This is
indeed the Devils trouble, and Hell is full of such troubled spirits.

Ahab, 1 Kin. 21.2.7. So Caine, Judas, Simon Magus, Act. 8.24. This is to be
troubled for Hell, not for sin.

Thirdly, When the carriage under troubles is evil, then its an evil

1. When men rage, and swell under Gods stroke, but their uncircumcised hearts
accept not of the punishment of their iniquity: So Caine stormed at his
punishment. So, Isa. 8.21, 22.

2. When notwithstanding their troubles they still go on in sin. Felix
trembled, but it wrought no good upon him, Act. 24.27. Jeroboam, 1 King. 12.33.
he was ill, but Ahaz was worse after judgments upon them, 2 Chro. 28.22. So,
Rev. 16.11. and 9.20.

3. Then troubles are evil, whose cure is evil, or when an evil course is
taken for their removal: as 1. When men fly to outward means to remove inward
grief, but go not to to God, as Caine, to traveling, and building of Cities.
Saul to David's Music. An ill diversion does but prorogue, not cure the
disease. 2. Wen they rest in the outward use, and observation of religious
means, without an inward change of heart, and through reformation of life: Ahab
humbled himself, fasts, mourns, etc, yet Ahab is Ahab still. Judas was full of
inward horror, confesses, and makes restitution, but goes not penitentially
to God, and fiducially to Jesus Christ. Jeremy therefore calls this a gadding:
its not a penitential returning, Jer. 2.36. 3. When men have recourse to
Diabolical, and sinful means: as Saul to the Witch: 1 Samuel 28.7, 8. Ahaziah
to Baal-zebub, 2 Kin. 1.2. Belshazzar to his Magitians, Dan. 5.7. So, 47.12,
13. 4. When men dispairingly give over all our hopes, and use of means, saying,
there is no hope, Jer. 2.25. and 18.12. This putting away all mercy is worse
then all the former. This was Cains case: I am sentenced, I must be damned: God
has not mercy for me, I will ask him none. This is a wilful casting away of
a man's self: This evil is of the Lord, 2 Kin. 6.33. why should I wait, or
pray, or repent, etc. This is to forsake our own mercies, Jonah, 2.8.


Quest. How may we know a good troubled conscience?

Answ. First, When our trouble is rather for our sins, then our sufferings:
when we cry out of our sins: as Lam. 5.16. So Jer. 31.19. Ephraim

Secondly, When in this condition we confess, bewail, and lament our sins, as
David, Psalm. 51.3. So, Job 7.20. and 3, 4.

Thirdly, When after this we forsake it, Prove. 28.13. such shall have mercy.

Fourthly, When we do not only forsake it as to the outward act, but the hides
pride from man, Job 33.17. when we can say, sin is more bitter then death,
Eccless. 7.26.

Fifthly, When upon this the heart is carried out to seek after Christ for
rest, Matthew. 11.29. when we go to this Fountain to wash away sin, Zach. 13.1.
Joh. 3.14, 15.

Sixthly, When after this the Conscience is made more watchful, and tender,
Job 34.31, 32.

Quest. What are the marks of an erroneous Conscience?

Answ. First, When it leaves the Word, which is the standing Rule to rectify
Conscience by, and prefers Traditions, or some humane invention before an
express Precept. So, Matthew. 15.13.

Secondly, When we leave the waters of Siloah, the holy Scriptures, which Deuteronomy.
13.3. Dan. 11.35. Erroneous Conscience imputes his success to his cause, and
his cause prospering, he styles Gods cause: This was Rabshakeh's Divinity, Isa.
36.10. and of the Chaldeans, Hab. 1.11. Such say, as Jer. 50 7. we offend not,
because they have sinned, and we have prevailed. Solomon tells us, we can
conclude nothing certainly from hence, Eccles. 9.1.2, 11. and 7.15. and 8.14,
ult.

King. 13.18. Now all divine revelations coming from the Spirit of Truth, are
ever consonant to the word of truth, which is the rule to try all revelations
by, 2 Pet. 1.19.

Fourthly, It prefers a strong impulse from his own thoughts, before Gods own
Jer. 7.31. God said, that it never came into his mind to approve of what they
did, yet they would do it, because it was their Conscience, and came into
their mind. But these impulses, though coming from a gracious Spirit, can be no
rule: as we see in David's impulse to build God an house, 2 Samuel 7.2, 3. so to
be revenged on Nabal, 1 Samuel 25.22. Prove. 28.26. He that trusts his own
heart is a fool. Hence, Job 15.31. Its trusting to vanity.

The time is not come (say they) to build Gods house, therefore its not our
duty, Hag. 1.2. but this is a sluggards Conscience, when he pretends a Lion in
the way, Prove. 26.13.

Job 13.7. Our Rule is, not to do the least evil to gain the greatest
beneficial good, or to avoid the greatest penal evil, Romans 3.8.

Seventhly, Its so confident that it dares appeal to God to patronise his
exorbitancies, Joh. 16.2. they thought they did God the best service, when they
did the Church the greatest disservice. So. Phil. 3.6. Paul out of zeal
persecuted the Church. So, Act. 23.12.

Quest. What motives may quicken us to get, and retain a good Conscience?

Answ. First, Remember that God weighs, and tries the Conscience, Prove.
16.2. So much of Conscience as is in a man, or duty, or action, or suffering,
so much of thanks, and esteem with God: So much Conscience as thou have toward
God, So much comfort is coming to thee from God.

Secondly, If Conscience be wanting, thou will suffer loss of all thou have, of
when you fasted was it not to your selves, etc? Ananias lost his cost when he
had been at so great charges: Alexander his reward when he had suffered so
much: Judas lost all after he had followed Christ so long, and preached to
others so often.

Thirdly, A good Conscience leads a man to perfect, and complete happiness

1. In this world its the only way to a good, and blessed life: and that 1. In
prosperity it will be as an hedge about all thou have, as the Candle of the
Lord in thy Tabernacle. 2. In adversity, it will be as the good houswifes
candle, that goes not out by night. Or like Isreal's Pillar of fire, it will not
leave thee in a wilderness. As Ruth to Naomi: or Ittai to David, 2 Samuel 15.21.
It will in all make thee more then a conqueror, Romans 8.37. its a man's dearest,
and closest friend that will visit him in prison, etc. 3. In death: it gives
rejoicing when under the stroke, and sentence of death. Its like Saul and
Jonathan, lovely in life, and in death not divided.


2. In the world to come: It will stand a man instead when he appears before
the great Tribunal of God, where courage dares not show its face: nor
eloquence open its mouth: nor Majesty has any respect: nor greatness any
favor: where money bears no mastery: as that Martyr said, Rev. 6.15, 16. Hence,
1 John 3.20, 21. Yea, its the step to the highest glory, and its the stare of
highest Beatitude. To be feasted with the fruits of a good Conscience, is
Angels food, and some of the sweet meats of Heaven: as a tormenting Conscience
is one of the greatest miseries of Hell.

Fourthly, Consider the miseries of an evil Conscience in life, in death, and

1. In this life: In the midst of prosperity he can have no security, Job 20.
especially, verse 16, 17, 22, 23, 24. and 15.21. there is no torment like that
of an evil Conscience: It marred Belshazzars feast, etc.

2. But much more in adversity: then Conscience that had been long silent, and
quiet, cries out, and flies in the sinners face: as in Joseph's brethren. This
woe, though dreadful, yet is the least, because shortest, and ends in a few
days, or years: but

2. At death: which is a great woe, and double to the former: All the
sufferings in this life to the wicked, whether in body, or in spirit, are
nothing if compared with that which follows: yet this also has an end, at the
day of judgment: But then follows another.

3. At the day of judgment, when all the Cataracts of wrath are set open, all
the vials emptied out: then shall that sealed book of Conscience be unclasped,
and out of their own mouth, and heart, and book shall they be judged: then
shall a Hell in Conscience be cast into a Hell of despair, and an Hell of
guilt into a Hell of pain: and this judgment is called Eternal judgment, Heb.
6.2. and the destruction of the wicked, an Everlasting destruction, 2 These.
1.9. and this Eternity is a vast Ocean, that has neither bank nor botton: A
Center that has no Circumference: no measures of times, nor number of ages can
fathom, or reckon the length of it. In which Eternity thy evil Conscience
shall accompany thee, and fill thy heart with new tortures of grief, and fear,
and wrath, and bitterness, and despair.

Quest. What then are the means whereby a good Conscience may be gotten, and
preserved?

Answ. First, They are either principal, or subservient. First, principal,

1. To get the blood of Christ sprinkled upon the Conscience, by the hand of
Faith, Heb. 9.14. All duties, gifts, observances, etc. are nothing to this.
Other things may make the outside clean before men, but the blood of Christ is
that alone which makes the Conscience clean before God, that there is now no
more Conscience of sin, as to the guilt, and spot of it. So Heb. 10.29. the
blood of the Covenant is that whereby the believer is sanctified, Christ's
wounds are our City of Refuge: Christ's blood is the well of Bethlehem, which we
should long for, and break through an Host of difficulties to come unto. Except
we drink this blood we have no life in us, etc. Joh. 6.53, 54.

2. To seek, and get the Spirit of Christ, which is the next principal
ingredient in, or efficient of a good Conscience: Its Gods Spirit with our
spirits that makes the good Conscience, Romans 9.1. The single Testimony of
natural Conscien^ (...) not much to be regarded: but when Conscience is
cleared by the Spirit, and (...) with the Spirit, the Testimony of these two is
great, and weig^^^^ Gods Spirit thus witnessing to our Spirit is the clearest
testimony of our Adoption, and Salvation, Romans 8.16. Hence, 1 Cor. 2.10, 11,
12. So then where the Spirit of God is, there is a good Conscience.



1. Thou must get Faith to make thee a good Conscience, therefore Faith, and a
good Conscience are often joined together, Acts 15.9. Christ gives faith for
this end, to purify the Conscience: where faith is pure, the Conscience is
pure: this makes the good, and mends the bad Conscience. Now this Faith that
makes, and keeps a good Conscience, is three fold: 1. Justifying Faith: for
there must be apprehending, and applying the blood of Christ, Act. 15.9. For
(...) qua creditur, is Fides qua vivitur. Faith whereby we believe, is the
faith whereby we live. 2. Doctrinal Faith, 1 Timothy 1.19. For corrupt opinions,
breed corrupt consciences: and corruption in morals, usually follows corruption
in intellectuals: Here begins commonly the first step backward to all Apostasy,
and the first step forward to all impiety. 3. A particular warranting Faith to
legitimate our actions, which also may in some sense be called a justifying
Faith, not to justify our persons from all guilt, but our actions from sin:
Every action that is good in it self is hereby sanctified to the use of
Conscience by the word of God. So Romans 14.5, 23.


2. Repentance, and the daily renewall thereof is a second means: This ever
goes along with true Faith, Mar. 1.15. Hence this was the total sum of what
Paul taught: To repent and believe, Act. 20.21. So, Job 11.14, 15. Conscience
must shut all known sin out a doors, or sin will soon thrust Conscience out a
doors.

3. If thou would have a good Conscience, observe what hints thou have at
any time from Christ, and the Spirit. Good Conscience must observe the eye,
voice, beck, finger, and every motion of Christ. As its a fearful judgment to
fear where no fear is. So its a foul sin not to fear where fear should be,
Jer. 5.3. Thou have smitten them, and they have refused to receive correction,
etc. Hence, Prove. 29.1. they shall suddenly be destroyed. Peter by observing
these hints from Christ, recovered after he had denied him.

4. Listen attentively to the mutterings, and whisperings of thy own
Conscience: Take notice what news Conscience brings thee home every day:
Commune often with thy own heart, Psalm. 4.4. So did David, Psalm. 77.6. These
Soliloquies are our best disputes, and the most useful conferences. Observe
every day what were thy actions, what were thy passions: See what words fell
from thee, what purposes, and thoughts were in thee. Non venitur ad bonam
Conscientiam, nisi per Cordis custodiam. Bern.

5. Yet so we must hearken to, and confer with Conscience, as also to confer
Conscience with the Scripture: that's the Book of life, and according to that,
our Conscience must be copied, or corrected. Unicuique suus liber est
Conscientia, Bern. Search the Scriptures, and trust not thine own judgment too
far. This rule well observed, would resolve what is to be done in many cases:
most men, whatsoever their opinion, and practice is, plead Conscience,
Conscience: Its my Conscience say they, my Conscience bids me do thus: I, but
what does God bid Conscience do? Had Adam never fallen, we should have needed
none other rule, but our own Consciences? But now we have a Law written, and
proclaimed, we must not make conscience the supreme Law, but the subordinate.
^deed Conscience is to have a negative voice, so that nothing is to be done
without his assent, and good liking: but it must not Challenge an arbitrary,
and illimited power to act, or determine any thing without the advice of this
great Council, the Law, and the Prophets.

6. Prayer is a great friend to good Conscience: the good Conscience makes many
a good Prayer: there is the particular demand of a good Conscience, 1 Pet. ^
21. which B^za understands of Prayer. Good Conscience has ever one eye upon
God to observe his precepts, and the other up to God to beg his direction:
usually such as are most frequent in prayer have the best Consciences: Acts
10.2. Cornelius. Hypocrites do not so, Job 27.10. and 21.14, 15.

7. Beware of committing the smallest sins, yea of many things which go for
lawful: the least spark may consume the greatest house, the least leak, the
greatest ship. Call not Faith, and troth small Oaths, they are more then yea,
and nay. Refrain idle words, rash anger, vain mirth foolish jesting, etc. The
greatest spoil made in Conscience, had at first but small beginnings. Qui
otiosum verbum non reprimit, ad noxia cito transit: and vanus sermo est vanae
Conscientiae index.

8. Take heed of adventring, though but upon one greater sinful act: lest it
for ever shut Conscience out of doors: One deliberate act of sin, threw the
Angels out of Heaven: that one sin deliberately committed by our first Parents
against an express precept cast them out of Paradise. So in Judas, Ananias, and
Saphira, etc.

9. Take heed of living under, and contenting thy self with a cold,
man-pleasing Ministry, which sows pillows under thine Armholes, crying Peace,
peace. The voice of a faithful Preacher is the voice of a Crier, Isa. 40.3. His
found, the sound of a Trumpet, Isa. 58.1. His words like sharp nails, etc.
Eccl. 12.11. So, Mal. 3.2. Isa. 11.4, 10. Take great heed whom thou choosest
for thy bosom friend: Ill acquaintance has undon many. One sinner destroys
much good: One corrupt man, corrupts another, 2 Samuel 13.3.

10. In things doubtful, be well advised, or forbear, and take the surer, and
safer way. Some defend Usury, Cards, Dice, long hair, naked necks, etc. But
most condemn them. Judge what is safest, and let these be thy rules to judge
by, Ephesians. 5.11. Phil. 4.8.

11. Take heed of worldly mindedness: there is no greater enemy to Conscience:
These Thorns choke the best seeds of grace: and this Canker eats out the very
life of Conscience: For, for a piece of bread such an one will transgress: Such
will break their word, betray their trust, deceive their brother, falsify
their wares, weights, measures, lie for advantage: Riches and a good Conscience
seldom dwell under the same roof.

12. Take heed of an Erroneous Conscience: This is as wildfire in dry Corn: as
the wild Bore, or ravening Bear: as the wild Ass, Jer. 2.24. Many hopeful
Professors being once leavened with Error, do first in their hearts
undervalue, and contemn, and then with their mouths vilify, and disgrace those
faithful Ministers, whom they formerly magnified, and highly prized.

Mr. Sheffield in his accute, and accurate Treatise of Conscience.

Quest. What are the signs of a good Conscience, whereby it may be known?

Answ. First, It may be known by the causes of it: Its not the work of

Secondly, By the manner whereby it is wrought in us: For its not wrought by
worldly persuasions, taken from our credit, pleasure, profit, etc. but by the
Ministry of the word begetting faith in us whereby the heart is purified, and
this it does. 1. By terrifying with the sight and sense of our sin., and the
punishments due for the same, whereby we are humbled: and then, Secondly, by
pacifying, and comforting it; by offering to us in Christ the free pardon of
our sins, reconciliation with God, and the eternal salvation of our souls.

Psalm. 26.2. After which Audit, it will justify us in regard of our integrity,
as Ps. 17.3. Not in respect of the perfection of our performance, which is full
of wants and weaknesses; but of our desire and resolution, Psalm. 130.3. and
143.2.



1. As its peaceable, so also its pure, not only from the guilt of sin, but
